description: NOW at the Arena Players Repertory Theater in East Farmingdale is "I Hate Hamlet," a droll comedy whose ordinary message is that money cannot buy personal satisfaction. What is extraordinary are the theatrical flourishes that the author, Paul Rudnick, employs to make his point.

title: Headhunters Try to Find A Heartbeat In Job Market
description: HEADHUNTERS are reputed to be an optimistic lot, but not in Connecticut. In a recent random survey of search agencies that match employees with positions paying $100,000 and up, headhunters were glum about the prospects of a turnaround in the state's depressed market. They cited few sectors of strength and many weak ones.

title: Andrea LoCascio, James Lardiere
description: Andrea Lauren LoCascio, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Vincent LoCascio of Yonkers, was married yesterday to James Joseph Lardiere, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Lardiere of Basking Ridge, N.J. The Rev. Peter Donohue performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the Church of the Transfiguration in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title:
Viewpoints;
A Clean Slate for Clean Energy
description: THE WAY we produce and consume energy affects our economy, our environment and our jobs. Burning coal produces electricity, but also the pollutants that cause acid rain and global warming. Gasoline fuels our cars, but is also made more and more with imported oil and is the chief cause of urban smog. Nuclear energy produces electricity, but also the dangerous radioactive wastes for which there is no permanent, safe storage site.

title: Now and Always, Fashion Mad
description: SUNDAY morning. A car arrives to take you to the Abyssinian Baptist Church in Harlem. Andre Leon Talley, Vogue magazine's ambassador to Paris, is waving from the back seat. His shoulders are festooned with gold braid, part of an officer's uniform in some navy that sails only in the mind of Yohji Yamamoto. You jump into the car.

title: No Headline
description: I've got a lover who has got AIDS and I have to support him. Then I have to contend with my own diagnosis. Then I have my friends who are struggling and dying. Then my patients. It's sort of like Camus's 'The Plague.' When there are so many dead bodies, what do you do, just step over them? -- DR. LEON McKUSICK, a psychologist who is infected with H.I.V. [ 32:3. ]

title: Amy Fisher Locales Shunned by Producers
description: Three production companies are racing to complete television movies of the Amy Fisher story, but none of the filming is being done on Long Island, where the drama played itself out.

title: POSTINGS: 3 Lincoln Center; Japanese Take Title to 312 Condos
description: The apartment tower called 3 Lincoln Center is certainly in the right place, overlooking the complex from which it takes it name.

title: A Cousin For Nessie?
description: Some years ago a French zoologist, Bernard Heuvelmans, coined the term "cryptozoology" to describe the activity of those who apply scientific methods to the study of hidden animals, or "cryptids." Now two Canadian marine researchers, Dr. Edward L. Bousfield and Dr. Paul K. LeBlond, suggest in a paper that large serpentine creatures comprising "a distinct vertebrate species of presently indeterminate class" are swimming lakes and coastal waters of British Columbia and may even be related to the Loch Ness monster.

title: Installing Insulation, at Least in Theory, Is Not Difficult
description: INSULATING the floor above an unheated basement or crawl space can save on heating bills and increase comfort in the winter. In theory, the job is not difficult. It usually consists of fastening strips of fiberglass or mineral-wool insulation between the floor joists. But in practice the task can be dirty, awkward and time-consuming unless the basement is in a new house and there is plenty of headroom.

title:
All About/Skiing;
The Slopes Battle a Bad Economy and the Wrong Weather
description: STILL smarting from a string of nearly snowless winters and from consumers who hid their wallets during the recession, the American ski industry is fighting a counteroffensive on all fronts.

title: A Mission of Mercy for Travnik
description: The world continues its pretense of protecting Bosnia and punishing Serbia. The United Nations imposed a no-fly zone over Bosnia on Oct. 9, but Serbian planes and helicopters by the hundreds have violated that ban. The U.N. voted to tighten the trade embargo on Serbia by imposing a naval blockade, but ships still carry contraband down the Danube to Serbia.

title: Butch Reynolds Says He's Back in the Race
description: The world record-holder at 400 meters,BUTCH REYNOLDS, who was awarded $27.3 million in damages against the International Amateur Athletic Federation by a Federal court in Ohio, said he would return to competition despite federation threats to countersue or take further disciplinary action against him.

title:
DINING OUT;
Innovative Food and High Standards
description: JUST before the bridge that crosses the Delaware River from Frenchtown into Pennsylvania, there is an old building on the right called the Frenchtown Inn. Seven years ago, Bob and Holly Long bought the inn and turned it into a mecca for people who enjoy innovative cooking.

title: Eskimos Learn They've Been Living Amid Secret Pits of Radioactive Soil
description: The season of darkness, two months without a sunrise, has fallen over much of the Alaskan Arctic, and with it has come a sense of betrayal and uneasiness among the native people not seen for some time.

title: So Get It Off Your Chest
description: Christopher Janney, an artist, has turned a high-tech gadget into a fashion accessory.

title: Baseball, Heal Thyself
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Symbol, Songs, Food, Traffic
description: LAST Monday night, Allan Gurganus, the author of the best-selling "Oldest Living Confederate Widow Tells All," was in the basement of the Museum of Modern Art's bookstore, looking for slides to illustrate a lecture on narrative in painting, which he would give the following week in Boston. He was flushed and in a bit of a rush, because he was expected upstairs to give a reading as part of MOMA's ceremony to mark A Day Without Art, in memory of people who have died of AIDS.

title: Bequest Blends Into a Museum's Scheme
description: AT the New Britain Museum of American Art, the spotlight is on a collection bequeathed by Olga Knoepke, who died recently. Little of the collector's life is revealed, beyond her having been a member and friend of the museum for the last four years. But it is clear from the two dozen paintings, drawings and sculptures in the exhibition that her taste was for 20th-century American art excluding abstraction. Hence, the gift should fit easily into the museum's collection.

title: At Work; AIDS Awareness Goes to the Office
description: The Federal Government last week used the occasion of World AIDS Day to launch "Business Responds to AIDS," a workplace awareness and education program. Several officials, including Health and Human Services Secretary Louis W. Sullivan, encouraged employers to provide education on AIDS for all employees and support for employees who have AIDS or are infected with the human immunodeficiency virus.

title: In the Region: New Jersey; Recent Sales
description: Glen Rock $245,000 14 Grandview Avenue 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 92-year-old colonial; new roof, siding and heating system, eat-in-kitchen; taxes $4,665. Livingston $170,000 1 Claremont Avenue 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 38-year-old split level; family room, 1-car garage, fireplace in living room; $3,853. Maplewood $159,900 32 Colgate Road 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 45-year-old colonial; 2-car garage, 2-zone heat; taxes $4,555. Short Hills $780,000 65 Lake Road 4-bedroom, 4-bath, 4-half bath, 36-year-old colonial; family room, 2-car garage, fireplace, porch; taxes $12,927. South Orange $360,000 332 West End Road 5-bedroom, 2-bath, 3-half bath, 42-year-old Tudor; deck, fireplace, 2-car garage, eat-in-kitchen; taxes $9,664. West Orange $195,000 35 Edgewood Avenue 5-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 45-year-old Cape Cod; enclosed porch, full basement, 2-car garage, eat-in-kitchen; taxes $5,085. OTHER AREAS Ossining, N.Y. $202,000 57 Park Avenue 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 34-year-old Cape Cod; fireplace, formal dining room, den, deck, hobby room, family room; taxes $5,287. Bayville, L.I. $214,000 5 Hilltop Drive 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 68-year-old Tudor; dining room, fireplace, finished basement, carport; taxes $3,200. New Canaan, Conn. $1,325,000 110 Greeley Road 5-bedroom, 4 1/2-bath, 4-year-old custom colonial; french doors, brick terrace, invisible fence, 2 acres; taxes $11,671.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Lewiston, Me.;
City Steps In To Save a Mill
description: THIS central Maine city is trying to salvage a historic textile mill that once employed 6,700 workers and made one-third of the nation's textiles.

title: Taste of the Town
description: Craig Claiborne created a new kind of food journalism during the 1960's and 70's in his weekly column in The New York Times. He wrote about both professional and amateur cooks and treated the home cook with the same respect and interest he accorded the professionals. He also wrote about the unbelievable diversity of ethnic cooking in New York City. Molly O'Neill, the food columnist for The New York Times Magazine, continues his approach in her NEW YORK COOKING (Workman, $17.95). This is not a cookbook in the traditional sense of the word, but rather an enthusiastic collection of food lore, essays and recipes gathered over the past five years. The approach is not necessarily focused on the best recipes available; it reflects the tastes of the people Ms. O'Neill writes about. There are, however, some wonderful recipes, like Sirio Maccioni's pasta primavera, La Cote Basque's stuffed vegetables and Eileen Yin-Fei Lo's honey walnut appetizer. There are also recipes from celebrities, among them the painter Robert Motherwell, the restaurateurs Jennifer and George Lang, Estee Lauder and Katharine Hepburn. From home cooks there are interesting recipes like potato focaccia and an unusual version of minestrone alla Genovese in which lard is used instead of olive oil, a practice that was common in Italian households until concern for saturated fat hastened the substitution of olive oil. Some recipes are slightly changed versions of well-known ones; some, like a pasta sauce with 17 ingredients, gave me heartburn just to read. Ms. O'Neill offers an antipasto of ethnic cooking with something for every taste. But in her zeal to capture the true diversity of New York cooking, she has given us a book that is complicated by a somewhat confusing format. Besides recipes and anecdotes, there is a great deal of information on where to shop for particular ingredients, as well as dates and places for ethnic festivals. For me the least attractive feature of this book is the constant reference, no matter the origin of a particular recipe, to chicken broth as "New York penicillin." Molly O'Neill is too good a writer to depend on such cliches. Overall, however, "New York Cooking" is well written, informative and entertaining.

title: Rancor Grows Between Baymen and Anglers
description: RECREATIONAL fishermen and East Hampton baymen have been squabbling since the 1970's, when a decline in striped bass and an increase in state regulation provoked charges that one group or the other was responsible for threatening the legendary fish.

title: Robert Lepage: Multicultural and Multifaceted
description: Robert Lepage stepped forward at the Royal National Theater's Lyttelton auditorium for his third curtain call following "Needles and Opium" one recent evening and, suddenly, this most assured of performers seemed uncertain how to respond. The Quebecois actor-writer-director turned up his palms and gave a slight, very Gallic shrug, as if to ask, "Who's all this attention for -- moi?"

title: A Sorter-Out of Ideas That Clog the Imagination
description: Until his obituary came in over the fax two weeks ago, I had no idea what Sir John Summerson looked like, knew almost nothing about the personal life of this great architectural historian. But for years his words have been marching around in my brain, and his death (at 87) won't halt the march. Many of those words were written before I was born, including one sentence that for me sums up a critic's marching orders. "The most a critic can do," Summerson wrote in 1947, "is to sort out those aging ideas that get encrusted round past creative achievement and clog the proper working of the imagination in changing times."

title: Old Hand
description: Yevgeny Kissin -- THE 21-year-old Russian pianist who is being talked about in terms of Vladimir Horowitz, who is a throwback to the old Russian Romantic style, who is currently the hottest item on the international circuit of classical pianists, who is a child and beneficiary of the new Russian revolution -- was fooling around at the piano. He was playing not Chopin, not Liszt, not Rachmaninoff but Scott Joplin rags. He adores Joplin.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: VICTORIAN CHRISTMAS

title: Aid for the Aging
description: Burden Center salutes an executive, Nov. 30.

title: Lilly Lee, Gary Tsang
description: Lilly Lee, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Wing Yui Lee of Brooklyn, was married yesterday to Gary Tsang, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Kin Sown Tsang, also of Brooklyn. The Rev. Matthew Lui performed the ceremony at the First Chinese Presbyterian Church in New York.

title: Where to Place Blame For Latin Misery
description: While I am sympathetic to the struggling largely El Salvadoran immigrants, it should be apparent by now that most of them are not political refugees, but rather victims of an economic and social order that has long abandoned them, and they're here more or less permanently.

title: Topics of The Times; Presidential Pronouncement
description: There are still people who say "Roo-zuh-velt" when speaking of the Presidents Roosevelt; it's "Roe-zuh-velt." And there are doubtless some who never caught on to Ronald Reagan's "Ray-gn."

title:
ABOUT MEN;
Gender de Plume
description: A small ad in the back of Poets & Writers magazine asked for stories or poems on "the experience of Catholic girlhood," so I submitted a story that seemed to fit the bill. I was hoping for the satisfaction of publication, not an unwilling and somewhat public change of gender.

title: Milan Report
description: There was a time when we really believed that all you needed was love. Bras were abandoned in the dresser drawer. Hair was ironed and Afro-ed. We all knew who had what kind of bellybutton. But what we looked like wasn't really about fashion, it was about expressing ourselves -- and the Beatles getting back together. Free love. Free Angela Davis.

title: Park Service Raising Fees
description: The National Park Service is raising single-visit entrance fees at 126 parks, monuments, wildlife refuges and other areas from Jan. 1. At most affected areas, the vehicle fee will rise by $1, to $4, and the individual fee by $1, to $2.

title: Talking: Town Services; Condos And Co-ops Ask Equity
description: Residents of condominiums, co-ops or homeowner associations spread over many acres have been fighting for more than a decade for such municipal services as garbage pickups and road maintenance.

title: Price of Disability Has Few Guarantees
description: A week ago tonight, the Jets' owner, Leon Hess, visited Dennis Byrd at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan. Byrd's neck was broken and he was paralyzed from the waist down after colliding head-first with his teammate Scott Mersereau during a loss to the Kansas City Chiefs that afternoon.

title: Freedom Fighters
description: LIBERATORS Fighting on Two Fronts in World War II. By Lou Potter with William Miles and Nina Rosenblum. Illustrated. 303 pp. New York: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $29.95.

title: Bahr Caught in Giant Shuffle
description: In a series of roster moves, some surprising, the Giants today ended the seasons of Matt Bahr and Steve DeOssie, placing them on injured reserve, and apparently ended the New York career of John Washington by waiving him.

title: Results Plus
description: SKIING Austrian Takes Slalom Anita Wachter of Austria, capitalizing on a fall by first-run leader Pernilla Wiberg, captured a women's World Cup giant slalom yesterday by six-tenths of a second over surprising Italian Sabina Panzanini at Steamboat Springs, Colo. Another Italian, Deborah Compagnoni, placed third in her first World Cup since tearing knee ligaments last February at the Winter Olympics.

title: For the Government, Contractors Have Special Rates
description: THE Environmental Protection Agency hired American Coastal Resources in 1991 for help in buying computers and office equipment. But only after the North Carolina company had submitted months of excessive bills did an auditor discover that the E.P.A. was paying four times the market price and wasting millions of dollars.

title: Liora Shir, Stephen Yalof
description: April wedding plans have been announced for Liora Shir and Stephen Justin Yalof, by the bride's parents, Menachem Shir and Miriam Ruzow, and by Stephen L. Ruzow, the bride's stepfather.

title: Puppetry at UConn: No Second-String Major
description: THE stage looked as if it had been lifted right out of London circa 1840, with a sweeping skyline of sooted chimneys, thatched roofs, arched doorways, a looming clock tower and St. Paul's Cathedral off in the distance.

title: Susan Landau, Richard Glasser
description: Susan Landau, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Landau of Hartsdale, N.Y., was married last evening to Dr. Richard M. Glasser, a son of Frieda Glasser of Naples, Fla., and the late Jack Glasser. Rabbi Stephen D. Franklin performed the ceremony at the Ridgeway Country Club in White Plains.

title: Outsiders for Drug Testing?
description: To the Editor:

title: NUNN UNDER FIRE FROM GAY GROUPS
description: Senator Sam Nunn removed two aides a decade ago for being gay, and gay rights groups are now contending that his action disqualifies him from a post in a Clinton Administration.

title: Ms. Denison, Jeffrey Walsh
description: Mary Ellen Denison, a textiles company executive in New York, was married in Larchmont, N.Y. yesterday to Jeffrey James Walsh, a newspaper editor in White Plains. Msgr. Walter Kenny performed the ceremony at St. Augustine's Roman Catholic Church.

title: The Riddle Solved
description: When The Book Review asked Edward Sorel to create the drawings for many of the features in this holiday issue, we asked him, as has been our custom, to include an extra picture that would challenge the imaginations of some of our best storytellers. Six writers rose to the occasion.

title: 'SO HOW DID I GET HERE?'
description: Bray should be directing most of her anger at her father, not at the state or at the people who have jobs and pay taxes.

title: Thoroughly Modern Victoriana
description: A FANFARE is a loud flourish of trumpets, a noisy or showy display. So the organizers of the New York Philharmonic's Victorian Ball, next May 26, decided that "fanfare" would be a great name for an event connected with the ball.

title: All-Consuming Art
description: THORSTEIN VEBLEN, meet Wendy Wasserstein.

title: A Cache of Roman Mosaics
description: COMING from any direction, travelers have a memorable first glimpse of Volubilis. Whether you approach this Roman city in Morocco from the exotic labyrinth of Fez, about an hour and a half away by car, or the bustling city of Meknes, a drive of half an hour, you spot the spectacular ruin first from a hilltop. Suddenly you see in the distance an agglomeration of columns and arches. This concentration of intensely civilized forms is on a high plateau surrounded on all four sides by land that drops down to a fertile river valley.

title: Church Weighs Its Response To Ruling on Lesbian Pastor
description: Members of a Presbyterian church here are debating whether to press for change or disobey a national church ruling barring them from hiring a co-pastor who is a lesbian.

title: NOV. 28-DEC. 5: A Bigger Melting Pot; Census Officials Revise Population Predictions Up
description: The Census Bureau said last week that the nation's population would grow by 50 percent in the next 60 years. And it adopted new demographic assumptions that alter the image of America as a melting pot.

title: Natalie Monroe, Richard Thigpen
description: June wedding plans have been announced for Richard Thomas Thigpen, a Congressional aide in Newark, and Natalie Patrice Monroe, an associate product manager at Best Foods, the food manufacturer, in Englewood Cliffs, N.J.

title: Q and A
description: Round-the-World Air Fare

title: Envoy Asserts Intervention in Somalia Is Risky and Not in Interests of U.S.
description: In a strongly worded warning to Washington, the American Ambassador to Kenya has said that the military intervention in Somalia presents more risks than the United States realizes and is not in this country's interests.

title: POSTINGS: Queens 'Incubator'; Storage for Start-Up Businesses
description: Construction on a new warehouse designed to provide storage facilities for small start-up businesses began last month in Long Island City, Queens, across the East River from mid-Manhattan. The building, the first new commercial structure started in Long Island City in two years, is on 49th Avenue and 11th Place, 200 feet from the entrance to the Queens-Midtown tunnel. It is across the street from the IND subway line's Vernon Boulevard-Jackson Avenue stop and the Long Island Rail Road's Hunter's Point station.

title: Offense Vows to Shake Shades of Finals Past
description: The University of Virginia and the University of San Diego are determined to overcome the stigma of the scoreless tie that has marred the championship game of the Division I soccer tournament in recent years.

title: State Bypasses Town In Zoning Approval
description: AS the State Environmental Conservation Department nears a decision on controlling development in nine areas of Long Island deemed crucial to ground-water quality, another state agency is leading a drive to build a corporate headquarters in one such area.

title:
Gift Books: Bulldogs, Beatles, Bullfinches, Bananafish;
Yesterdays
description: Paul McCartney was my favorite Beatle. When I was 15 years old I used to devise horrifying-death scenarios for his red-haired girlfriend, Jane Asher. When their relationship ended, I threw a party for all my Beatle friends and we wickedly threw darts at a picture of Jane's cheeky freckled face. Maybe now I would get

title: Union Rides the Wind To North Jersey Crown
description: When Lou Rettino, the coach of Union High School's football team, woke up this morning and heard the howl of a brisk wind outside his bedroom window, he must have smiled. He had to know then that Randolph, a pass-happy offensive machine, would be in for a long day in its showdown with Union for the North Jersey, Section 2, Group 4 championship.

title: In Support of Buyouts, Not Flood Tunnel
description: The article "Passaic Flood Tunnel: A Turning Point" (Nov. 8) identified several important points that should be evaluated carefully by the decision makers dealing with flood control within the Passaic River Basin.

title: Effort to Get Food Out to Somalis Falls Prey to Arms and Frustration
description: In a renewed example of the instability that threatens famine relief efforts here, aid workers were thwarted today as they tried to move 400 tons of food stacked up at the city's port. As hungry Somalis awaited the rations at feeding centers, the aid effort again bogged down because warlords would not guarantee safe passage.

title: Paris Report
description: The set should have been a tip-off. The designer Karl Lagerfeld, returning to the house of Chloe after an absence of nearly 10 years, had asked that the bare tent in a courtyard of the Louvre -- where the French pret-a-porter collections are shown -- be transformed into a sentimental valentine.

title: American Express Begins Search to Replace Chief
description: The American Express Company said yesterday that it had begun to seek a replacement for James D. Robinson 3d, its chairman and chief executive for 15 years.

title: Cookies for Eating and Giving as Christmas Gifts
description: MANY years ago, some friends of mine made it a rule that their three children were never to buy them presents. Since then, these children have come up with gifts they have made themselves, ranging from paintings and hand-knitted sweaters to cookies and cakes. Of course, these were appreciated much more than anything bought in a store, and the children liked making them, too.

title: Red Sox and Dodgers Are Desperate to Add Punch to Lineups
description: Don't tell the Boston Red Sox and the Los Angeles Dodgers that pitching is 75 percent of the game, or 90 percent, or whatever Connie Mack proclaimed many decades before the 1992 Red Sox and Dodgers proved a team has to hit home runs and score runs occasionally to win games.

title: CURRENCY
Kelly McCaffrey, Stephen Chase
description: Mr. and Mrs. James P. McCaffrey of West Norwalk, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Kelly Anne McCaffrey, to Stephen Bartlett Chase, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold A. Chase of Greenwich, Conn. A June wedding is planned.

title: 'SO HOW DID I GET HERE?'
description: The question raised in the title of Rosemary L. Bray's article " 'So How Did I Get Here?' " (Nov. 8) is given a clear answer in her piece. She had a strong mother, with vision -- a supportive parent so concerned with the education of her child that she recruited a neighbor to help her teach her daughter to read when she was 3 years old. A mother like this is not available to all children.

title: U.S. Role Is Not to Disarm, Aide to a Top Somali Insists
description: Taking a tough stance as the arrival of United States troops appro aches, a key backer of the most powerful Somali warlord said today that any disarming of fighters should be carried out by the Somali police and not by Americans.

title: Hospital Bills and Paying Them
description: By court order, New Jersey had to change the way it compensated hospitals for unpaid care. But last week the state went far beyond that task, not only adopting a controversial alternative on paying for indigent care, but making momentous changes in the rules governing health insurance and hospital charges.

title: Celia Slom, Greg Vimont
description: Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Slom of New York have announced April wedding plans for their daughter, Celia Slom, and William Gregory Vimont, a son of Shirley Vimont of San Antonio and the late Lieut. Col. William Vimont of the United States Army.

title: Ms. Geoghan, Donald Sullivan
description: Margaret Mary Geoghan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph E. Geoghan of Wilton, Conn., was married there yesterday to Donald Patrick Sullivan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Sullivan of Garden City, L.I. The Rev. Michael Palmer performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at Our Lady of Fatima Church.

title: RECORD BRIEFS
description: Tom Ze: 'The Hips of Tradition' Luaka Bop 945118-2; CD and cassette. TXT>

title:
Viewpoints;
Getting It Backward on Antitrust
description: A NEW study by the McKinsey Global Institute in Washington demonstrates that competition makes America more competitive, but not every policy maker seems to be getting the message. Congress has been at work on a comprehensive "competitiveness" package, and some proposals being advanced twist the meaning of that term beyond recognition. One illustration is a bill called the Fundamental Competitiveness Act of 1992, introduced by Representative Robert S. Walker of Pennsylvania and 14 other Republican members of the House. It declares that globalization has rendered American antitrust law counterproductive and proposes weakening Section 7 of the Clayton Act, the antitrust statute limiting mergers. The catch is that although this measure was offered in the name of competitiveness, it would actually make America less competitive.

title: A Show by Contemporary Italian Artists
description: IT took Simon Rodia from 1921 to 1954 to erect the Watts Towers in Los Angeles. Rodia was one of the countless Italian artisans whose skills were indispensable to American architects in the early 20th century. His labor of love (and patriotism), however, is a masterpiece of folk art nouveau, reminiscent of its high-art predecessor in Barcelona, the Church of the Sagrada Familia, by Gaudi.

title:
Long Island Q&A;: Richard Vaczy;
Inspiration and Other Talents Behind Comedy Shows on TV
description: RICHARD VACZY wrote and was executive producer of "The Golden Girls" television series, for which he was nominated for two Emmy and three Golden Globe awards. In 1988 he won a People's Choice award for producing the Best Comedy Series, "My Two Dads." Mr. Vaczy also wrote "My Two Dads" and episodes of "Benson," "Newhart," "227" and "Married . . . With Children."

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: A JOHN JAY CHRISTMAS

title: Gifts of Gab for '93
description: With all thy getting," the publisher B. C. Forbes liked to quote from Proverbs 4:7, "get understanding."

title: Run Knocks Rowan Out Of Playoffs
description: Washington and Jefferson 18, Rowan 13

title: Oaxaca's Way With Christmas
description: MEXICO is known for its Christmas festivities, which in many parts of the country begin on Dec. 12 with the celebration in honor of the Virgin of Guadalupe and continue to Epiphany, on Jan. 6. Perhaps best known to foreign visitors are the Christmas Eve posadas, in which children walk from house to house in re-creation of Mary and Joseph's search for lodging in Bethlehem, followed by a family feast known as the Cena de Noche Buena.

title: L.I. Builders Reviving Pine Barrens Plans
description: THE frustration of builders on Long Island over a suit that has delayed their projects within 110,000 acres of the region's Central Pine Barrens for the last three years was ended late last month when the state's highest court, the Court of Appeals, dismissed the case.

title: Fannie Bear Besser Dies at 92; Did Legal Work for 70 Years
description: Fannie Bear Besser, who at the age of 20 became one of New Jersey's first female lawyers and did legal work until she was 90, died on Friday at St. Barnabas Hospital in Livingston, N.J. She was 92 years old and lived in East Orange, N.J.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: MAX IN HOLLYWOOD, BABY

title: For Seoul Ex-Firebrand, A New, Maybe Final Run
description: The last time South Korea's most famous dissident and opposition leader, Kim Dae Jung, ran for president, a million and a half Koreans poured into a plaza for one of his famed rallies, a cloud of tear gas drifted over the city, and a few more extreme supporters periodically bit off the tips of their fingers to write his name in blood.

title: Streak Does Wonders for the Nets
description: Nets Coach Chuck Daly was asked about his team's six-game winning streak.

title: Dow Chemical Revamping
description: The Dow Chemical Company has announced the early stages of a revamping that will divide the company's management into three businesses.

title: Landmarks Panel to Hear TriBeCa Plan
description: After years of veering between conflicting impulses -- to preserve its architectural heritage (about five stories high) or exploit its development potential (more like 50) -- the TriBeCa area of lower Manhattan is nearing a decisive moment.

title: Essay; Iraqgate Deadline Day
description: Tomorrow, Dec. 8, is the day that the Attorney General of the U.S. has set for receipt of a report that will force a decision to obey the law or to continue to break the law.

title: ABC's Extra Careful Look At 'Jackie Thomas Show'
description: ABC executives were so concerned about the performance of the network's new comedy, "The Jackie Thomas Show," that they commissioned a special minute-by-minute ratings report on the show's premiere episode last week.

title: For Giants, the More Things Change, the More They Remain the Same
description: New starters on offense and defense, new kicker, new punter, same old Giants. All the changes did nothing for the Giants today as the Washington Redskins played better offense and sounder defense and won going away, 28-10.

title: Divorced, Middle-Aged and Happy: Women, Especially, Adjust to the 90's
description: When Lynn Steinhauer divorced a few years ago, after more than two decades of marriage, she expected to feel lost and lonely. Instead, she delighted in the peaceful pleasures of an empty house and a table set for one.

title: For the Real Potholes, See Moynihan
description: "ISN'T it about time we had a Senator" rivals George Wallace's "send them a message" as a campaign slogan that resoundingly struck a responsive chord. The time was 1970. The would-be Senator was James L. Buckley. The "we" were New Yorkers who for one reason or another felt disenfranchised.

title: Treasury to Auction Only Bills This Week
description: Treasury financings this week are confined to today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills normally held each Monday.

title: Vacated Corporate Headquarters Scatter the Suburban Landscape
description: After more than 20 years as a magnet for large corporations, the lush suburban landscape of Fairfield County, Conn., has become home to hundreds of vacant executive offices that analysts say are among the worst white elephants of American business.

title: In Recording Industry, Harmony Is Everything
description: Ed Germano, owner of the Hit Factory, likes to say his business is making people happy. "I entertain," he says.

title: Classical Music in Review
description: Sacred Music in a Sacred Space Church of St. Ignatius Loyola Park Avenue at 84th Street

title: Alpine Journal; Cultural Frictions of a Border Town
description: For nearly a year, employees of the grocery store in this quiet town near the Mexican border kept a yellow ledger titled Mexican Incident Book, which chronicled their complaints about the migrant workers who camp across the road.

title: Better Times May Lead Clinton to Focus on Deficit
description: The economic team that President-elect Bill Clinton has chosen and a recent pickup in economic growth mean that Mr. Clinton is likely to take a tougher approach to reducing the Federal budget deficit than he expressed during the campaign, transition team members said this weekend.

title: Toasting the Philharmonic's 150th: Count the Ways
description: It was 150 years ago tonight that a few hundred subscribers to the new Philharmonic Society of New York took their seats at the Apollo Rooms, on lower Broadway, and heard Ureli Corelli Hill lead the society's new orchestra in its first concert. After the Beethoven Fifth Symphony, Mr. Hill yielded that baton to Henry C. Hill, who led opera arias and duets by Weber, Beethoven, Mozart and Rossini and overtures by Weber and Kalliwoda. There was even some chamber music, a quintet by Hummel.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Press Notes; A Publisher's Observations About His 'Vanity Paper'
description: ARTHUR L. CARTER, who may be worth $100 million, definitely did not make his money in newspaper publishing. That, he has learned, takes more patience than the businesses in which he did amass his fortune: finance, real estate and water utilities.

title: Review/Opera; Ozawa's Met Conducting Debut In a Frankly Romantic 'Onegin'
description: Tchaikovsky would have expected that any viewer of "Eugene Onegin" -- which he called a series of "lyric scenes," not an opera -- would have known the characters inside out from Pushkin's classic poem. This story of wealthy Onegin, a sampler of sensation, jaded before his time, and the passionate and innocent love he awakens in the young Tatiana, was almost part of Russian folk culture. Even the language of the libretto would have been recognized, since so much of it is drawn directly from the 14-line stanzas of Pushkin.

title: Injunction for Small Shops: Agency, Market Thyself
description: MORE than a year after two of New York's more promising young agencies merged, the new shop they formed is proving that sometimes one plus one can equal three. But in an intensely competitive environment, in which one plus one needs to equal five or six, that ambitious goal is still tantalizingly elusive.

title: Wagner Gets an Emotional Lift to Title
description: Even though both teams were away from home and playing at Columbia's Wien Stadium in upper Manhattan yesterday, it was Susan Wagner, not Lincoln, that got the most inspiration from a glimpse of the landscape before the Public Schools Athletic League Class A championship football game.

title: Courier Perks Up in Time for Title
description: Two weeks ago, Jim Courier suggested that he might be too tired to play singles in the Davis Cup final this weekend against Switzerland.

title: Homicidal Litterbugs
description: To the Editor:

title: MISSION TO SOMALIA: Reporter's Notebook; Guns, Greed and Khat Define A Once-Graceful Somali City
description: In a lawless capital that has lost its banks, its national airline and its everyday comforts, hardheaded residents have learned to make do.

title: Watts Postpones Recital
description: The pianist Andre Watts, who has suffered a back injury, has postponed his Friday evening recital at Avery Fisher Hall to March 7 at 3 P.M. The original tickets will be honored. Information: (212) 721-6500.

title: Bridge
description: Would you care to play opponents who pass cards under the table, to insure that your play will fail? "No" is the wrong answer -- you should be willing to pay $49.95 for the privilege ($10 more after Christmas). The money should be sent to Fred Gitelman, 15 Lillian Street, Toronto, Canada M4S2H7.

title: 2 Top Officials Start Firms
description: Two vice chairmen at two large agencies have resigned to start their own businesses.

title: INSIDE
description: New Turn on Nixon Tapes

title: If Only Barry Bonds Were Too Expensive
description: IF only a snag in the Barry Bonds deal with the as yet unapproved new owners of the Giants had developed earlier.

title: Cab Hurts 2 Women at Bus Terminal Curb
description: Two New Jersey women were injured yesterday morning when a taxicab jumped the curb and hit them in front of the Port Authority bus terminal in midtown Manhattan, the police said.

title: Baseball's Giants Play Let's Not Make a Deal
description: Deal? What deal? Biggest contract ever? Not at the moment. Next week? Next month? Who knows? Not Barry Bonds, among everyone else.

title: Nancy Phillips, Thomas Dunne
description: Nancy Jean Phillips, the business manager of Life magazine in New York, was married yesterday to Thomas Aquinas Dunne, a commissioner at the New York State Workers' Compensation Board in Brooklyn. The Rev. Thomas F. Pike performed the ceremony at the Chapel of St. George's Episcopal Church on Stuyvesant Square in New York.

title: Review/Cabaret; The Theater's Songwriters In 'The Jule Styne Revue'
description: "Make Someone Happy! The Jule Styne Revue," the newest in a series of musical salutes to great theatrical songwriters at Rainbow and Stars, was to have had its official opening on Nov. 24. Then at the last minute, its best-known performer, Dolores Gray, left the cast, and the show's 35 songs were redistributed among its four principal singers. At the press opening on Tuesday evening, the turmoil could be felt in the tense, mechanical performances of Broadway and cabaret professionals who have all sounded more at ease in other settings.

title: 28 Suspects in Suffolk Drug Ring Arrested
description: A Long Island man who the police said bragged that for $5,000 he could make people disappear was arrested early this morning and identified as the leader of a major narcotics ring in western Suffolk County.

title: Diamandis Resurges in Cable Effort
description: In a long-expected comeback, Peter G. Diamandis, a dominant figure in the magazine industry until he was abruptly dismissed from Hachette Magazines in 1990, will resurface as a publisher of cable television guides.

title: Computer Agreement
description: Apple Computer Inc. and America Online Inc., a supplier of electronic information services based in Vienna, Va., have announced that Apple will manage and market services developed by America Online. The two companies also announced on Friday that they planned to work together to develop enhancements to America Online.

title: Great Bowl Experiment or Great Injustice?
description: Week by week throughout the season, the members of the college football bowl coalition searched for the next problem that could complicate their effort to reshape an increasingly bitter and clandestine selection process into one of order, understanding and trust.

title: REGULATORS AGREE ON REVAMPED PLAN FOR FAILED INSURER
description: The insurance regulators of New York and New Jersey agreed yesterday on how to resolve the largest insurance company failure in history, increasing the interest that will be paid on the savings of hundreds of thousands of customers of the failed Mutual Benefit Life Insurance Company. But most customers may still have to wait up to seven years before they have access to all their money.

title: Diverse Talents in a Rhodes New Yorker
description: Nnenna Jean Lynch is a senior at Villanova University, an eight-time All-America distance runner and a sometime model whose face has graced the pages of Vogue and Sports Illustrated, not to mention bus shelter billboards across New York City.

title: Review/Theater: Once Removed; Homesick for Cuba In a Tacky America
description: For the bourgeois Cuban-Americans in Eduardo Machado's plays, the old adage that you can't go home again is not a sentimental cliche but the overriding fact of life. Exiled to a vulgar country where Spam can pass for food, "Father Knows Best" for culture and Bermuda shorts for fashion, they dream of a return to a Havana that, more than three decades after Fidel Castro's revolution, still remains a mesmerizing 90 miles out of reach.

title: A Big Ranger Shakeup Followed by a Shutout
description: Roger Neilson was tired of waiting for his bench full of talent to play like the Stanely Cup contenders they are supposed to be. Neil Smith was sick of watching dismal defensive breakdowns and sloppy goaltending and forwards who wouldn't backcheck.

title: A Corporate Storm Blows In at American Express
description: Call it a coup or call it a nudge, now it's the American Express Company's directors who are looking for a new leader after some grew uneasy with James D. Robinson 3d, the chief executive for 15 years.

title: THE TRANSITION: The Inauguration; Inaugural Elbowing Aside Big Tractors and Games
description: To Washington politicians, the inaugural events will be the hottest tickets in town, but don't tell that to people who prefer to watch jump shots and tractor pulls.

title: Mogadishu Port Opens to Allow Some Food Deliveries
description: Food backed up at the port here began to roll today as a 400-ton shipment of United Nations wheat and sorghum reached the northern sector of the capital. Behind it came a second convoy with 800 tons.

title: Abroad at Home; What We Should Do In Bosnia
description: When Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney briefed the press on the Somalia operation, he was asked whether it was a precedent for U.S. intervention in Bosnia. No, he said, the situation there was "dramatically different" -- the history, the terrain, the armies involved.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: WHITE ELEPHANTS IN CONNECTICUT

title: Riverside South's Goal Is to Keep Park in Touch With River
description: Riverside South was motivated primarily by the chance to create a waterfront extension of Riverside Park that, in contrast to other parks in Manhattan, would allow intimate contact with the Hudson River.

title: New Questions on a Company's Past
description: In December 1989, the Comptronix Corporation's board dismissed Harvey L. Pegram, one of the company's founders, contending that he had traded stock on inside information, court records here show. But the fast-growing electronics manufacturer, currently at the center of a new board room scandal, did not publicly disclose the reason for the key executive's ouster or report the incident to stock market regulators.

title: Police Officer Is Charged With Bribery
description: A Port Authority police officer who was the target of a six-month "sting" operation by his force and the Queens District Attorney's office was arraigned yesterday on charges of taking a $300 bribe to escort an undercover agent posing as a cocaine dealer past drug-detection security systems at La Guardia Airport.

title: U.S. Cancels Tax on Wine
description: Carla A. Hills, the United States trade representative, announced at the last possible moment the formal cancellation of 200 percent import taxes on white wine from the European Community that had been scheduled to take effect on Saturday.

title: Rice Has Record Touchdown As 49ers Manhandle Dolphins
description: 49ers 27, Dolphins 3

title: CHRONICLE
description: MICHELE GRIGSBY, 20 years old, was supposed to marry BERNARD BARBER in Los Angeles on Dec. 26. But when Mr. Barber, a 25-year-old specialist in the Army 10th Mountain Division based at Fort Drum, N.Y., learned last week that he would soon be heading to Somalia, the couple hastily scheduled a Saturday afternoon ceremony.

title: 3 WOMEN ARE SAID TO BE CANDIDATES FOR CABINET POSTS
description: Concerned that his first Cabinet appointments might signal the wrong intentions for his Adminstration, President-elect Bill Clinton plans to expand this week's announcements to include posts that would be filled by female and minority appointees.

title: SWISS REJECT TIE TO WIDER EUROPE
description: Choosing the security of their traditional isolation and neutrality over the risks and opportunities offered by Europe, Swiss voters today vetoed a Government-backed plan for Switzerland to move toward economic integration with the European Community.

title: Gore Says Clinton Will Try to Halt Waste Incinerator
description: Vice President-elect Al Gore says the Clinton Administration will seek to halt operations at the nation's newest hazardous-waste incinerator until Congress investigates the plant's safety and how it got its state and Federal operating permits.

title: Byrd's Roommate Isn't Alone in His Joy
description: Jets defensive end Marvin Washington had been Dennis Byrd's roommate on the road. On Saturday night, Washington had a room to himself in downtown Buffalo, but there was no peace in the solitude.

title: Col. Alva Harvey, 91, Military Flight Pioneer
description: Col. Alva L. Harvey, a pioneer military aviator who survived 10 days in Alaska's wilderness after crashing on an around-the-world flight attempt in 1924, died Monday at Mount Vernon Hospital in Arlington, Va. He was 92 years old and lived in Arlington.

title: No Headline
description: "Dennis told me: 'Play hard on Sunday, Mark. Hang in there. Don't worry about me, I'll be all right."' -- MARK GUNN, who played left end in place of Dennis Byrd for the Jets yesterday. [ C7:1. ]

title: Sports of The Times: Pro Football; In Wind and Cold, Jets Bare Their Emotions
description: 'Oh, my God," exclaimed Bruce Coslet, the Jets' coach, smiling broadly and blowing on his hands in the bitter, windy cold at Rich Stadium yesterday. "Oh, my God; oh, my God!"

title: Lloyd Bentsen: Insider at Treasury
description: By choosing Senator Lloyd Bentsen to be his Treasury Secretary, President-elect Bill Clinton would gain instant clout in Congress for his legislative package. Mr. Bentsen, who has run the Finance Committee with an iron first, won't need any road maps to guide him through the corridors of Capitol Hill.

title: The Jets Defy All the Odds and Win One for Byrd
description: A powerful feeling swept over Jets cornerback James Hasty before his team stepped onto the frozen field today to play the Bills here at Rich Stadium.

title: Hindu Militants Destroy Mosque, Setting Off a New Crisis in India
description: A screaming mob of thousands of Hindu militants stormed a 16th-century mosque here today and demolished it with sledgehammers and their bare hands, plunging India into a political and religious crisis.

title: Patents; Substituting A Finger For a Mouse
description: FOR many people who buy personal computers, the biggest question is not horsepower but ease of use.

title: Classical Music in Review
description: Downtown Chamber and Opera Players Middle Collegiate Church East Village

title: Moscow Journal; Voices of the New Russia's Congress
description: The debates of Russia's Congress of Peoples' Deputies, the country's highest legislative body, can range from the vituperative to the petulant, from the cogent to the perverse. But among the deputies who have come from all over the vast Russian Federation, many are sensible and relatively businesslike, eager to influence the Government, not undermine it, and to represent the hopes and fears of their constituents.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-13 CONFLAGRATION IN INDIA

title: Dance in Review
description: 'The Nutcracker' New York City Ballet New York State Theater

title: Virginia Gets Title In Shutout
description: Coach Bruce Arena of Virginia didn't have to keep his promise of jumping into nearby Lake Norman if his team failed to score against the University of San Diego today in the collegiate soccer championship game.

title: Bond Mood Supports Clinton
description: The sharp rally in the bond market after the release of employment data on Friday seems to show a surprising comfort among market players with President-elect Bill Clinton, a Democrat who will govern with a Democratic-controlled Congress.

title: Dance in Review
description: Margaret Beals Loft Theater 228 West Broadway (between Franklin and North Moore Streets) TriBeCa

title: Wall St. on Bentsen: Will He Stir Pot?
description: The news that Senator Lloyd Bentsen of Texas is expected to be nominated as the next Secretary of the Treasury was generally well received on Wall Street. But many executives said they feared that the economic stew in a new Administration may have too many cooks for any one to be decisive.

title: Devils Surge Past Sabres
description: Devils 7, Sabres 3

title: No Sleighs For Santas Trudging Sidewalks
description: The night-sky sleigh riding, the last-minute list checking and the down-the-chimney ho-ho-hoing are the easy part. For some sidewalk Santas in Manhattan, December means long days collecting donations for the Volunteers of America, the nonprofit group that is New York State's largest provider of shelter services for single adults. The group provides a home away from the North Pole, a shelter on the Upper East Side.

title: Pressmen Ratify Contract With The Times
description: The pressmen's union approved a new contract with The New York Times yesterday, which the paper called an important step toward full operation of its $450 million printing plant in Edison, N.J.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt * Amoco Canada Petro Co., Calgary, Alberta, a unit of Amoco Corp., is offering $300 million of 7 1/4 percent guaranteed notes due 2002 at 99.646 to yield 7.3 percent through Goldman, Sachs. The noncallable notes are rated triple-A by both Moody's and S.& P. * Central Power & Light Corp., a Corpus Christi, Tex., unit of Central and South West Corp., is offering $115 million of noncallable first-mortgage bonds due 2002 at 99.89 to yield 7.515 percent and $25 million of 7 1/8 percent first-mortgage bonds due 1999 at 99.7 to yield 7.18 percent. Both issues are rated A-2 by Moody's and A by S.& P. and Duff & Phelps. Morgan Stanley leads the underwriters.

title: A Yugoslav Macedonia Threatens Greece; A Case for Recognition
description: To the Editor:

title: The Senate's Ethical House of Cards
description: Acting expeditiously, the Senate Ethics Committee has started a preliminary inquiry into allegations of sexual harassment lodged against Senator Bob Packwood, Republican of Oregon. But the committee still owes a better response on another unpleasant matter: the strange case of Senator Phil Gramm's vacation home.

title: Books of The Times; On Becoming a Writer and a Man
description: The Certificate By Isaac Bashevis Singer Translated by Leonard Wolf. 231 pages. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $22.

title: Joyner Makes All-Star Catch And Trots Home for Key Run
description: There were 4 minutes 22 seconds left and the Minnesota Vikings trailed the Philadelphia Eagles by 21-17. The Vikings had just scored a touchdown on a 70-yard, 14-play drive that required a little more than seven minutes. Their defense had forced an Eagles punt, and now the Vikings had the ball again at their 30, primed for another long march to swipe the lead and maybe the game.

title: Jane Levenstein, Paul Trager
description: Jane Mara Levenstein, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Levenstein of Woodmere, L.I., was married yesterday to Paul Trager, a son of Lawrence Trager of New York and the late Jacqueline Trager. Rabbi Ben Pernod performed the ceremony at Temple Israel in Lawrence, L.I.

title: On Sundays, Bergen Shoppers Rest
description: A SUNDAY at the shopping malls in Bergen County, N.J., is like a scene from a low-budget doomsday film. Mammoth concrete stores and acres of parking spaces are abandoned, as if nuclear winter has driven tens of thousands of die-hard bargain hunters underground, or at least to the relative comfort of the vast Willowbrook Mall in neighboring Passaic County.

title: Article Says Nixon Schemed To Tie Foe to Wallace Attack
description: Secret White House tapes show that in an effort to embarrass the Democrats President Richard M. Nixon tried to have George McGovern's Presidential campaign literature planted in the apartment of the man who shot George Wallace in 1972, according to an article in The New Yorker magazine.

title: Argentina Signs Debt Accord With Banks
description: In another important step toward resolving the Latin American debt crisis, Argentina and its creditor banks signed a final agreement today that will effectively reduce its commercial bank debt by 35 percent.

title: Advertisers Less Skittish About Explicit Programs
description: Fewer advertisers are pulling their commercials from television shows this season because of sexually oriented content, network executives say. And one reason appears to be that the more popular shows can easily replace any skittish advertiser with another willing to take the risk.

title: New Rules For Rating Insurers
description: Insurance regulators from all 50 states approved a new standard yesterday for measuring the financial strength of life and health insurance companies.

title: Yanks Are Winners In the Abbott Derby
description: The Yankees, who have emphatically said that quality starting pitching is their central off-season aim, hit their first major target tonight when they traded for California's Jim Abbott.

title: Venezuelans, Some of Them at Least, Go to Polls in Local Elections
description: Venezuelans, who saw an unpopular Government put down two attempted coups this year, went to the polls today to elect state and local officials.

title: A Yugoslav Macedonia Threatens Greece
description: To the Editor:

title: Dance in Review
description: Ruth Fuglistaller Bessie Schonberg Theater

title: Review/Theater; Woyzeck, Antihero, Cannot Outrun His Destiny
description: The title character in "Woyzeck" is, we are told, "running around like an open razor blade." The image, in common with the play itself, is as precise as it is terrifying. Woyzeck, a military barber and the most ordinary of common men, is overcome by dementia. He hears strange sounds, sees visions and is driven to a desperate act of murder. Along with "Danton's Death," the play certified Georg Buchner's reputation as the first modern playwright. Written in the 1830's and discovered as fragments after the author's death, the work foreshadowed explorations by Kafka, Brecht and Beckett. The modernism of Buchner is basic to JoAnne Akalaitis's compelling production at the Joseph Papp Public Theater.

title: Texas View of Its Senator Is Quite Rosy, Of Course
description: Not surprisingly, the news that President-elect Bill Clinton had settled on Senator Lloyd Bentsen as his Treasury Secretary was welcomed by the Texas business community.

title: Miller High Life To Y.& R. Chicago
description: The Miller Brewing Company unexpectedly disclosed Friday that it would move its Miller High Life account to Young & Rubicam Chicago from Leo Burnett U.S.A. in Chicago, effective early next year. Estimates are that High Life spending has been reduced to well under $10 million as the brand's sales continue to decline, compared with the estimated $110 million Miller Lite account that Burnett retains.

title: Florida Moves Against Insurer
description: Florida has ordered the Foremost Insurance Group, a unit of the Foremost Corporation of America, to resume selling new policies in 40 of the state's 62 counties.

title: Washington Pays Tribute To Performing Artists
description: They survived that fall, after all. There were Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid, a k a Paul Newman and Robert Redford, one paying tribute to the other as President Bush looked on this evening at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the scheduled release dates for major economic indicators this week. Monday None Tuesday None Wednesday None Thursday Producer Price Index . . . Nov. Weekly Jobless Claims Friday Consumer Price Index . . . Nov. Retail Sales . . . Nov.

title: Home Health Care Policies Need to Be Refined; Cost-Effective Choice
description: To the Editor:

title: Rape -- and Soldiers' Morale
description: All wars are alike in at least three particulars: death, destruction and rape.

title: Conde Nast? Rumor Quashed
description: The magazine business, if it does nothing else, loves a good rumor. People in the industry even start rumors that this penchant for rumors has at times led to leaks from within the industry that -- if you can believe this -- do not always turn out to be true.

title: Raiders Are Too Much for Chiefs
description: Raiders 28, Chiefs 7

title: Gibson Danes, Dean, 81, and Ilse Getz, Artist, 75
description: Gibson A. Danes, a former dean of the Yale School of Art and Architecture, and his wife, Ilse Getz, an artist, were found dead on Friday at their home in Litchfield, Conn., a Connecticut State Police official said yesterday. Mr. Danes was 81 years old, Ms. Getz 75.

title: Fighting in Sarajevo Suburbs Cuts Off Access and Power
description: Heavy shelling and infantry clashes spread across the western suburbs of Sarajevo today, shutting down the Bosnian capital's telephone, water and electricity systems and preventing United Nations workers from reaching hundreds of civilians still trapped by fighting in the suburb of Otes, local news reports said.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: SKIING Tomba Irked on Slopes

title: Byrd Receives Some Special Deliveries
description: It was too good to wait, too good to hold on to, too good not to bring straight to Dennis Byrd. So the Jets president, Steve Gutman, accompanied by Dr. James Nicholas, chairman of the Jets' medical department, quietly entered Lenox Hill Hospital Sunday night with the game ball from the Jets' big upset of the Bills in Buffalo.

title: Huge Ships Carry Supplies to the Marines
description: When the first wave of 1,800 marines stage their daytime landing into Mogadishu early this week, they will rely on food, water, fuel and equipment aboard this huge supply ship to sustain the initial operation.

title: Classical Music in Review
description: The Chung Trio Violinist, Cellist, Pianist Carnegie Hall

title: Go Faster on Russian Reform
description: As has been the case so often, Russia faces a vital decision. A battle is raging between the liberal Government and the "centrist" Civic Union alliance. But is compromise what Russia needs? Instinctively, many people react positively to terms like "compromise" and "moderate reform," but we must not be fooled. The essence of politics is to provide viable solutions to the problems facing society.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: WEEKEND Baseball American League

title: A Fresh Start for the Homeless
description: Smarting under contempt of court orders, New York City officials propose to shift a failing homeless policy from the Human Resources Administration to a new agency. The announcement invites skepticism: Why should a bureaucratic shuffle make any difference? This shuffle might; it's certainly worth a try.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings this week: MONDAY Berlitz Intl Capstead Mtg Corp Cincinnati Bell Inc Harnischfeger Inds Omnicom Group Rykoff-Sexton Inc United Indl Corp Unocal Corp TUESDAY Calgon Carbon Corp CRI Insd Mtg Assn Inc Cummins Engine Inc Fleetwood Entrps Inc Flour Corp Intl Flavors & Frags Lennar Corp Oklahoma Gas & Elec Co Pep Boys Manny Moe & Jack Premier Indl Corp St Joe Paper Toro Co TRI Contl Corp WEDNESDAY Carolina Pwr & Lt Deere & Co General Re Corp Green Mountain Pwr Heinz H J Co Nicor Inc South New England Telcom Standard Prods Co Supervalu Inc TRW Inc THURSDAY Atlantic Energy Inc NJ 1838 BD-Deb Trading Excelsior Income Shs Hancock Fabrics Inc Handelman Co MBIA Inc Millipore Corp National Fuel Gas Co NJ Penn Cent Corp Scor U S Corp Trinity Inds Inc Vestaur Secs Inc FRIDAY Illinois Tool Wks Superior Inds Intl

title: Fire Damages 15 Businesses in Queens Block
description: For a year, Frank Gil put off buying fire insurance for his pet store in Woodside, Queens. But yesterday, he regretted not spending the extra $2,000 a month after fire swept through his and 14 other small businesses, destroying eight.

title: CHRONICLE
description: MORTON L. JANKLOW has his name on a literary agency, Janklow & Nesbit Associates, and a law firm, Janklow Newborn & Ashley, so where, one wonders, can it be found next?

title: Crown Hts. Drives Contest For Mayor
description: The scalding racial tensions of Crown Heights have unfolded against the backdrop of next year's New York City mayoral race, and while none of the three announced candidates would put it this way, all are trying to turn the undercurrents of anger and recrimination to their political advantage.

title: What the U.S. Isn't Besides 'Christian'
description: To the Editor:

title: Top-Level Changes At Riney & Partners
description: Hal Riney & Partners will make top-level personnel changes, effective Jan. 1, aimed at helping develop its next cadre of leaders.

title: Food Is Delivered to Somalis
description: Trucks carrying U.N. wheat and sorghum left the port in Mogadishu for feeding centers, impeded by only minor looting. Page A12.

title: Dance in Review
description: Jane Goldberg Cooper Union East Village

title: Market Place; A New Outlook On Oil and Gas
description: ANALYSTS say that a new market psychology, a result of weak oil and gas prices in recent months, may be setting the stage for large-scale sales of oil and gas properties from major international oil companies to large independent producers in the United States.

title: U.S. Warns Somali Gunmen Against Efforts to Block Aid
description: Administration officials warned today that United States troops would try to disarm Somali gunmen who interfered with food deliveries.

title: A Few in Congress Advising Caution, or Vote, on Somalia
description: In the chorus of Congressional support for military intervention in Somalia, a few dissident voices are urging caution and, in some cases, suggesting that the mission be formally put to a vote under the War Powers Act.

title: Economic Growth Seen
description: Economic growth in the world's seven leading industrial economies will accelerate to 2.8 percent in 1994, from 2.2 percent next year and 1.3 percent in 1992, the London Business School said in its latest International Economic Outlook. Growth last year was five-tenths of a percent. The school's Center for Economic Forecasting said the recovery in the Group of Seven nations is "slow by comparison with previous recoveries from recession." The forecasters see growth of 2.7 percent in the United States next year.

title: Anna Pascual, David M. Felig
description: Anna Marie Pascual, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ernesto Pascual of Quezon City, the Philippines, was married yesterday to Dr. David Marshall Felig, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Philip Felig of New York. Rabbi Haskel Lookstein performed the ceremony at the New York Palace Hotel in Manhattan.

title: Rev. James C. Finlay, 70, Dies; A Former President of Fordham
description: The Rev. James C. Finlay, a Jesuit priest who was president of Fordham University from 1972 until his retirement in 1984, died on Saturday in Murray-Weigel Hall, an infirmary for retired Jesuits on the university's Rose Hill campus in the Bronx. He was 70 years old.

title: Fighting Police Department Corruption Amid Distrust
description: Lieut. Philip M. Druss has hunted down so many crooked colleagues in the New York City Police Department that he's earned the nickname "Destruction," and he says he has never doubted his mission for a minute.

title: A Religious Zeal Turns Into Abuse
description: This morning's sun, a dollop of deep orange, rose over processions of young men, their heads swathed in saffron headbands, their necks wrapped in saffron scarves, marching, some in lockstep, toward this sacred city. Dawn brought with it, as well, the ceaseless call and response: "Jai Sri Ram, Jai Sri Ram!" -- "Hail Lord Ram, Hail Lord Ram!"

title: Clint Eastwood, Back on the Side Of the Law, Protecting a President
description: The hotel ballroom in downtown Los Angeles explodes with applause as hundreds of couples in fancy outfits welcome the arrival of a fictional President of the United States. The reporters at the scene (who seem uncharacteristically neat and well-dressed) and the television crews start to move in. Watching the audience with darting eyes are a handful of men and women with receivers in their ears and transmitters on their lapels.

title: Help for Neediest: A Job on Crutches
description: Barbara Johnson endured a life of pain and emptiness for two decades, shuttling in and out of hospitals so surgeons could mend bones that were crushed when she jumped from a third-story window to escape a fire. She was usually confined to bed during those years, a prisoner of her own body.

title: 300,000 IN MUNICH PROTEST VIOLENCE
description: More than 300,000 Germans marched peacefully through Munich today in one of the country's largest demonstrations against intolerance, anti-Semitism and rightist violence.

title: THE TRANSITION: The President's Church; Pastors Want Clinton in Their Flocks
description: In Washington these days, overtures for a place in the next Presidential Administration are coming not only from potential Cabinet members and White House advisers, but also from churches.

title: Review/Cabaret; Connecting the Strands: Woman of Many Voices
description: Melba Moore has as many different singing voices as she has had phases in her show business career. And in "Songs My Mother Taught Me," her one-woman show that plays at the Ballroom through Dec. 20, those voices often sound like different personalities housed in the same body.

title: Equity Issues This Week
description: The following equity offerings are expected this week:

title: Signal on Toxic Waste
description: In its first environmental policy decision, the Clinton Administration will seek to halt operations at the nation's newest hazardous-waste incinerator until Congress investigates the plant's safety and the way it got its operating permits, Vice President-elect Al Gore says.

title: Review/Television; Peddling Sugar and Spice and Everything Hyped
description: Although "Buy Me That 3! A Kid's Guide to Food Advertising" delivers a bah-humbug message, the half-hour of anticommercials about junk food is anything but Scroogelike. As the awkward title indicates, this is the third special from Consumer Reports and HBO that attempts, wishfully, to protect youngsters from the flood of television advertising that crests during December and drowns any inhibitions that still exist about laying out good money for dubious products. As one of the likable children who pop up now and then to describe the effects of the commercials confesses, "You think you absolutely need it."

title: Classical Music in Review
description: Soldier String Quartet New York String Trio Merkin Concert Hall

title: Use of Undercover Officers Sets New York Unit Apart
description: Many police forces across the country have internal affairs units, but unlike New York City's, almost all must split their time between both corruption and brutality complaints. In New York City, allegations of brutality are referred to the Civilian Complaint Review Board.

title: Review/Mime; Conjuring Up Worlds Out of Silence
description: Marcel Marceau remains a master of silence. The French mime, who first toured America during the 1955-56 season, appeared on Saturday night at Lehman Center for the Performing Arts at Lehman College in the Bronx and was as gently comic and technically spectacular as ever.

title: Who's Stirring the Pot?
description: Many Wall Street executives fear the new Administration's economic stew may have too many cooks. Page D1.

title: Duke's Consistency Dominates in an Early Showdown
description: Is Duke capable of winning a third consecutive national title this season? Is Michigan capable of replacing the Blue Devils as champion?

title: Cord Pullers With No Emergency; Vandals (or Pickpockets) Posing Challenge to Transit Police
description: It is a crime invariably committed amid a crowd, but the transit police are frankly baffled.

title: Home Health Care Policies Need to Be Refined
description: To the Editor:

title: Broncos Still Can't Pass Muster
description: Cowboys 31, Broncos 27

title: Thud! Economic Report Lands on Baseball's Desk
description: A long-awaited study committee report on baseball's economics recommends that players be eligible for free agency after three years instead of six, a move that would eliminate salary arbitration. The committee also recommends that clubs increase the amount of revenue they would share among themselves in order to protect financially weaker teams and that clubs and players enter into a partnership for the future financial benefit of the industry.

title: Bridge
description: If you are looking for a holiday gift for a bridge player, here are some possibilities. All prices include shipping.

title: DSP Technology Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: Surprising Victory, Yes, but Another Week of Injuries
description: Almost 24 hours after their storybook victory over the Buffalo Bills, the Jets returned today to the harsh reality of their immediate future: three more games in 1992 with a roster that has increasingly been decimated by injuries.

title: Ukraine's Nukes-for-Aid Bid Is Justified
description: To the Editor:

title: Job for Hobert Is Cited
description: The Pacific-10 Conference is investigating whether University of Washington athletic boosters improperly provided quarterback BILLY JOE HOBERT with a job in high school and financial benefits after he joined the Huskies, The Seattle Times has reported.

title: Emil Haury, 88, Anthropologist Who Studied American Southwest
description: Emil W. Haury, an archeologist and anthropologist who was influential in the study of the prehistory of the American Southwest, died Saturday at his home in Tucson, Ariz. He was 88 years old.

title: Disability Law Applies To the Candidates Too
description: To the Editor:

title: A Promotion To President At Monsanto
description: The Monsanto Company said yesterday that Robert B. Shapiro, the head of its agricultural products group, would move up to president and chief operating officer on Jan. 1.

title: Probert Free to Travel
description: BOB PROBERT of the Detroit Red Wings was cleared yesterday by the Immigration and Naturalization Service to travel between the United States and his native Canada. The ruling means that Probert will be able to live in Canada and still play hockey in the United States for the Red Wings, said JAMES MONTGOMERY, the director of the Detroit district office.

title: Studios Get a Reprieve In Battle Over Reruns
description: A Federal appeals court in Chicago gave Hollywood movie studios a reprieve yesterday in their battle to retain regulations that prevent television networks from owning the lucrative rerun rights to shows they broadcast.

title: COMPANY NEWS: A $30 Million Carrot; Whirlpool and Frigidaire In Refrigerator Contest
description: A coalition of utilities that is dangling a $30 million carrot before refrigerator makers has selected Whirlpool and Frigidaire as finalists to build an ozone-friendly, super-efficient model.

title: Islanders Romp as Mullen Scores Twice
description: Islanders 6, Lightning 1

title: Agency Search By Bausch & Lomb
description: Bausch & Lomb 's personal products division in Rochester said yesterday that it had placed Clear Choice, a new nonalcoholic mouthwash, in review. Billings for the new account were estimated at $10 million to $15 million.

title: Bonds Must Play Ball With Lawyers
description: More than 48 hours after Barry Bonds and the San Francisco Giants thought they had completed a record-shattering $43.75 million deal, their future together remained in the hands of lawyers today.

title: GTE Southwest Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said that the 1991 results included the impacts of an after-tax charge related to a rate case proceeding in Texas and a one-time reserve for restructuring costs associated with the merger of GTE Corporation and Contel Corporation.Excluding the impact of the rate case and merger reserve, the third quarter increase from 1991 to 1992 was $ 19.8 million and the 9-month increase from 1991 to 1992 was $ 33.8 million.The company is a subsidiary of GTE Corporation.

title: Supreme Court Roundup; Iran-Contra Appeal Refused by Court
description: Turning down an appeal from the independent prosecutor in the Iran-contra case, the Supreme Court today let stand the appeals court decision that threw out the criminal conviction of John M. Poindexter, the highest-ranking Reagan Administration official to be found guilty in the affair.

title: Problem Gambling Masks Severe Depression; Myth of the Victim
description: To the Editor:

title: Open Call Issued By LoJack
description: The LoJack Corporation in Dedham, Mass., an auto security company, said yesterday that it had placed in review its consolidated account, with billings estimated at $3 million. The media portion is currently divided among three agencies and the creative portion is handled in-house.

title: Neediest Aids Babies At Risk
description: They are babies few people want, sickly and fragile infants often abandoned by parents who cannot bear the emotional or financial burden of raising them. Some are born of mothers whose drug use left the children suffering from cerebral palsy, Down syndrome or diabetes.

title: Twisted Insults
description: To the Editor:

title: Jack Carlson, 59, Budget Specialist And Ex-U.S. Aide
description: Jack Carlson, an economist, budget specialist and leading economic spokesman for American business interests, died yesterday in Suburban Hospital in Potomac, Md. He was 59 years old and lived in Potomac.

title: T.W.A. Pact On Pensions Is Reached
description: Carl C. Icahn virtually wrote the final chapter in an era in aviation history and to his involvement with financially troubled Trans World Airlines yesterday by reaching an agreement with the Government to support the airline's pension funds.

title: Chess
description: When you have accepted your opponent's surprise sacrifice and run into more trouble than you expected, one of the difficult decisions facing you will be how much you must concede. Because, unless your enemy is following a will-o'-the-wisp, you usually cannot hope to keep everything -- material and position.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Seems there's some turbulence in the world of weather watchers. Tomorrow a group of meteorologists plans to demonstrate outside the studios of WNYW, Channel 5, at 205 West 67th Street to protest the reassignment of the station's forecaster NICK GREGORY from weeknight duty on "The 10 O'Clock News" to the weekend evening broadcasts.

title: Building Imaginary Railroads Under Real Trees
description: TOY trains are not found under the Christmas tree as frequently as they once were, but some railroad buffs may be delighted this year to find a train set in their computers.

title: Classical Music in Review
description: Chamber Music Society Alice Tully Hall

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt * AMR Corp. is offering $200 million of 7 3/4 percent unsecured notes due Dec. 1, 1997, at 99.954 to yield 7.76 percent through Morgan Stanley. The noncallable notes are rated Baa-2 by Moody's Investors Service Inc., BBB by the Standard & Poor's Corp. and BBB- by Duff & Phelps. * Norwest Financial Inc., Des Moines, a unit of Norwest Corp., is offering $100 million of 6.875 percent senior notes due Dec. 15, 1999, at 99.317 to yield 7 percent, through Merrill Lynch. The company is also offering $100 million of 4 7/8 percent senior notes due Dec. 15, 1994, at 99.764 to yield 5 percent. The noncallable notes are rated Aa-3 by Moody's, A+ by S.& P. and AA by Duff & Phelps.

title: Chiron's President Quits
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 7

title: Pause in Trade Talks Urged
description: Senator Max S. Baucus, the Montana Democrat who heads the Senate Finance Committee's trade panel, called today for the Bush Administration to stop taking part in world trade talks until it had consulted extensively with President-elect Bill Clinton and his transition team.

title: Motion to Dismiss All Charges In Sex Assault Case Is Rejected
description: The judge in the Glen Ridge sex assault trial today rejected a defense motion for dismissal of all charges against four former football teammates accused of assaulting a mildly retarded woman in March 1989.

title: AT LEAST 200 KILLED IN INDIA AS MUSLIM-HINDU RIOTS RAGE
description: India's towns and cities were swept by rioting between Muslims and Hindus on Monday, leaving more than 200 people dead and hundreds more injured a day after militant Hindus destroyed a 16th-century mosque in the northern town of Ayodhya.

title: Citizen Watch Selects D.M.B.& B.
description: The Citizen Watch Company of America, based in Lyndhurst, N.J., said yesterday that it had selected D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles in New York to handle its American and Canadian account, previously handled by Young & Rubicam New York for four years. Billings were estimated at $10 million to $12 million.

title: 976 Points of Light -- and Counting
description: Midway in his acceptance speech to the Republican National Convention in 1988, George Bush waxed inspirational about all the organizations that perform good works in America -- "a brilliant diversity, spread like stars, like a thousand points of light, in a broad and peaceful sky."

title: Pioneer in Radiation Sees Risk Even in Small Doses
