description: The first independent study of the health records of 35,000 workers at a Government bomb plant in Washington State presents a new, more sinister picture of the risks of small doses of radiation.

title: Review/Rock; Joe Satriani as Guitar Hero
description: As a musical form, heavy metal's attractions are pretty obvious: a show is a good way for the audience to rebel for a few hours, to create a community of like-minded people, acting out the role of antisocial hero. If the music is anything, it's mythic.

title: Bayou Steel reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK CITY CONSOLIDATION PLAN FOR CUNY

title: Germany Agrees on Law to Curb Refugees and Seekers of Asylum
description: Moving to defuse anxiety over the influx of immigrants and the rash of rightist attacks on foreigners in Germany, leaders of the country's main political parties have agreed on a new law to make it harder for asylum-seekers and refugees to enter Germany.

title: Classical Music in Review
description: "Die Schone Magelone" William Sharp, baritone Accompaniment by William Blier, pianist Readings by Beth Dixon New York Festival of Song Greenwich House Music School

title: Everest & Jennings International reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a restructuring reserve of $ 2.5 million, offset by a tax credit of $ 986,442 in both the quarter and 9 months.c-Included a gain of $ 791,000 in the quarter and $ 1,189,000 in the 9 months from discontinued operations.

title: TV Shopping Network Is Acquired
description: The Liberty Media Corporation said yesterday that it would take control of the Home Shopping Network of St. Petersburg, Fla., the company that distributes a shopping cable service to 40 million homes.

title: Terror of Deep Faces Harsher Predator
description: THE shark, that mythic terror of the deep, has been top predator of the seas for nearly 400 million years. But sharks themselves are now being wiped out en masse by the human appetite for shark flesh, and their disappearance could disrupt the ecology of the world's oceans.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-19 DEADLY RIOTS SWEEP INDIA India was swept by bloody rioting between Muslims and Hindus a day after Hindus destroyed a mosque in the town of Ayodhya. More than 200 people were killed and hundreds more injured. A1 MILITANCY CONFOUNDS NEW DELHI News analysis: The razing of a Muslim mosque exposed the depths of Hindu fundamentalism and the weakness of India's Government. It also challenges the Constitution, which requires that India preserve its secular character. A16

title: Q&A
description: The Sandman

title: General Host Corp.  reports earnings for 12wks to Nov 1
description: b-Included a gain of $ 1.1 million, or 6 cents a share, from the elimination of income tax reserves no longer required in both the quarter and 9 months.c-Net incomed-After income from discontinued operations of $ 5,940,000, or 33 cents a share, in both the quarter and 9 months.Year-ago 9 months' results included Calloway's Nursery Inc., an 80 percent-owned unit sold in July 1991, which had earnings of $ 1,757,000, or 10 cents a share, on sales of $ 18,888,000.Year-ago 9 months' results included an after-tax gain from the sale of Calloway's of $ 7,800,000, or 43 cents a share.

title: Jury in Ex-C.I.A. Official's Case Reports Agreement and Deadlock
description: The jurors in the Iran-contra retrial of Clair E. George reported today that they had reached a unanimous verdict on some charges but were deadlocked on others. The trial judge then ordered them to continue deliberations in the hope of reaching a verdict on all seven counts.

title: Justice Obstructed in the Poindexter Case
description: By refusing to hear a Government appeal in the case of John Poindexter, the Supreme Court has failed to stand up for important criminal laws that were gutted by a lower court ruling.

title: Museum Chief Quits
description: THE American Museum of Natural History announced yesterday that Dr. George D. Langdon Jr., would step down as president next June and that a search had begun for his replacement.

title: Critic's Notebook; Re Somalia: How Much Did TV Shape Policy?
description: The emplacement in recent days of network news big guns alerted the nation that something serious was afoot in Somalia. Dan Rather, Tom Brokaw, Ted Koppel and the scores of lesser correspondents have become certifiers of disaster. If they are on the spot, watch out!

title: BULGARIA MUST FIX RUN-DOWN A-PLANT
description: Bulgarian officials are struggling to change the reputation of the nuclear power plant here, which some Western engineers regard as the most dangerous in the world.

title: Seeds of a Newspaper Struggle
description: The root of Mortimer B. Zuckerman's current problems in trying to take over The Daily News go back to a 114-day newspaper strike that began 30 years ago this morning.

title: Maddux and Howe Head Yankees' List
description: As the courting of Greg Maddux continued in New York today, the Yankees moved closer to completing a contract agreement with free-agent reliever Steve Howe. The club was also exploring its chances for reaquiring third baseman Charlie Hayes.

title: Honors for Scholars Who Are Athletes
description: Thirteen college football players sat down for lunch yesterday at the "21" Club in Manhattan. One of the 13 was Jim Hansen, an offensive tackle from Colorado who has just been awarded a Rhodes Scholarship. Another was Rod Tranum, a wide receiver from Massachusetts Institute of Technology with a perfect grade average.

title: Behind the Facade, a Building Divided
description: For 108 years, the four-story Montgomery Block has been an ample presence on East 86th Street, as well as an architectural symbol of an almost vanished Yorkville, with the Kleine Konditorei restaurant on the ground floor, delicate ornamentation and a powerful cornice above.

title: Brister Comes Back For Steelers' Stretch
description: Entering the season, many Steeler pundits thought that Bubby Brister was the better choice over Neil O'Donnell to lead Pittsburgh at quarterback.

title: A Comptronix Options Account Is Frozen
description: Prudential Securities agreed yesterday to freeze the account of a customer who made almost $350,000 on stock options of the Comptronix Corporation the day the company announced the suspension of its top management for falsifying the company's books.

title: Another 2d-Half Struggle For Pirates
description: P. J. Carlesimo is now .500 in his career as a college coach and Seton Hall is 5-1 on the season, but how the two got there tonight wasn't expected.

title: Observer; The Firing Culture
description: After years of feeding on strawberries, cream and honey, or tons of money if you'd rather not be poetic about it, corporate executives are suddenly getting fired. Mr. Stempel of General Motors was the most spectacular instance of their new vulnerability. Now Mr. Robinson of American Express is said to be getting the boot.

title: Sexual Behavior Levels Compared in Studies In Britain and France
description: The higher you are on Britain's social ladder, the more likely you are to have had more than one sexual partner in the past year. And in France young people are more likely to use condoms than their elders.

title: Shocked, Stunned, Adjusting To the Deal
description: There was an initial and tremendous shock for Jim Abbott, and today, 24 hours later, the newest member of the Yankees was still attempting to sort out his feelings.

title: Organist Is Sentenced for Burglaries at 2 Churches
description: Oather James Blocker, a reclusive 47-year-old church organist who confessed to stealing religious articles from more than 500 churches and synagogues in the Northeast, was sentenced today to between 4 and 14 years in prison for burglaries in two churches on Long Island.

title: U.S. Lures Dominicans, Too, to the Cruel Sea
description: After failing to persuade relatives in New York to take her in, losing money on a counterfeit visa that was never delivered, and prostituting herself in the hope of finding an American willing to marry her long enough that she could emigrate legally, Josefina Archibald was down to what for many Dominicans represents the final hope.

title: Sports of The Times; The 'Push' Baseball Needs
description: THE healthy part of the heated controversy concerning Marge Schott, said Steve Greenberg, the deputy commissioner of baseball, is that "without that push things don't get done."

title: Now, From Somalia, 3 Star Newscasters
description: Two television networks, CBS and NBC, have sent anchormen to Somalia; a third, ABC, has sent the host of its late-night news program.

title: James P. Layton, Pioneer in Rocketry And Jets, Dies at 73
description: James Preston Layton, an aeronautics engineer who spent more than four decades working on rocket technologies, died Thursday at O'Connor Hospital in San Jose, Calif. He was 73 years old and lived in Santa Clara, Calif., where he had moved from Princeton, N.J., in May.

title: The Sigh of History
description: Felicity is a village in Trinidad on the edge of the Caroni plain, the wide central plain that still grows sugar and to which indentured cane cutters were brought after emancipation, so the small population of Felicity is East Indian, and on the afternoon that I visited it, all the faces along its road were Indian, which was a moving, beautiful thing, because this Saturday afternoon "Ramleela," the epic dramatization of the Hindu epic the "Ramayana," was going to be performed, and the actors from the village were assembling on a field strung with different-colored flags, like a new gas station, and beautiful Indian boys in red and black were aiming arrows haphazardly into the afternoon light. Low blue mountains on the horizon, bright grass, clouds that would gather color before the light went. Felicity! What a gentle Anglo-Saxon name for an epical memory.

title: Kenneth I. Nissman Executive, 46
description: Kenneth I. Nissman, a men's clothing executive in New York, died on Saturday at Beth Israel Hospital in Manhattan. He was 46 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Thompson Marsh, 89, Denver Law Professor
description: Thompson G. Marsh, a professor of law at the University of Denver for 60 years, died on Saturday at his home in Denver. He was 89 years old.

title: The Cotton Bowl Puts NBC And Irish in Awkward Spot
description: Presume, for a moment, that NBC exerts a smidgen of influence over the teams chosen for its bowl games. NBC pays dearly to be a player on New Year's Day: $2.7 million for the Cotton Bowl and $6 million for the Orange Bowl.

title: Student Charged in Slaying Over $100 Debt
description: A 17-year-old Queens College student has been arrested and charged with stabbing a high school student to death over a $100 debt, the police said yesterday.

title: VOLKSWAGEN GIVES EASTERN GERMANS $60.6 MILLION JOB
description: Volkswagen A.G. said yesterday that it had awarded a $60.6 million contract to Umformtechnik Erfurt G.m.b.H. for the delivery and installation of presses at a joint venture auto plant in Changchun, China. It is the largest contract the German auto maker has given to an industrial company in eastern Germany. Umformtechnik will be responsible for carrying out the whole contract at FAW-Volkswagen in Changchun. The presses are expected to be operational in the second half of 1994.

title: Bradlees Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 7
description: b-Included a $ 1.1 million LIFO inventory charge in both the quarter and 9 months.The company said its results up to the acquisition of Bradlees business on July 10 are stated pro forma.

title: D.C. to Keep Redskins In New Cook Stadium
description: The Washington Redskins' owner, JACK KENT COOKE, reached agreement yesterday with the District of Columbia Government to build a new stadium adjacent to Robert F. Kennedy Stadium, the team's existing home.

title: Youth, 16, Stabbed In School, Police Say
description: A 14-year-old junior high school student stabbed a 16-year-old five times in the lobby of a Brooklyn school yesterday morning after the older youth tried to slash him with a razor, the police said.

title: 3 Israeli Soldiers Are Slain, Uprising's Biggest Such Toll
description: Three Israeli soldiers were shot to death today while on patrol in the Gaza Strip, apparently by Islamic militants who drove up alongside their jeep and raked it with automatic gunfire.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: CENTURY 21 REAL ESTATE CORP., Irvine, Calif., will reorganize its operations to create seven decentralized divisions. FLEET FINANCIAL GROUP, Providence, R.I., a bank holding company, sold about $525 million of mostly nonperforming real estate assets.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Companies

title: Richard J. Hughes, Governor and Judge, Dies at 83
description: Richard Joseph Hughes, who reshaped New Jersey's education system as Governor and then offered a new direction for the national right-to-die debate after becoming the state's Chief Justice, died yesterday. He was 83.

title: Texfi Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
description: b-Net loss and the quarter included $ 982,000 in expenses from discontinuance of fleece apparel operations; the year included provision of $ 8,603,000 for discontinuance of fleece apparel operations.Latest year's share earnings included after-tax gain of 71 cents a share from sale of two yarn plants.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Press Notes column on the Media Business page yesterday about speculation over a possible new editor in chief for The Daily News referred incorrectly to the current editor of The New York Post. He is Lou Colasuonno.

title: Two Ad-Spending Forecasts Debate Amount of Growth
description: BY the time 1992 is over, advertising spending in the United States will have risen 4.5 percent over 1991, a leading industry researcher said yesterday.

title: Battling Nuclear Waste in Michigan
description: Here on the shore of Lake Michigan, in the yards of the Palisades nuclear reactor, sits a row of 100-ton concrete-and-steel storage casks designed to hold nuclear waste for decades and keep it safe from earthquakes, tornados and even plane crashes.

title: Corrections
description: A chart on Sunday with sketches of candidates for top economic positions in President-elect Bill Clinton's Administration misstated the age of Lawrence H. Summers, an economist. He is 38, not 48.

title: Executive Changes
description: ATLANTIC MUTUAL COS., Madison, N.J., an insurance holding company, appointed Klaus G. Dorfi senior executive vice president. BANK OF BOSTON CORP., Boston, named William J. Shea chief financial officer and treasurer, succeeding Peter J. Manning, who will concentrate his efforts as executive vice president of acquisitions and mergers.

title: Florio Presents Proposal To Restructure State Debt
description: The Florio administration unveiled today a $1.6 billion bond refinancing and new debt plan that would capitalize on lower interest rates to pump more than $900 million into New Jersey's state coffers over the next three years, but at the expense of higher bond payments later.

title: Big Test for Small Force: Logistics of Somali Aid
description: Though the American force heading to Somalia is far smaller than the one that fought in the Persian Gulf, the logistics of military intervention in the Horn of Africa are in many ways far more difficult, senior military officials said today.

title: No Headline
description: To paraphrase from Dorothy and 'The Wizard of Oz': 'Toto, you ain't in Riyadh any more,' -- MICHAEL P. KALLERES, a U.S. Navy vice admiral. [ A18:1. ]

title: Problem Gambling Masks Severe Depression; Family and Friends
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Granddaddy' Cactus's Death Throes
description: THE oldest, biggest and most thickly limbed saguaro in the United States, a giant cactus known here with crisp Western affection as "Granddaddy," is dying of what scientists say is the succulent equivalent of extreme old age.

title: White House Wraps Christmas in Laughs
description: Summoned to the East Room of the White House this morning for formal Christmas greetings, President Bush's staff heard the Marine Corps Band grind out "Hail to the Chief" and waited anxiously for the appearance of their leader.

title: Justices Decline to Hear Mississippi Abortion Case
description: Providing further evidence that it has said all it plans to say for now on the subject of abortion, the Supreme Court today refused to hear a challenge to a Mississippi abortion law that requires women to wait 24 hours for their abortions after first receiving counseling intended to persuade them to change their minds.

title: Peril to the Indian State: A Defiant Hindu Fervor
description: When fanatical Hindus attacked a mosque in the northern town of Ayodhya on Sunday, they did more than reduce the 16th-century edifice to rubble. They also exposed the depths of Hindu fundamentalism and the weakness of India's Government, posing a fundamental challenge to the nation's Constitution.

title: Jays Re-sign Carter and Swipe Molitor
description: Showing they can perform in the front office as well as they did on the field this year, the World Series champion Toronto Blue Jays executed an electrifying double play tonight, re-signing free-agent Joe Carter and snatching Paul Molitor from the Milwaukee Brewers.

title: Classical Music in Review
description: Artur Pizarro Pianist 92d Street Y

title: A Door Opening Wide for the Poor
description: The City University of New York began in 1847 as a free academy for young men of poor and immigrant families who normally did not have access to other universities and colleges in the city.

title: Mideast Peace Talks Reconvene In Washington but Quickly Stall
description: Israeli and Arab negotiators opened another round of the Middle East peace talks here today, but like last month's sessions, the discussions were clouded by violence in the Middle East and political sparring here.

title: Muslims Oust Some Serbian Forces From Sarajevo Siege, Bosnians Say
description: Muslim forces struck back today at the better-armed Serbs besieging Sarajevo, driving some Serbian forces from two city suburbs and surrounding others on a hilltop west of the Bosnian capital, a Bosnian Army statement said.

title: Cablevision Systems Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago revenue for both the quarter and 9 months are adjusted net revenues.

title: New York Copes as Best It Can With Homeless-Family Crisis
description: To the Editor:

title: Harold Kreiger, 86, Lawyer for 60 Years
description: Harold Kreiger, a lawyer in Jersey City for 60 years, died on Saturday at his home in Manhattan. He was 86.

title: Grace Chief, 79, Is Retiring After 47 Years
description: J. Peter Grace, one of American industry's bluntest and most colorful executives, will retire as chief executive of W. R. Grace & Company at the end of the year, the company announced yesterday.

title: Edison Brothers Stores reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
CHRONICLE
description: When her only child was killed in 1986 at the age of 24 in a helicopter accident over Mali, Countess ALBINA DU BOISROUVRAY sold the movie studio she operated in Paris and her real estate, art and jewelry, all of it worth some $100 million, and set about financing projects she said "would continue my son's loving presence."

title: Article 367592 -- No Title
description: Playing holiday host in one of the most glamorous settings in all New York, City Council President Andrew J. Stein raised another $1 million last night for his planned mayoral campaign next year, increasing the total he has taken in so far to nearly $4 million for what promises to be a bitter and costly race.

title: Oregon Now Wonders Who Is Real Packwood
description: After a quarter-century, Oregonians are hearing about a Bob Packwood who is far different from the man they have sent to the Senate for four terms.

title: Ex-Priest Goes on Trial In Child-Molesting Case
description: Testimony began today in the trial of a former Roman Catholic priest who has been accused of sexually assaulting a minor here and of molesting more than 100 children in three states.

title: Lois Braun; Leader of Jewish Groups, 73
description: Lois Braun, a member of the board of the New York Federation of Reform Synagogues, died yesterday at her home in Larchmont, N.Y. She was 73 years old.

title: Somalia Famine No Different: Children Are the First to Die
description: A year ago, almost to the day, 5-year-old Mohammed Abukar lay on his back in a decrepit hospital yard, his right leg newly amputated after a shell blast in the war that killed his family.

title: Classical Music in Review
description: Rosemary Glyde Violist Kosciuszko Foundation 15 East 65th Street

title: On My Mind; The Lucky Americans
description: In Bosnia and Serbia, it all seemed clear that the killing and the terror came out of old, ugly Balkan history and hatred. Except for the human duty to try to save Bosnian Muslim lives, none of it could possibly have any meaning or connection to America.

title: EUROPEANS FACING BATTLE OF BUDGET
description: Instead of providing an occasion to repair tattered dreams of regional unity, a summit meeting of European Community leaders this week may well result in a new rift over an issue that deeply concerns all 12 member countries: who pays for and who benefits from the community budget.

title: Mets' Choice Is Mike Who?
description: The front-office executive for the Mets made his way through the packed ballroom to the microphone and announced: "The Mets select, from the Columbus roster, right-handed pitcher Mike Draper."

title: Clinton Warns That Predictions of Economic Upturn Might Be Premature
description: As he prepared to announce his economic team later this week, President-elect Bill Clinton emerged from days of virtual seclusion today to warn that predictions of an economic upturn might be premature.

title: Leslie Cheek Jr., 84; Led Virginia Museum
description: Leslie Cheek Jr., an architect and a former director of the Virginia Museum of Fine Arts, died on Sunday at his home in Richmond. He was 84 years old.

title: Christmas PC Books
description: FOR the computer fan on your gift list, there is a tough-minded, plain-spoken new guide to selecting and buying hardware and software. Some samples of its approach:

title: Accounts
description: * Lucille Roberts Health Clubs, New York, to Follis/DeVito/Verdi, New York, to handle its account, previously at Baron & Zaretsky Advertising, New York. Follis/DeVito/Verdi was also named by Futai Inc., Edison, N.J., to handle the umbrella manufacturer's American account. Combined billings were estimated at $3 million.

title: Review/Music; Searching for Challenges
description: It is by no means certain that the Kronos Quartet meant its listeners to find a unifying current in the program it played on Saturday evening at Alice Tully Hall. Ambiguity, after all, is a spice that this new-music ensemble values, and it is not unlike the Kronos to offer a program that seems stylistically random at first, but acquires cohesiveness upon reflection.

title: MOZAMBIQUE FORCE PROPOSED AT U.N.
description: Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali asked United Nations members today to send a peacekeeping force of up to 10,000 troops and civilians to prepare free elections in Mozambique.

title: Japanese Regulators Seize Files in Stock-Pricing Inquiry
description: Japan's new stock market regulatory agency, created in July to rebuild the credibility of the scandal-tainted stock market, took its first enforcement action today, seizing records of parties said to have been involved in manipulating the shares of an affiliate of the Unisys Corporation.

title: Will Rangers Need A Revolving Door?
description: Brian Leetch can sense the worry. Personally, he has no reason for concern. He is the top defenseman on this Rangers team, and one of the best defensemen -- if not the best -- in the league. His job is untouchable.

title: Forest City Enterprises Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary loss of $ 1,000 in the quarter and an extraordinary gain of $ 80,000, or 1 cent a share, in the 9 months, both from disposition of properties and other provisions.c-Included an extraordinary loss of $ 47,000 and an extraordinary gain of $ 220,000, or 2 cents a share, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, both from on disposition of properties and other provisions.Year-ago results are restated to reflect the adoption of Accounting Standard for Income Taxes, FAS 109.Revenue represented consolidated sales and operating revenues.

title: Review/Television; Keeping Child With AIDS From Becoming a Pariah
description: With docudramas, sometimes the subject itself compels attention. "Blood Brothers: The Joey DiPaolo Story," tonight at 7:30 on HBO, addresses AIDS. Then sometimes an uncommonly strong performance or two can do wonders for a mediocre script. CBS's "Killer Among Friends," tonight at 9, can claim the indispensable contributions of Patty Duke and a young actress named Margaret Welsh.

title: CUNY Head Seeking Overhaul Of 19 Autonomous Campuses
description: The Chancellor of the City University of New York is pressing for an overhaul of the 19-campus system that would eliminate or consolidate some academic programs so that the university could improve or expand others.

title: More Mathematicians
description: American educational institutions continue to award doctorates in mathematics at a near record rate, but more than half the recipients are foreigners, and employment prospects for the new mathematicians are distinctly uncertain.

title: H.I.V. Clue Supports Early Use Of Condom
description: A TEAM of Harvard researchers has uncovered new evidence that H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS, is present in sperm-free fluid that precedes ejaculation. They said the findings showed the need for men to put condoms on before any genital contact occurs.

title: Back to Basics, Little Richard Is Happy at Last
description: Those who invent genres both define them and are stuck with them. Little Richard, hair like an apartment building, sexually ambiguous, wildly extroverted and very funny, is coming to New York for three nights at Tramps (45 West 21st Street, Chelsea), starting this evening. Little Richard (Richard Penniman), for those who don't remember, helped invent rock-and-roll. He made a strain of American extremism, all Saturday-night hysteria, a regular part of international mass culture.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Dec. 1 about the initial stock trading of Caremark International Inc. misstated the financial performance of a competitor, T2 Medical Inc. Growth in T2's earnings has exceeded Wall Street's projections.

title: Classical Music in Review
description: Garah Landes Pianist Merkin Concert Hall

title: Crack Addict Found Able To Face Trial
description: Larry Hogue, the crack-addicted, homeless veteran who residents of West 96th Street say has terrorized them for seven years, was found competent by a judge in Manhattan yesterday to stand trial on a charge of criminal mischief for scraping a car with a knife.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of the Feast of the Immaculate Conception, alternate-side parking rules are suspended in New York City today. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Former Shearson Executive Will Join Cantor Fitzgerald
description: Only six months after joining Steinhardt Partners, Peter J. DaPuzzo, the former co-head of international equities at Shearson Lehman Brothers, is moving on again.

title: Stop & Shop Companies reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 7
description: b-Included loss from discontinued operations of $ 208,497,000, which included charge of $ 194,539,000 from disposal of discontinued operations. The period also included a loss of $ 14.9 million from early retirement of debt.c-Net loss and included a loss of $ 6,789,000 from discontinued operations.d-Net income and included loss from discontinued operations of $ 28,237,000.

title: AMERICAN EXPRESS SHARES SURGE TO A 52-WEEK HIGH
description: After the disclosure by the American Express Company over the weekend that James D. Robinson 3d was resigning as chief executive, the company's stock rallied to a 52-week high yesterday. The stock, which was the most active on the New York Stock Exchange, gained $1.375, to $24.75. More than 8.8 million shares changed hands.

title: Corrections
description: The Art in Review column in Weekend on Friday misidentified an artist whose sculpture, of glass jars filled with paint, is part of a group exhibition at Muranushi Lederman Productions in SoHo. He is James Elaine, not James Siena.

title: NOVELL IN DEAL TO USE ELECTRONIC DISTRIBUTION SYSTEM
description: Novell Inc., a computer-network software company, is licensing a system from Electronic Book Technologies that will permit Novell to convert its printed manuals into electronic documents for a variety of computers. Systems that permit the electronic storage and distribution of documents are becoming a significant business. Such systems are designed to reduce printing cost and increase the efficiency and ease of distributing printed material. Electronic Book Technologies, based in Providence, R.I., offers a system called Dynatext. Novell is based in Provo, Utah.

title: College-Aid Plan in Trenton
description: Republicans offered a plan to guarantee financial aid for New Jersey high school graduates attending college in the state. Page B1.

title: CUSTOMERS PROTEST NEW PLAN FOR MUTUAL BENEFIT LIFE
description: A newly revised rehabilitation plan for the Mutual Benefit Life Insurance Company drew fire from a group of more than 500,000 people who have retirement savings invested with the seized Newark-based insurer. The Association of Mutual Benefit Life Insurance Contract Holders, said yesterday that the plan worked out by New Jersey and New York regulators favored contracts backed by state guarantee funds.

title: Review/Music; With 3 Maestros and a Bit of the Circus, the Philharmonic Turns 150
description: The party the New York Philharmonic gave itself last night for its 150th birthday began with an elephant from the Big Apple Circus performing in Lincoln Center's Fountain Plaza and ended with the audience at Avery Fisher Hall offering a standing ovation and singing "Happy Birthday" just before it was showered with confetti shot from cannons. The hall's balconies were draped with white cloth, with gold fringes that rustled lightly; in front of the orchestra was a thick border of lilies and orchids. A buffet preceded the event, and champagne followed it. The entire concert (except for the prefatory show on the plaza) was also broadcast nationwide on PBS. For the nation's oldest orchestra, it was a wholehearted celebration, seemingly not the sort of occasion for solemn assessment.

title: Electric Car Is Reviewed
description: The General Motors Corporation said today that it was reviewing its electric-car development program to determine whether to push ahead with commercial production during the next few years.

title: By Design; New Bra Image
description: The brassiere is more than just an essential undergarment. It also has fashion status. As such it is both "in" and "out" right now.

title: F.C.C. Chief Plans to Resign Before Clinton Inauguration
description: Alfred C. Sikes, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, said today that he would resign on Jan. 19, the day before Bill Clinton is sworn in as President.

title: Staunch Conservative Wins G.O.P. Post in House
description: In a victory by conservatives over the moderate wing of the party, House Republicans today selected as their third-ranking leader Representative Dick Armey, a blunt-talking Texan with a penchant for bashing liberal Democrats and promoting supply-side economics.

title: Patterns
description: Stores' holiday lures

title: Ram vs. Allah: 2 Different Cures for India's Ills
description: Hari Dass Sharma and Mohammed Alim may be united in their hopes for a peaceful solution to the crisis provoked on Sunday when a mob of militant Hindus demolished a mosque in northern India. But the solutions offered today by these men of different faiths were completely at odds.

title: Editors' Note
description: A front-page article on Nov. 30 described signs that the American economy may be recovering. It quoted business people and economists who were beginning to see signs of improvement.

title: Review/Pop; Musical Traditions Shared Across an Ocean
description: An ocean separates Cuba from West Africa geographically, but not musically. Los Munequitos de Matanzas, the 40-year-old Cuban group that performed at Davis Hall at City College on Saturday night, plays songs that share rhythms, dance steps and sometimes even the language with Yoruba and Abacua traditions from West Africa. The 13-member group concludes its first United States tour this week in New York City. It has also released an album, "Rumba Caliente 88/77" (Qbadisc).

title: Credit Markets; Reports of Clinton Nominees Ease Fears of Bond Traders
description: The bond market rallied yesterday as it absorbed the names mentioned over the weekend for important economic appointments in the Clinton Administration. The price of the 30-year bond was up almost half a point, and prices of Treasury notes rose across the board.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: S.& L. Gets Debt Accord
description: The Glendale Federal Bank, the nation's fifth-largest savings and loan, said today that it had reached an accord with leading bondholders that would allow the troubled bank to raise $100 million to help meet new Federal capital requirements.

title: Hint That Demjanjuk Once Was Treblinka Guard
description: Despite denials and contradictory testimony in Israel's case against John Demjanjuk for Nazi war crimes, a new clue that supports allegations that he served at the Treblinka death camp has been found in a 10-year-old letter.

title: A Rising Cost Of Modernity: Depression
description: IF the 20th century ushered in the Age of Anxiety, its exit is witnessing the dawn of the Age of Melancholy. The first international study of major depression reveals a steady rise in the disorder worldwide.

title: Prosecutors Find No Evidence of Criminality in Shooting by a Transit Officer
description: Prosecutors have questioned most of the witnesses in last month's shooting of a plainclothes transit police officer in Brooklyn by fellow officers who said they mistook him for a mugger, and have found no major conflicts in their accounts and no evidence of criminal negligence, investigators said yesterday.

title: Town Sees Small Gain In Big Fight
description: THE last decade has been hard on this historic village, once the center of commerce and industry on Long Island. As shoppers abandoned Hempstead's downtown and retailers moved out, crime, especially drug dealing, increased.

title: Books of The Times; Henri Troyat Adds His Life of Flaubert to the List
description: Flaubert By Henri Troyat Illustrated. Translated by Joan Pinkham. 374 pages. Viking. $25.

title: Analog Devices reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net lossc-Included a $ 7 million restructuring charge in both the quarter and year.

title: Petrovic, Feeling Slighted, May Not Re-sign With Nets
description: Just as the Nets are getting excited about their six-game winning streak, they were presented with a new problem today: the growing possibility that guard Drazen Petrovic will leave the team after this season.

title: 'Cheers' to End Production in March
description: After 11 seasons, "Cheers," the longest-running comedy series on television, is ending production, Paramount Pictures' Network Television Division announced tonight.

title: The Push and Pull Over Taxes
description: The 12 years of Republican reign seem, looking back, like a constant political war over taxes, a war that will almost certainly continue next year after Bill Clinton becomes President.

title: T.W.A. Said to Have Picked Backer Spielvogel for Ads
description: Trans World Airlines has chosen Backer Spielvogel Bates Inc. to handle its European and American advertising, an account valued as high as $60 million, according to people close to the deal.

title: Planetary 'Slingshot' Aims Craft At a Rendezvous With Jupiter
description: PASSING by Earth for the last time, the Galileo spacecraft is at last ready to sally forth toward its ultimate destination in 1995, the giant planet Jupiter. And despite the craft's continuing antenna trouble, officials of the $1.4 billion mission have high hopes that by clever improvisation, Galileo should still achieve nearly all of its scientific objectives.

title: Campbell Slides Toward End of Bench
description: Pat Riley has spoken.

title: Problem Gambling Masks Severe Depression
description: To the Editor:

title: Xtra Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Bush and Yeltsin in Talks to Gain A-Arms Accord
description: President Bush and President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia have begun personal negotiations by telephone and letter in the last week in an effort to resolve differences that threaten a major nuclear arms reduction agreement that the two announced in June, the White House said today.

title: 40 Killed in Fighting As Somalia Awaits Americans' Arrival
description: As Somalia prepared for the arrival of American troops, heavy fighting continued today in Baidoa, a rural town that has been the center of the famine relief effort.

title: Struggle Worthy Of Texas Looms Over Senate Seat
description: Lloyd Bentsen's appointment as Treasury Secretary is not even official yet, but that has not stood in the way of a feverish outbreak of political jockeying and speculation over who might replace him in what would be only the third change of Senators in Texas since 1961.

title: Harnischfeger Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Beijing Journal; China Is Fighting for Its Soul: Its Looted Antiques
description: It was not drugs the peasant was selling under the cover of darkness, but something just as restricted, and he was very careful as he displayed his wares on a quiet street before dawn.

title: Check Technology Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: From Gulf to Somalia: General Marches On
description: Into the turmoil of Somalia enters Lieut. Gen. Robert B. Johnston, a meticulous square-jawed believer in order and discipline.

title: Pulling Down India's Temple
description: The central task confronting India since its birth 45 years ago has been maintaining a secular state in a multi-religious society -- in short, respecting the rights of India's vastly outnumbered Muslim minority. Yet secularism has long been resisted by Hindu militants, and still is. On Sunday, a hateful Hindu mob destroyed a mosque in Ayodhya, igniting bloodstained riots.

title: Northwest Cancels Jet Order
description: Northwest Airlines, trying to retrench and survive, said yesterday that it had canceled a $3.5 billion order of jets from Airbus Industrie as part of an $8 billion package of cost savings and new financing.

title: Review/Music; A Gust of Woodwinds
description: Ebony and bamboo spoke louder than melody and harmony in Douglas Ewart's music on Wednesday night at Merkin Concert Hall. Mr. Ewart, a woodwinds player and instrument maker, led five other woodwind players and a bassist, Malachi Favors Maghostut of the Art Ensemble of Chicago, in pieces that brought together families of instruments to savor the shared timbres.

title: Bombardier Puts Engineer In Charge of de Havilland
description: Bombardier Inc., the Canadian transportation conglomerate, today named an engineer to head de Havilland Inc., the ailing Ontario-based maker of commuter jets it acquired from the Boeing Company a year ago.

title: Washington Memo; New and Old Questions For Senate Ethics Panel
description: The Senate is stepping warily into the unfamiliar role of deciding how seriously to take sexual-harassment charges, while also confronting familiar arguments over how well Congress polices itself.

title: The Odds of a Shark Attack
description: THE chance of being killed by a shark in United States waters, scientists say, is far less than that of dying from a bee sting, a snake bite or even lightning .

title: Classical Music in Review
description: Cosmopolitan Chamber Orchestra Ethical Culture Society

title: Grand Jury Hears Evidence in Crown Hts. Case
description: Brooklyn prosecutors began presenting evidence to a grand jury yesterday about the events surrounding the beating of a homeless black man in Crown Heights, in a case that is likely to turn on the credibility of the victim, who has a long arrest record.

title: HACKER INDICTED ON SPY CHARGES
description: In the first use of Federal espionage charges against a computer hacker, a Federal Grand Jury here has indicted a well-known Silicon Valley programmer on charges of stealing a classified military document, the Federal authorities said today.

title: Business and Health; AIDS Solution: Long Way to Go
description: GOVERNMENT agencies approved plans last week to expand testing of several unproven AIDS vaccines, but Government and company researchers are still far from a pharmaceutical solution to the AIDS problem.

title: Robot Named Dante To Explore Inferno Of Antarctic Volcano
description: AN eight-legged robot named Dante is to descend into the smoldering crater of an Antarctic volcano soon in an attempt to reach a lava lake that long has remained out of the reach of human explorers.

title: Microscopic Diamonds Are Not Stuff of Stars
description: NEW research on microscopic diamonds found in areas of Montana and New Mexico has shown they were not formed in the stars, as once believed, but rather on Earth when a large meteorite hit the Yucatan Peninsula in Mexico 70 million years ago.

title: CHANCELLOR FINDS SUPPORT ERODING ON SCHOOL BOARD
description: w York City Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez backed away from the most scornful statements in his new autobiography yesterday as members of the Board of Education who will vote on renewing his contract began voicing deepening disenchantment.

title: Market Place; Hot Concept, Big Following, But Stock Takes Hefty Fall
description: Eagle Hardware and Garden has a hot retailing concept and a big Wall Street following. But it seems to have some trouble counting.

title: Wider Human Testing Ahead for Drastic Gene Therapy
description: THE first patient to be treated for a fatal cholesterol disease by receiving new genes in her liver tissue is faring so well that the scientist who devised the gene therapy technique wants to try it on others.

title: The World's Only Other Cop
description: President-elect Clinton talks boldly about expanding the U.N.'s role in global crisis management. But judging from this year's grim experiences in Bosnia, Cambodia and Somalia, the U.N. has already taken on more responsibilities than it can manage.

title: Review/Fashion; Costume Change At the Met
description: The newest permanent floating costume exhibition opens Thursday at the Metropolitan Museum of Art in the redesigned galleries of the Costume Institute.

description: The Giants as we know them apparently have ceased to exist.

description: By the slimmest of majorities, 15-13, the major league baseball owners voted today to reopen negotiations on the collective bargaining agreement with the players, instantly creating speculation that the absence of a new agreement could jeopardize the beginning of the 1993 season.

description: Fearful that recent reports suggesting an economic rebound could blunt public pressure on Congress, President-elect Bill Clinton cautioned that hard times were probably not over and that, in any case, painful long-term changes were still required.

description: Dennis Byrd will begin an extensive physical therapy program later this week when he is moved to the Department of Rehabilitation Medicine at Mount Sinai Medical Center in Manhattan, the Jets said yesterday.

title:
Real Estate;
Recovering From Storm In Florida
description: HURRICANE ANDREW plowed head-on into the headquarters of Burger King here in August, pummeling the company's twin six-story glass office towers on Biscayne Bay with flying tree limbs and 16-foot waves. Within hours, executives of the fast-food chain began the task of assessing the damage to the South Dade County building and regrouping.

title: A Computer Industry Popularity Poll
description: Technology professionals surveyed by Computerworld have listed the International Business Machines Corporation, the Microsoft Corporation and the Hewlett-Packard Company, in that order, as the companies in the industry they most admire.

description: When she talks of the looming threat of losing her home and her lifelong belongings, her voice is filled with fear and uncertainty.

title: Wine Talk
description: ABOUT a dozen wine enthusiasts gathered in a room in a nondescript Manhattan office building last Saturday morning to sample some Burgundies. Well, not just some Burgundies. There were 40 wines, all good, many exceptional, and all from the excellent 1990 vintage.

title: A High-Tech Baton for Living-Room Maestros
description: Conducting his ensemble in a recent performance at Arizona State University, Arthur Weisberg paid attention to the strange-looking instrument alongside the flute, clarinet, violin, cello and piano. The success of the music, an experimental piece called "Virtual Encounters," depended on a computerized apparatus that looked like an oversized pizza box played by a man with what seemed to be a pair of timpani mallets.

title: 3 Historic Districts Are Created in TriBeCa
description: Three TriBeCa historic districts were created yesterday by unanimous votes of the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission, which is seeking to preserve the 19th-century commercial and mercantile flavor that remains in that part of lower Manhattan.

title: Someone's In the Kitchen With . . . a Book
description: JADED as I am, I sometimes wonder whether the world really needs another cookbook. Yet, cooking titles continue to pour off publishers' lists, especially now at gift-giving season, promising fulfillment from old ways or rejuvenation from new ones, cautioning healthful restraint or endorsing self-indulgence, introducing us to new products, new techniques, new ethnic cuisines.

title: Talks Off to a New Start, but Finish Seems Far Away
description: Paul Tagliabue, the National Football League commissioner, said the players' lawyers have been given a new proposal that he feels could pave the way for a collective bargaining agreement.

title: London Journal; With Its Bombs, Will the I.R.A. Steal Christmas?
description: Joanna Grace said her friends and relatives in suburban Essex thought she was daft when she asked them to join her on a Christmas shopping trip into central London on Monday.

title: Company Promises a No-Effort TV-Rating Device
description: Seeking again to compete with A. C. Nielsen in the national ratings business, the Arbitron Company announced yesterday that it was developing a high-technology device for keeping track of television and radio audiences.

title: WHEELING-PITTSBURGH PLANS A REVAMPING
description: The Wheeling-Pittsburgh Corporation said yesterday that it would offer severance to 280 salaried employees as part of a restructuring plan that reflects low steel prices and one-time production problems during the fourth quarter.

title: A Working-Class Outlet for Fine Foods
description: FIFTY cases of mesclun, 28 kilos of fresh basil and half a dozen boxes of chanterelles were stacked in the entrance of the new Gourmet Garage in SoHo on a recent afternoon, waiting for a truck to deliver them to a midtown Manhattan hotel. Next to a huge commercial scale, and across from an espresso machine, a display of yellow vine-ripened tomatoes, fragrant Galia melons and tender baby white carrots enticed curious pedestrians to enter and explore.

title: Ready for a Battle, Troops Storm Beach But Find No Enemy
description: Just as dawn peered into a new morning here, a CH-46 Sea Knight helicopter roared over a sandy bluff and touched down near the airport just long enough for 15 members of Lieut. Hezekiah Barge's Marine infantry platoon to barrel out the ramp of the twin-rotor chopper.

title: Somali Clans Planning Last Grab for Advantage
description: The competing clans that have ravaged this country spent the day today plotting attacks to wring the last bit of military advantage over their foes before the arrival of American forces, which are expected to put a damper on much of the fighting.

title: Saudi Joins Bidding for Circle K
description: In a continuing struggle for control of the bankrupt Circle K Corporation, the Commonwealth Oil Company said yesterday that it intended to file an amended reorganization plan for Circle K that includes $360 million of equity capital supplied by a Saudi prince.

title: CNL Realty Investors Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a gain on sale of land and building of $ 11,432 in both the quarter and 9 months.c-Included a gain on sale of land and building of $ 7,225 in both the quarter and 9 months.

title: Amid a Lost Season, Giants Find Brown
description: Rookie quarterback Dave Brown may start before the season ends, Coach Ray Handley said today, and the Giants began making preparations for that likelihood by increasing Brown's workload in practice.

title: Daily Challenge to Be True to One's Dream
description: When Donato Mancini moved into his cold-water loft in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, the idea was to stay a year, then move on to more comfortable quarters. That was in March 1980. "Almost 13 years without a hot shower," Mr. Mancini said with a rueful smile, gesturing out over his studio.

title: Go-Video Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Pacific Physician Services reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Included a gain of $ 464,000 from the sale of government securities.The company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: Andrew J. Kappell; Professor, 41
description: Andrew J. Kappell, an associate professor of English at Hofstra University, died on Sunday at St. Vincent's Hospital in Manhattan. He was 41 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Letterman Accepts CBS Offer to Oppose Leno on Late TV
description: David Letterman has accepted an offer from CBS to leave NBC for his own late-night talk and entertainment show opposite Jay Leno at 11:30 P.M. on weeknights.

title: U.S. Orders Relief Workers Indoors for 48 Hours
description: Relief workers have been advised by the United States military to stay indoors for at least the first 48 hours after the arrival of American troops in the Somali capital, but many relief officials are concerned that the interruption will last longer, gravely affecting hundreds of thousands of hungry people.

title: Changes Due In Hospitals, Panel Says
description: A panel commissioned by Mayor David N. Dinkins last year to conduct a top-to-bottom investigation of New York City's sprawling public hospital system identifies weaknesses that have already been pointed out and endorses changes that have already been made.

title: Fernandez Looking to Albany to Shore Up His Authority
description: Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez looked to the State Legislature in Albany yesterday to rescue his shaky authority as he braced himself for a possible rebuff by the members of his own Board of Education.

title: Martech USA Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Eagle Hardware & Garden Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
description: b-Included a charge of $ 2,398,000 due to inventory shrinkage.Eagle Hardware & Garden said that the latest third quarter results have been adjusted for a 3-for-2 stock split paid Nov. 17 of this year, and reflect the fact that there are 42 percent more shares outstanding in the current period.The company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: Corrections
description: A headline yesterday about the shooting of a plainclothes transit police officer in Brooklyn by fellow officers referred incompletely to the prosecutors' investigation. No conclusions have been drawn, because the Brooklyn District Attorney's office has yet to interview two witnesses, including the officer who was shot.

description: The results are in Canadian dollars.

title: TCG International reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

title: Metro-North Train Hits Car, Injuring 2
description: Two New Canaan, Conn., women were seriously injured last night when their station wagon was struck by a one-car Metro-North train on the New Canaan branch of the New Haven line.

title: Report Cards: Some Say There Must Be a Better Way
description: Emily Donahue aced her eighth-grade report card last month, so she took a friend to see "Home Alone 2" and her dad gladly paid for the tickets. Douglas and Keith Murray's parents bought them a new game for their computer because they had made the honor role. Nicholas Urban's parents told him that good grades are their own reward, but he got his Aunt Kathy in New Jersey to give him a dollar for every "A" he brings home.

title: Smile, and Say Hearing
description: The manager of heavyweight champion RIDDICK BOWE and a member of his camp will face a state disciplinary hearing in Las Vegas, Nev., for allegedly assaulting a photographer after Bowe dethroned EVANDER HOLYFIELD.

title: Don't Lower Flag on Rokeby
description: For the last three months, the auctioneer's gavel has chipped away pieces of the empire, but there are still 26 race horses and two ponies in the picture-postcard barn of the Rokeby Farm in South Carolina these days, and MacKenzie Miller says, "That's what's left."

title: Italian Town Hitches Its Wagon to a Pale Star: White Truffles
description: IN these remote reaches of Tuscany, what on earth -- or at least under it -- is there to talk about all through winter's long gloaming? The answer is simple: truffles.

title: HOLE BEING DRILLED TO REACH MINERS
description: Rescue workers began drilling today through 900 feet of limestone in an effort to provide air for eight coal miners missing underground since an explosion Monday morning.

title: Transmedia Network Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: All share earnings and shares outstanding have been adjusted to reflect the 3-for-2 stock split in the form of a 50 percent stock dividend paid on April 17, 1992, to shareholders of record, April 7, 1992.The company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: Police Admit Error In Arrest of Lindros
description: ERIC LINDROS was mistakenly handcuffed after surrendering to the police on a minor assault charge last week, Durham Regional Police said yesterday in Toronto.

title: Atlanta Alters Golf Strategy for '96 Games
description: Organizers for the 1996 Olympic Games in Atlanta, who have encountered resistance to their plan to incorporate a golf competition at the Augusta National Club as a medal sport, will try a softer approach next week when they appear at a meeting of the International Olympic Committee in Lausanne, Switzerland.

title: Less Meat Please, With The Chinese
description: LOOKING back at recipes in the first Chinese cookbook I ever owned, I discovered a startling fact: The amount of meat in the dishes was quite small, relative to the other ingredients. That is the way Chinese traditionally eat. But when Chinese cooking crossed the Pacific the proportions changed: The meat became the central note, the vegetables secondary.

title: Indicted Congressman Withstands Challenge
description: Sweeping aside pleas from freshmen to raise the ethical standards of Congress, House Republicans today dropped a proposal that would have removed their ranking member from the powerful Appropriations Committee because of his indictment on racketeering charges.

title: Books of The Times; Of Black Troops and a White Colonel
description: Blue-Eyed Child of Fortune The Civil War Letters of Col. Robert Gould Shaw Illustrated. Edited by Russell Duncan. 421 pages. University of Georgia Press. $29.95. Free at Last A Documentary History of Slavery, Freedom and the Civil War Illustrated. Edited by Ira Berlin, Barbara J. Fields, Steven F. Miller, Joseph P. Reidy and Leslie S. Rowland. 571 pages. The New Press. $27.50.

title: Clinton Returns to Capitol, And Bouquets All Around
description: The opening line got a laugh. The closing line drew volunteers. And in between, when President-elect Bill Clinton offered familiar nostrums like "my door will always be open," House Democrats believed him as if the prescriptions were miracle drugs.

title: Israel Closes Gaza in a Search for Soldiers' Killers
description: Israel closed off the Gaza Strip today and confined hundreds of thousands of Palestinians there to their homes as the army searched for the killers of three soldiers who were gunned down on Monday while on patrol.

Also included are the results of two other department stores closed in the ordinary course of business and included in this year's results only through May.

title: New Teller Machines That Listen
description: Someday, perhaps as soon as early 1994, account holders may be talking back to their automated teller machine -- and it won't be in disgust. A.T.&T. and its computer unit, NCR, the world's largest maker of computerized bank tellers, are developing a new machine that identifies clients by voice, rather than by passwords punched into a keyboard.

title: Court Grants Most Fees In Macy Case
description: A Federal bankruptcy judge yesterday awarded most of the $5.27 million in fees and $436,175 in expenses requested by lawyers, accountants and financial professionals employed by R. H. Macy & Company and its creditors during the three months that ended on Oct. 31.

title: Campus Journal; Fireworks and Dazzle At Panel Talk on Beauty
description: For a Princeton student, the scene must have been jarring.

description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $ 93,000, or 2 cents a share, which reflected extinguishment of long-term debt.c-Net incomeThe company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: Review/Music; The Philharmonic's Birthday Party
description: The party the New York Philharmonic gave itself on Monday night for its 150th birthday began with an elephant from the Big Apple Circus performing in the Fountain Plaza at Lincoln Center and ended with the audience at Avery Fisher Hall offering a standing ovation and singing "Happy Birthday" just before it was showered with confetti shot from cannons. The hall's balconies were draped with white cloth, with gold fringes that rustled lightly; in front of the orchestra was a thick border of lilies and orchids. A buffet preceded the event, and Champagne followed it. The entire concert (except for the prefatory show on the plaza) was also broadcast nationwide on PBS. For the nation's oldest orchestra, it was a wholehearted celebration, seemingly not the sort of occasion for solemn assessment.

title: IN THE KITCHEN WITH David Bouley; Putting Heart Into Affairs of the Palate
description: IF you're the type who's afraid of commitment, you'd better think twice about eating at Bouley. First, there's the wait for reservations at the TriBeCa restaurant, which on the weekends can run three months. Then, there's the popular tasting menu, a nine-course innovation that costs $80 a person and can take up to four hours to consume. But perhaps most important is that, unknown to you, the diner, you have not come to Bouley just to eat. You have unwittingly entered into an impassioned affair with a possessive lover.

title: Perry L. Ruston, 86, Conde Nast Chairman
description: Perry Lounsbery Ruston, a former president and chairman of Conde Nast Publications Inc., died on Sunday at his winter home in Delray Beach, Fla. He was 86 years old.

title: Fleet Call Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

title: Carjacking: New Name for Old Crime
description: When Lieut. Allen Tharling joined the Houston Police Department's robbery division 16 years ago, young thugs were stealing cars and pickup trucks at gunpoint.

title: Mother Gets Neediest Cases' Help For Her Daughter's Rare Disease
description: They came alone, mother and daughter, unprepared for a foreign land where the winters are so harsh and the food, though plentiful, is too expensive. But they thought doctors in America could cure the daughter's rare illness, so they stayed.

title: Bill Filante, 63, Dies; California Lawmaker
description: Bill Filante, a California Assemblyman for 14 years who often parted ways with his Republican colleagues, died of brain cancer at his home in Terra Linda, Calif., today. He was 63.

title: Public & Private; Whose Best Interests?
description: This is the sad story of a little girl, the four adults who want her, and the legal system that calls her by three initials and treats her as something even less significant than that.

title: Bridge
description: At national championships, which the American Contract Bridge League insists on calling, long-windedly, North American Championships, Canadians, outnumbered, tend to lose out to players from south of the 49th parallel. But they had a glorious moment in the final of the 1964 Spingold Teams, when a Toronto team (Eric Murray, Sam Kehela, Bruce Elliott and Shorty Sheardown) defeated another Canadian team (Marvin Altman, Bruce Gowdy, Fred Hoffer, Ray Jotcham). The Toronto foursome retained the title a year later.

title: People
description: * Stephani Cook was named to the new post of senior vice president and director of strategic planning and research at Bloom FCA, New York. She was previously an independent consultant. * Jeanne Chinard was named senior vice president of advertising at Estee Lauder U.S.A., New York, succeeding June Leaman, now senior vice president for creative services at Estee Lauder Inc. Ms. Chinard was previously an executive vice president and senior creative director at Young & Rubicam New York.

title: Bonds and the Giants Come to an Agreement
description: The two most controversial and economically significant issues that have developed at baseball's winter meetings -- the Barry Bonds contract and the owners' reopening of the collective bargaining agreement -- have turned on the uncompleted sale of the San Francisco Giants.

description: Stanley C. Myers, founder of the Greater Miami Jewish Federation and a prominent civic figure in South Florida for more than 60 years, died Friday at Mount Sinai Hospital in Miami Beach. He was 87 years old and lived in Miami Beach.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the cancellation of a $3.5 billion jet order by Northwest Airlines misidentified the maker of $2.7 billion worth of additional jets for which orders were being delayed. It is the Boeing Company.

title: A McDonald's Burger of the Garden Variety
description: No, Detroit is not about to diversify into the bicycle business, A.T.& T. is not planning to sell postage stamps and Nike has no plans to sell saddle shoes. It is true, though, that the McDonald's Corporation has begun test-marketing, yes, a vegetarian burger.

title: Counselor Says Woman in Abuse Case Sought Affection to Gain Friends
description: A high school guidance counselor testified today that the mildly retarded woman in the Glen Ridge sex assault case was desperate for friends and thought that it was a gesture of friendship when boys fondled her.

title: A Tale of Literary Mystery Wins The First Russian Booker Prize
description: In the old days, Russian writers writing in Russia won prizes named after Lenin and Stalin, and their works were judged on their value to the proletariat. Tonight, a 55-year-old Russian writer won the first Russian Booker Novel Prize, an annual award made famous in Britain and now transplanted to a Moscow literary scene unaccustomed to the rituals of the glitterati.

title: Market Place; Hitching Toys To Hit Movies
description: IT'S white-knuckle season for the nation's toy manufacturers. After months of planning and preparation, the Christmas shopping season is well under way, and there is little the toy makers can do now but sit back and hope their long-formulated strategies pay off.

title: This Season, Bottom Line Is on Top
description: Although sale signs that promise 25 percent off are as ubiquitous as ever in stores this holiday season, retailers are dusting off and playing up time-honored techniques for snaring shoppers -- techniques that take less of a bite out of the bottom line.

A public viewing will be held Sunday from 3 to 9 P.M. at St. Mary's Cathedral, three blocks from the State Capitol.

title: Excerpts From 'McTeague'
description: Excerpts from William Bolcom's "McTeague," a new opera recently given its premiere by the Lyric Opera of Chicago, will be presented with piano accompaniment in the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum's "Works and Process" series on Dec. 14 and 15, at 8 P.M. at the Marymount Manhattan Theater, 221 East 71st Street. Mr. Bolcom will accompany singers from the Lyric Opera and will join the co-librettists Arnold Weinstein and Robert Altman in a discussion of the work. The two-act opera is based on an 1899 novel by Frank Norris, which also inspired Erich von Stroheim's 1923 silent-film classic, "Greed." Tickets are $15; $10 for students and seniors. Information: (212) 423-3699.

title: WITCO TO TAKE $28 MILLION IN CHARGES
description: The Witco Corporation said yesterday that it would take charges totaling $28 million against its 1992 earnings to restructure its operations, restate its books and move its New York headquarters to the suburbs. Witco last month completed a $440 million cash purchase of chemical and plastics units from Schering A.G. of Germany. Witco said the restructuring would streamline operations and allow it to integrate the two Schering units, which increased the company's size by 30 percent. The company declined to estimate how many jobs would be cut. In trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, Whitco's share price was unchanged at $46.625.

title: Negotiations Deadlocked on Bailing Out the M.T.A.
description: Negotiations aimed at bailing out the Metropolitan Transportation Authority and preventing a possible fare increase on subways and buses remained deadlocked today after the first face-to-face meeting on the issue between Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and leaders of the State Legislature.

title: HINDUS ARE FORCED FROM MOSQUE SITE
description: Cheerfully shouting slogans, thousands of militant Hindus who demolished a mosque here on Sunday left the town today on special buses and trains after they were driven from the disputed site by commandos in a predawn raid.

title: No Headline
description: "I'm worried about a young teen-age Somalian whose been chewing khat during the afternoon and all evening and wants to test the U.S. Marines. " -- COL. GREG S. NEWBOLD, commander of the Marine expeditionary force. [ A1:6. ]

title: William Shawn, 85, Is Dead; New Yorker's Gentle Despot
description: William Shawn, the shy, strong-willed editor who ran The New Yorker for a third of this century, died yesterday morning at the apartment on the Upper East Side of Manhattan where he had lived since 1950. He was 85 years old.

title: Yeltsin Offers to Concede More Power to Congress
description: President Boris N. Yeltsin today offered the Russian Congress a say in choosing security and foreign ministers, apparently in an effort to gain critical votes for the embattled Acting Prime Minister, Yegor T. Gaidar.

title: Americans Will Find Somalia Full Of Arms Provided by Superpowers
description: The American marines who landed in Somalia tonight have entered a country that is awash in weapons, many of them Soviet-made but also including American arms supplied to the African country by Washington in the 1980's.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L. Penguins Defeat Jets Mario Lemieux was one of three Pittsburgh players with a goal and two assists last night as the Penguins beat the Winnipeg Jets, 5-2, for their eighth victory in 10 games. Lemieux increased his National Hockey League-leading totals to 32 goals and 78 points as the Penguins improved their record to 20-7-3. Lemieux has had at least 2 points in 25 of his 29 games this season. Ron Francis and Jaromir Jagr also had a goal and two assists each as the Penguins raised their home record to 11-1-2. The Penguins are 7-2-1 in their last 10 games against Winnipeg. Pittsburgh is 18-0-3 this season when leading after two periods. (AP) Blackhawks 3, Red Wings 2: Detroit lost its fourth straight game at home for the first time in three years as Michel Goulet's third-period goal was the difference for Chicago. The last time Detroit lost four consecutive games at Joe Louis Arena was November 1989. The Blackhawks, 3-0-1 in their last four games, outshot Detroit, 41-30, to give goalie Tim Cheveldae his first five-game losing streak since January 1991. An apparent goal by Shawn Burr of the Red Wings with 5 minutes 39 seconds left in the game was waved off by Referee Dan Marouelli, who ruled Burr kicked the puck in. (AP) Oilers 3, Flames 1: The Oilers ended a six-game streak without a victory against their provincial rival as Bernie Nicholls's disputed goal in the first period helped Edmonton defeat Calgary. With the Flames a man short, Craig Simpson sent a pass through the crease that hit Nicholls in the skate and went past goaltender Mike Vernon at 17:50 for a 2-1 lead. Vernon complained to Referee Ron Hoggarth, who called for a video review. Replays showed the puck went in off Nicholls's skate, but also that he was in the crease at the time. Hoggarth allowed the goal to stand. (AP) TENNIS Ivanisevic Triumphs Goran Ivanisevic had 17 aces yesterday to beat Guy Forget of France in the opening round of the Grand Slam Cup in Munich, Germany, but was not happy with the playing surface. "This court is too fast to enjoy playing," the big-hitting Croat said after defeating Forget, 7-5, 6-4. In other matches, Henri Leconte of France produced the first upset in the $6 million tournament by beating Wayne Ferreira of South Africa, seeded fifth, 3-6, 6-3, 6-0. Petr Korda of Czechoslovakia, seeded seventh, rallied to beat Wally Masur of Australia, 2-6, 7-5, 6-4. In the last match of the day, another serve-and-volley specialist, Richard Krajicek of the Netherlands, seeded eighth, swept past Emilio Sanchez of Spain, 6-3, 6-2. By reaching the quarterfinals, the winners made sure of collecting $300,000 in the richest tournament in the world. First-round losers took home $100,000. (AP)

title: Landlord's Criminal Conviction Is Overturned by Appeals Court
description: An appeals court has overturned the 1990 conviction of J. Leonard Spodek, a landlord who was involved in several highly publicized cases about violations in dozens of apartment buildings that he owned in Brooklyn.

title: Billy Graham To Lead Prayer
description: The Rev. Billy Graham, the evangelist who has been spiritual adviser to several Presidents, will deliver the invocation and benediction at the inauguration of President-elect Bill Clinton and Vice President-elect Al Gore, organizers of the event announced today.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: YOU MISSED AUTUMN To all you New Yorkers who moved down South: You missed blazing trees, the crunch of dry leaves, And tart apples that freshen your mouth. You missed carved pumpkins, stuffed scarecrows, and the first icy hail that pings at your windows. I needed the heater as I drove to town. Look for me I'm coming down! STELLA E. SMALLHEISER . . .

title: METRO DIGEST
description: METRO DIGEST NEW YORK CITY FEW SURPRISES IN HOSPITAL REPORT

title: Topics of The Times; Extended Forecasts: Clouded
description: December comes in with some mixed extended weather forecasts. Scientists making new studies of ancient minerals believe that the earth's next Ice Age, which has been scheduled to deep-freeze much of the North within a few centuries, may not come for another 10,000 years.

title: Safety Panel Opens Inquiry Into G.M. Pickups
description: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration opened an investigation today to determine whether there is a defect in the design of General Motors pickup trucks built from 1973 to 1987 that poses the danger of fire during a crash.

title: Live, and in Great Numbers: It's Somalia Tonight With Tom, Ted and Dan
description: The troops landing in Somalia yesterday jumped from their rubber boats and headed into the dunes -- and into the glare of television lights.

title: Foe of Slovak Leader Asking For U.S. Aid for New Nation
description: A leader of the opposition in Slovakia, which is to become an independent republic in three weeks, said today that the United States should assist his country regardless of the relatively authoritarian character of its current Government.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Monday with an article about vacated corporate buildings in the suburbs misidentified the picture at the left. It showed a building built for GTE that now houses Stamford city offices. The picture at the center, labeled the GTE building, was the company's corporate headquarters, also in Stamford.

title: Nets' Contrast: Coleman and Anderson
description: From the day Derrick Coleman slammed his teammates in print last month, the new coaching staff of the New Jersey Nets has gotten what it considers to be a fairly good read of its two young franchise players, Coleman and Kenny Anderson. It hardly likes what it sees of Coleman. It loves the current view of Anderson.

title: The Pop Life
description: Remembering Roy Orbison

title: Comptronix Stock Falls
description: The shares of the Comptronix Corporation fell 15 percent in early over-the-counter trading yesterday but bounced back in late afternoon and closed at $6.125, off 62.5 cents. The stock of the electronics concern, based in Guntersville, Ala., collapsed from $15.875 to $6.125 on Nov. 25 when the company said it had suspended its top three officials for inflating profits.

title: MANY WILL ESCAPE ETHICS RESTRICTION
description: After weeks of internal debate, transition officials for President-elect Bill Clinton said today that they had drafted ethics rules that would apply to fewer than half of the Administration's political appointees.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: TCF FINANCIAL CORP., Minneapolis, and Republic Capital Group Inc., Milwaukee, announced the signing of a definitive agreement for TCF to acquire Republic Capital in a tax-free stock-for-stock exchange for valued at $62.4 million. TYCO TOYS INC., Mount Laurel, N.J., announced it had reached an agreement in principle to acquire a majority interest in Munecas y Juguetes Ensueno S.A., the distributor in Mexico of Tyco and a wide range of other toy products. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Germany Closes the Gate
description: Engulfed by refugees and torn by violent attacks on foreigners, Germany has decided to clamp down on a frontier now entirely open to asylum-seekers. The ruling Christian Democrats and the opposition Social Democrats agreed last weekend on a tough policy that would end the refugee tide by closing the gates to newcomers from countries said to be free of repression.

title: Executive Changes
description: EMI-VIRGIN MUSIC PUBLISHING, Los Angeles, named Kaz Utsunomiya president. EPSON AMERICA INC., Torrance, Calif., appointed Norio Niwa president and chief executive. He will continue to serve as president and chief operating officer of the computer products business unit at Epson Portland Inc.

title: Redmen Scare UConn But Lose in Overtime
description: No one, least of all the first-year coach Brian Mahoney, had put too much stock in St. John's 3-0 record. After all, the victories were over St. Francis of Brooklyn, Iona and Niagara -- not teams of Big East caliber.

title: Deere & Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Included a gain of $ 20.7 million from the reduction of inventories valued on last-in-first-out basis in the quarter and $ 42.8 million for the year.c-Net loss and included after-tax restructuring charges of $ 120 million in both the quarter and year. The periods also included LIFO gains of $ 65 million in the fourth quarter and $ 84.4 million for the year.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Once again, they're changing the stationery, the business cards and the sign on the door at Akin, Gump, Hauer & Feld, the Washington law firm, to include the name of one of its founders, ROBERT S. STRAUSS (it goes between Gump and Hauer).

title: AMERICAN DENTAL LASER STOCK SOARS
description: The stock of American Dental Laser Inc. has increased more than threefold since Friday, when the company said it had received clearance from the Food and Drug Administration to market its KCP 2000 cavity preparation device.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Every once in a while, LOWELL P. WEICKER JR. likes to step out of his role as Governor of Connecticut.

title: Catherines Stores reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Included an after-tax unusual charge of $ 970,000.c-Included a pretax unusual charge of $ 1,899,000. The after-tax charge was not disclosed.The company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: A.L. Van Houtte reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 10
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Accounts
description: * Fisher-Price, East Aurora, N.Y., to Orsatti & Parrish, Boston, as the toy company's first direct-marketing agency. Orsatti will work with Fisher-Price's ad agency, Waring & LaRosa, New York. Billings were not disclosed.

title: Intermetco Ltd. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net lossResults are in Canadian dollars.

title: Agency Gives Up Cruise Account
description: J. Walter Thompson Chicago announced yesterday that it had resigned the Premier Cruise Lines account, with billings estimated at $4 million, after handling the account nearly three years.

title: Leasing Is Main Weapon In Battle for Top-Selling Car
description: WILL the Ford Taurus overtake the Honda Accord as America's best-selling car? With just a few weeks left in the year, Ford has its work cut out. Through the end of November, Ford was lagging by roughly 15,000 cars.

title: United Kingdom Fund Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Net income represented net investment income.Net realized and unrealized losses for the latest second quarter were $ 2,720,107, compared with net realized and unrealized gain of $ 4,147,517, or $ 1.05 a share, for year-ago period.Total net realized and unrealized gains for the latest 6 months were $ 4,187,293, or $ 1.05 a share, against total net realized and unrealized loss of $ 1,579,549, for year-ago period.

title: Prices of Municipal Bonds Rise
description: The prices of actively traded municipal bonds rose about 1/4 point yesterday as investors moved to buy ahead of what could be a rally at the beginning of next year. The demand was good enough that several new issues were repriced to lower yields.

title: Robert Patrick Jr., 58, Tax Lawyer in Capital
