description: Jesus' Son Stories By Denis Johnson 160 pages. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $19.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-23 YELTSIN DENOUNCES CRITICS

title: Company News: Flights of Fancy?; In Continental Auction, Fliers Can Blaze a Trail
description: Some lucky high flier will have a chance to get an acting career off the ground. Another veteran of the skies can spend seven days riding a prairie schooner along the Oregon Trail or four days riding a wagon train in Arizona.

title: Walker Leaves Team; UConn Pummels Yale
description: Toraino Walker, the co-captain of the Connecticut team, said today he had had enough basketball and would not rejoin the Huskies. No matter; they seem to be getting along well enough without the 6-foot-7-inch senior forward-center.

title: EUROPEANS TRYING TO RESCUE TREATY
description: With hopes for European unity clouded by an economic slowdown, squabbles between governments and waning public enthusiasm, European Community leaders are to meet here on Friday to try to rescue an ambitious blueprint for the future that they agreed on only 12 months ago.

title: AIDS Panel Urges Condoms for Students
description: If New Jersey wants to slow the spread of AIDS, condoms should be made available to all students beginning in the ninth grade and hypodermic needles should be sold over the counter, an advisory panel will tell Gov. Jim Florio on Friday.

title: A History of Hitting the Snooze Button
description: So what's to be done about Magic and Marge, two entertainers who seem to have worn out their welcomes? An odd pairing, perhaps, this ebullient, beloved, stricken former basketball star and this cranky, lonely, narrow-minded baseball owner. Perhaps not.

title: Diller Acquires QVC Stake
description: Barry Diller, who resigned as chairman of Fox Inc. earlier this year to start his own company, has agreed to acquire a stake in QVC Network Inc., a shopping channel, in hopes of forming a new cable venture that would be at the forefront in using new television technology.

title: Review/Opera; Probing A Woman's Madness
description: In her 1892 novella, "The Yellow Wallpaper," Charlotte Perkins Gilman described her own experiences with a peculiar rest cure, developed by Dr. Silas Weir Mitchell and thought to be the answer to all manner of feminine nervous disorders. The cure involved restricted reading and conversation, and a prohibition against creative work. Some women apparently responded well, but others -- including Gilman, who was treated for a nervous breakdown -- were driven from boredom to near-madness.

title: Tom Cunningham, 32, Worker With the Deaf
description: Tom Cunningham, a social worker who helped deaf people and others with disabilities and a was leader in AIDS organizations, died on Wednesday at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center in Manhattan. He was 32.

title: Mr. Barr's Cloud: Growing Darker
description: Could Attorney General William Barr be trusted to produce a credible examination of his own Administration's possibly criminal aid to Iraq before the Persian Gulf war? That didn't seem likely two months ago when he appointed Frederick Lacey, a former Federal judge, to conduct an ostensibly independent investigation. Judge Lacey has now issued his report and the answer is worse than no.

title: New Disclosures in Peru Show Plot's Wide Web
description: A coup attempt here last month so rattled President Alberto K. Fujimori that he took refuge for three hours in the residence of the Japanese Ambassador.

title: Music in Churches and Concert Halls; Oratorios in Abundance
description: Here is a sampling of performances of Handel's "Messiah" and other oratorios in New York City. Admission is free unless otherwise noted. Today

title: ERICSSON AND HEWLETT-PACKARD PHONE-SYSTEM VENTURE
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company, the third-largest American computer maker, and L. M. Ericsson, a top maker of telecommunications equipment, said yesterday that they planned a venture in the increasingly complex and lucrative market for managing large corporations' telephone systems. Ericsson Hewlett-Packard Telecommunications A.B. will be owned 60 percent by Ericsson and 40 percent by Hewlett, and based, like Ericsson, in Stockholm. The amounts invested in the venture were not disclosed. The venture, employing 350 workers, is to begin operating in the first quarter.

title: At the Bar
description: There are not many memorable moments in his 25 years in the Manhattan Surrogate's Court that Nathaniel Weiss has failed to record. Whether art experts were testifying in the Estate of Mark Rothko, or Al Pacino was testifying in the Estate of Lee Strasberg, or 15 workers were disrupting Estate of J. Seward Johnson, Mr. Weiss, his fingers dancing over the keyboard of his trusty stenograph, got it down.

title: Fire Guts St. Agnes, a Historic Manhattan Church
description: A four-alarm fire of unknown origin roared through the historic Church of St. Agnes near Grand Central Terminal yesterday afternoon, destroying one of midtown Manhattan's most notable architectural treasures and an oasis of serenity in the heart of a frenzied city.

title: Stanley Friedman, 64, Founder of Law Firm
description: Stanley J. Friedman, a founder and senior partner of the Manhattan law firm of Shereff Friedman Hoffman & Goodman, died on Wednesday at his home in Riverdale, the Bronx. He was 64.

title: Attacker in Howard Beach Case to Be Freed
description: Jason Ladone, one of three men convicted in the Howard Beach racial attack six years ago, will be released from prison in February after serving the minimum five years of a 5- to 15-year sentence, the State Parole Board announced yesterday.

title: BMW to Modify Lease Ads After an Abrams Complaint
description: BMW of North America was reprimanded yesterday by Attorney General Robert Abrams of New York for advertisements promoting lease deals. He said the advertisements were misleading because they "bury" information in small print about down payments needed to produce the relatively low monthly payments that are more prominently advertised.

title: U.S. IS SAID TO WEIGH LAWSUIT AGAINST BIG AIRLINES
description: Delta Air Lines Inc. and USAir Group Inc. said in Securities and Exchange Commission filings that recent discussions with the Justice Department led them to believe the agency was preparing to sue the big domestic airlines, based on a long inquiry into whether they fix domestic-ticket prices. USAir said its discussions with the agency "may result in a mutually acceptable resolution of the matter," but it could not give any guarantees. Several major airlines have said in regulatory filings that they received civil investigative demands from the Justice agency. But the department has yet to take any public action based on these information requests.

title: Top Award to Stallings
description: Alabama Coach GENE STALLINGS, who played for Bear Bryant at Texas A&M and was his assistant at Alabama, won the Bear Bryant Award last night in Houston as the college football coach of the year. (AP)

title: Fastest Growing Economies Cut Tax Subsidies
description: To the Editor:

title: Seasonal Favorites From Critics' CD Shelves
description: YEAR-END holidays are invitations to wallow in tradition, which may explain my preference here for old (or old-fashioned) performances over trendier newcomers. I pick Sir Georg Solti's "Messiah" because I have never felt comfortable with modern countertenors hooting the solo alto arias, and because Sir Georg's interpretation sounds warm and reassuring yet plausibly lean (unlike Sir Thomas Beecham's amusingly over-the-top account).

title: Seasonal Favorites From Critics' CD Shelves
description: REJOICE, rejoice greatly. When it comes to music associated with Christmas, the recorded blessings are, if anything, too plentiful.

title: Don't Equate Syphilis With Invaders' Ills
description: To the Editor:

title: Is He Gone? As the Giants Drop Games, Handley Has Dropped Hints
description: Publicly, Ray Handley refuses to discuss his job security. But privately, Giants players say, their beleaguered head coach has given mixed signals to them. They said he delivered these messages after losing games in which the Giants played poorly:

title: Port Authority Budget Averts Rise in Fares
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey approved yesterday a $2.7 billion budget for 1993 that it said insures that fares on the PATH system and tolls on the authority's six bridges and tunnels will not increase for at least two years.

title: Municipal Bond Volume to Set Mark
description: The dollar value of new municipal bond issues will set a record this year, the Public Securities Association said yesterday.

title: Judge May Dismiss Case in Drug Agent's Torture
description: A Federal judge said today that he would consider dismissing the case against a Mexican doctor on trial in the 1985 torture and murder of a United States narcotics agent, saying there was a lack of direct evidence.

title: Nicholas L. King, 68, Press Center Director
description: Nicholas LeRoy King, the managing director of the Federal Government's New York Foreign Press Center since 1981, died on Wednesday in his Manhattan office. He was 68.

title: Mets Try Ancient Remedy
description: The Mets' quest for a durable fifth starting pitcher ended yesterday when the club came to terms with Frank Tanana, a 39-year-old left-hander with surprising staying power.

title: Helen St. Aubin, 69, Athlete Who Inspired Film
description: Helen Callaghan Candaele St. Aubin, the speedy outfielder whose swing won one batting title and inspired two movies about the All-American Girls Professional Baseball League, died Tuesday night at Cottage Hospital in Santa Barbara, Calif., at age 69. She died of breast cancer, according to her son Kelly Candaele, whose 1988 documentary about his mother's career, "A League of Their Own," inspired last summer's movie of the same name.

title: Review/Film; Enough True Love For Two
description: Love as a terrifically intense if farcical learning experience is the subtext of Chantal Akerman's "Night and Day," an elegant and stylish new French comedy that's as subversively funny as its two very young lovers are self-absorbed and humorless. The film, opening today at the Joseph Papp Public Theater, is the Belgian-born Ms. Akerman's post-modern take on "Jules and Jim," with a little bit of "The Captain's Paradise" thrown in.

title: The Transition: An Eye Toward Wall Street and Capitol Hill; Promises Before Policies
description: With the choices he announced today, President-elect Bill Clinton indicated that the main responsibility of the top economic policy officials in his Administration would be not so much to develop new policy as to get his campaign promises enacted quickly.

title: Clinton Says He'll Consider Inquiry Into Bank Case Involving Iraq
description: President-elect Bill Clinton said today that despite a Bush Administration investigation that found no criminal wrongdoing in a bank fraud case involving loans to Iraq he still believed that there was more to be discovered about what happened.

title: Abroad at Home; An International Pariah
description: The world's diplomats have tried over many months to end Serbian aggression in Bosnia by talking with Serbia's President, Slobodan Milosevic. Such distinguished figures as Cyrus Vance, Lord Carrington and Lord Owen have been involved. Cease-fires and other steps toward peace have been repeatedly promised -- and forgotten.

title: Reflections in an Unflinching Eye: C-SPAN Meets Baseball
description: It's too bad C-SPAN could not provide coverage of yesterday's United States Senate hearings into baseball's antitrust exemption the way ESPN would do it. Where was the video? The replays of inflammatory comments? The studio analysis?

title: THE TRANSITION: A Cabinet Begins to Take Shape; Excerpts From Clinton's Announcement of Appointments to Economic Posts
description: Following are excerpts from a news conference yesterday in which President-elect Bill Clinton announced the appointment of Senator Lloyd Bentsen as Secretary of the Treasury and named other economic advisers, as recorded by News Transcripts Inc., a private transcription service:

title: Rockefeller Center Trust to Cut Dividend
description: Rockefeller Center Properties Inc., the real estate investment trust that holds the mortgage on Rockefeller Center, said yesterday that it would cut its fourth-quarter dividend.

title: Georgetown Alumni Clash at The Garden
description: Patrick Ewing poked his head into the Charlotte Hornets' locker room early last night and spotted Larry Johnson sitting near the door. As this was a Georgetown University kind of night at Madison Square Garden, Ewing couldn't resist replaying the old college game.

title: Dinkins Picks An Educator As a Deputy
description: Two months after his first choice was derailed by sexual-harassment charges, Mayor David N. Dinkins yesterday appointed a new deputy mayor to promote and publicize his initiatives despite criticism from political rivals that the job is mainly an arm of the Mayor's re-election effort.

title: TV Weekend; Imagining the Details Of the Royal Troubles
description: American television's fascination with Britain's royal family lurches forward yet again this weekend as ABC presents "Charles and Diana: Unhappily Ever After" on Sunday at 9 P.M. From the coronation of Queen Elizabeth II in 1953 through various royal romances and weddings, lavishly dramatized in earlier movies, television has exploited the supposed fairy-tale aspects of life at Buckingham Palace. Now it's time to dig into the subsequent scandals and divorces. Viewers may have a problem deciding whether to laugh or cry.

title: Clinton's Other Run
description: To the Editor:

title: University Seeks a Laboratory-Marketplace Link
description: The president of the University of California today proposed the creation of a for-profit corporation to help bridge the gap between the laboratory and marketplace for technology developed by university researchers.

title: Anderson Puts in Triple Time
description: Kenny Anderson and Mark Jackson are friends. Off the court. On it, no two players could be more competitive. They don't talk trash to each other, Jackson said, they just make jokes.

title: 2 Somalis Killed in Clash
description: Two Somalis were killed and seven ere wounded today in a gunbattle at a French military checkpoint here, the first deaths of the two-day-old American-led military mission.

title: U.S. Seeks to Make Transit Workers Take Breath Tests for Alcohol
description: The Transportation Department today proposed new regulations that would make seven million transportation workers subject to on-the-job breath tests for alcohol use and expand existing drug tests to include mass transit workers.

title: Fastest Growing Economies Cut Tax Subsidies; Debtors' Folly
description: To the Editor:

title: Neediest Offers Help To the Deaf
description: When Christina Dunams ventures onto the playground of her elementary school, she is often greeted by taunts instead of invitations to join games of tag or hopscotch. Other children tease her about her hearing aid, mimic her when she uses sign language or parrot her speech.

title: Harry Ellerbe, Actor and Director, 91
description: Harry Ellerbe, an actor and director who worked on Broadway, in regional theater and in films, died on Dec. 3 at the A. G. Rhodes Nursing Home in Marietta, Ga. He was 91 years old.

title: A Record-Breaking Year for Bank Profits
description: Signaling a dramatic turnaround for the banking industry from the gloomy forecasts of just 12 months ago, Federal regulators said today that 1992 would be the most profitable year ever for the nation's banks.

title: White-Faced Greenbacks
description: For years, there has been talk of redesigning America's currency, but it has centered on economic and anti-counterfeiting benefits, not on symbolic importance. Coins and paper money are a ubiquitous reminder of our national identity. Yet all in circulation were designed more than three decades ago and feature Dead White Males; the noncirculating Susan B. Anthony dollar is the exception that proves the rule.

title: Is Iacocca Just a Local Favorite or a World-Class Brand?
description: ONLY time will tell how well Lee A. Iacocca travels. Should he move to a different company when he retires from the Chrysler Corporation in a few weeks -- he has been talking with the machinists' union at Trans World Airlines about becoming the airline's chairman -- would the charisma he brought to 61 Chrysler commercials carry over?

title: Baseball Executives Are Taken To Task
description: One day after Bud Selig said major league baseball was running more smoothly than it is generally given credit for, baseball's top executive and five of his fellow club owners listened to a host of United States Senators and Representatives strongly disagree.

title: Bonds to Wear No. 25
description: BARRY BONDS, who joined the San Francisco Giants for $43.75 million earlier this week, decided to turn down godfather WILLIE MAYS's offer to unretire his No. 24 jersey so Bonds could have the number he wore for six years as a Pittsburgh Pirate. Instead, Bonds will wear No. 25, the number his father, BOBBY, wore for the Giants from 1968-1974. (AP)

title: Yankees Finally Get It Right and Land a Lefty
description: The Yankees finally did it. After a dreadful experience at the winter meetings, where they unsuccessfully chased expensive free agents, they finally signed a pitcher on their wish list last night as Jimmy Key agreed to a four-year contract worth $17 million.

title: Budget Option Would Raise Gas Tax in '96
description: The New Jersey Legislature and the Florio administration are studying a proposal to divert hundreds of millions of dollars from the state's Transportation Trust Fund over the next five years to balance the budget. The plan would require a 4.5-cent increase in the gasoline tax in 1996.

title: THE TRANSITION: Man in the News -- Lloyd Millard Bentsen Jr.; Insider for the Treasury
description: Lloyd Bentsen is almost everything Bill Clinton is not. He is a multimillionaire, languid and almost aloof, calm and not intensely driven. He got his political start proclaiming his record as a decorated bomber pilot.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Truman Capote loved the East End of Long Island, and in 1961 he bought a compound in Sagaponack that he later gave to Jack Dunphy, his companion of 35 years. Capote died in 1984, Dunphy in April, and last week the property, which includes two houses on four acres near the ocean, was put up for sale. The asking price: $1.25 million.

title: School Program for Poor Is Failing, a Panel Says
description: The Federal Government's main program for helping improve the basic academic skills of poor children is failing those students and needs to be overhauled, a report by an independent commission said yesterday.

title: Lithuania Seeks a Niche in High Technology
description: Under the eyes of Russia's 107th Division and beset by countless other unwelcome remnants of the Soviet era, Lithuanian scientists, engineers and would-be business leaders are gambling on advanced technology to gain entrance to the industrialized world.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Sunday about one of the first female lawyers in New Jersey rendered her last name incorrectly in some editions. She was Fannie Bear Besser.

title: Across the U.S., Immigrants Find the Land of Resentment
description: On her way home from school recently, a Chinese immigrant girl was attacked by other teen-agers who spray-painted her face black. She and her guidance counselors at the Seward Park High School in lower Manhattan were horrified, but they were not shocked. Attacks on newly arrived immigrants are a routine occurrence at their school, they said.

title: Review/Theater; Being Gay And Naked In America
description: During one section of his new, uninhibited monologue, "My Queer Body," Tim Miller is naked to the world, or rather to the 93 people who by his count fill the seats at Performance Space 122. Unabashed if a bit self-conscious, he is determined to talk to the audience as freely and openly as possible. After all, his life is on the line. In this and other shows, Mr. Miller specializes in self-exposure, and the approach is emotional as well as physical.

title: School Adopts Bid to Leave City College
description: Faculty members at City College's School of Engineering voted yesterday to seek the secession of the school from the college, a move that has been brewing for years but was accelerated by release of a report this week that calls for a major overhaul of academic programs throughout City University's 19 colleges.

title: Corrections
description: A report by Bloomberg Business News in the Company News column of Business Day yesterday about a stock offering by Hospitality Franchise Systems Inc. described the involvement of an executive, Henry Silverman, incorrectly. Mr. Silverman did not sell any shares as part of the offering. The report also misstated the amount of the Blackstone Group's investment in parts of the company two years ago. It was $120 million.

title: Defense Cross-Examines Woman in Assault Case
description: Defense lawyers in the Glen Ridge sexual-assault trial cross-examined a 21-year-old mentally retarded woman today, trying to show that the four defendants did not force her to perform sex acts nearly four years ago.

title: The Clinton Anti-Gridlock Team
description: Teamwork. Coordination. Words like these dominated President-elect Clinton's news conference yesterday because they govern his choice of five top economic officials. All five are cut from the same fiscally conservative cloth; they should have little trouble working together.

title: The Packwood Problem
description: By acknowledging the truth of charges that he had sexually harassed female aides, Senator Bob Packwood may have hoped to contain the scandal that now threatens his career. But his apology, however sincere, cannot excuse his abuse of office or his maligning of his accusers to hold off news coverage of the damaging facts until after his narrow victory in the November elections.

title: Somali Welcome Aside, The Marines Are Jittery
description: Peering out under his wet, sand-encrusted helmet, Cpl. Tony Storey glanced at the crowds lining the streets in a light rain here today, then suddenly barked, "Hey! Watch those guys up on that water tower!"

title: Fastest Growing Economies Cut Tax Subsidies; Advertising Body Blow
description: To the Editor:

title: Somali Gunmen, Pushed Away From Capital, Take Terror Inland
description: Gunmen, some of them flushed from Mogadishu by the arrival of American troops, have terrorized this town at the epicenter of the Somali famine in the last few days, killing, looting and preventing relief agencies from feeding the hungry.

title: First Proposal On Cable Prices
description: The Federal Communications Commission today proposed regulating cable television prices by measuring them against one of several possible benchmarks for reasonableness.

title: Tan Bien Journal; Hanoi to Show Tourists Hideout That Eluded U.S.
description: Deep in the steamy, malarial jungles of southwestern Vietnam, an army of teen-age laborers too young to remember the Vietnam War are redigging collapsed dirt tunnels and rebuilding the bamboo huts in which Communist rebels once planned the overthrow of the South Vietnamese Government and the humiliation of its American backers.

title: Investigation in Beating To Continue, Says Hynes
description: The Brooklyn District Attorney's office said yesterday that a grand jury would continue to investigate the case of a homeless black man who said he was beaten by Hasidic Jews in Crown Heights and whose lawyer says the man cannot now be found.

title: Diner's Journal
description: Restaurant Two Two Two

title: Article 065192 -- No Title
description: When the cold blasts of winter penetrate even the heaviest jacket, thoughts don't turn automatically to Cuban food. What can a country more familiar with palm fronds than bare trees offer for cold-weather eating? But it's hard to find food more warming, more filling or more comforting than the heaping portions at this often chaotic little Cuban restaurant.

title: On My Mind; Dinkins and Hasidim
description: What do the Jews of Crown Heights want of this man, this Mayor so civilized, so gentlemanly, that for millions of New Yorkers the words decent and Dinkins go together?

title: California Moves to Revitalize San Francisco Bay
description: After years of dispute, the state of California moved today to repair one of the worst environmental calamities in the American West: the degradation of San Francisco Bay and its estuary, which supplies drinking water to 20 million urban Californians and irrigation for millions of acres of farms.

title: Fernandez Tells Rebels Deadline Is Today
description: A day after the Board of Education overturned the suspension of a defiant school board in Queens, Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez and the local board clashed again yesterday over a curriculum that includes lessons about gay families.

title: Art in Review
description: Pat Steir Robert Miller Gallery 40 East 57th Street Mid-Manhattan Through Dec. 31

title: Times and a Union Have Tentative Pact
description: The New York Times and District 15 of the International Association of Machinists, whose members maintain and repair the newspaper's production equipment, reached a tentative contract agreement yesterday.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball American League

title: People
description: * John Kallir, 68, chairman and founder of Kallir, Philips, Ross Inc., New York, announced plans to retire, effective Dec. 31, though he will remain with the agency as chairman emeritus. Norman Cooper, 61, president and chief executive of the health-care agency, was named to succeed Mr. Kallir as chairman.

title: Britons Doubt Charles and Diana Will Ever Rule
description: Conservative members of Parliament, newspaper editorialists and even avid royalists voiced skepticism today that the Prince and Princess of Wales would be able to fulfill their intended future roles as King and Queen now that they have separated as husband and wife.

title: Bolivians May Never Know Rock Slide's Toll
description: The faces of the Andean Indians who work these gold mines are stoic or despondent. A woman with a felt hat and a long dark braid wept as she climbed over boulders and rubble in search of her three children. A man who had lost his wife and three children squatted quietly under a thatched shelter waiting for a bulldozer to uncover bodies. Children who had lost their parents wandered the camp stunned.

title: Torretta's No. 1 Backup: the Older Brother Who Went Before at Miami
description: This weekend, Geoff Torretta will make his second trip to the Downtown Athletic Club for a Heisman Trophy presentation, a remarkable achievement for a former quarterback whose major-college career consisted of 75 passes.

title:
About Real Estate;
New and Affordable East Side Rentals
description: After a decade-long search, Tina Amarena has finally succeeded in trading her cramped studio apartment on East 70th Street for a new one-bedroom rental blocks away at 175 East 96th Street on the Upper East Side of Manhattan.

title: Pirates' Hurley Finds A Mammoth Opening
description: On an evening of frigid winds and cold rain, Seton Hall learned a small lesson about weathering storms tonight.

title: Review/Film; Two Marines and Their Code on Trial
description: The role doesn't have to be big, but if it's good, and if the actor playing it is great, the results can be magically transforming. Witness Jack Nicholson's vicious, funny, superbly reptilian turn in Rob Reiner's entertaining "A Few Good Men," adapted by Aaron Sorkin from his hit Broadway courtroom drama.

title: It's Winter, but Steinbrenner Is Warming Up
description: Less than four months from being reinstated to his position as the owner who runs the Yankees, George Steinbrenner spoke out yesterday in defense of his team, his city and his "people."

title: The Revenge of History
description: Next week, our 8-year-old twin sons are traveling home with us to India. It is an India they have always identified with, though they have grown up elsewhere. Ask them what they are, and they'll tell you they're Indian. Not "Hindu," not "Malayali," not "Nair," not "Calcuttan," though they could claim all those labels, too. Just Indian.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: AMERICAN GENERAL LIFE INSURANCE CO., Houston, agreed to acquire the insurance assets and liabilities of New Jersey Life Insurance Co., Paramus, N.J. AMERICAN TELEPHONE AND TELEGRAPH CO. introduced technology aimed at eliminating eavesdropping on cellular-phone conversations. DIVERSICARE CORP. OF AMERICA, Franklin, Tenn., said a unit bought Duracare Medical Equipment of Tempe, Ariz. PROCTER & GAMBLE CO., Cincinnati, said it was reviewing operations and may cut its workforce, which currently numbers 106,000 employees worldwide.

title: Market Place; Here's a Pitch To Hang Up On
description: PSST. Lean in close. Here's a sure winner of a stock tip. Big company, its shares selling for a couple of bucks, and it's ready to go gangbusters. Lee A. Iacocca, that fella who turned around Chrysler? Well, he's been asked to take over this place. Not only that, but this company -- one of the nation's biggest airlines, mind you -- is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, and everybody knows that means financial strength. The company's name? Trans World Airlines.

title: INDIA ISSUES A BAN ON 5 RIVAL GROUPS
description: The Indian Government announced a ban on five powerful Hindu and Muslim fundamentalist organizations tonight as the death toll in rioting and clashes with security forces rose to 950.

title: California Retailer Settles Suit on Customer Privacy
description: Shoppers at Mervyn's department stores in California may be eligible for nearly $6 million worth of vouchers because of a settlement of a lawsuit that contended that the retailer had violated a privacy statute.

title: CHRONICLE
description: LORD ROTHSCHILD has been named president of the Institute of Jewish Affairs, the research arm of the World Jewish Congress. He succeeds EDGAR M. BRONFMAN, the president of the congress.

title: For Children
description: 'Hansel and Gretel' Promenade Theater 2162 Broadway (at 76th Street) (212) 677-5959 Recommended ages: 5 and up Through Jan. 3

title: Son Is Insider in MCA Case, S.E.C. Says
description: It was September 1990, and Hollywood was about to be shaken by the news that the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company of Japan was buying MCA Inc., the entertainment industry giant, whose president was the blunt, bare-knuckled Sidney Sheinberg.

title: One Good Half Ends 23-Game Frustration
description: Fordham turned back St. John's and the clock last night. Way back.

title: SEASONAL FAVORITES FROM CRITICS' CD SHELVES
description: CHRISTMAS is the musical holiday par excellence. To complement the rich and ancient song traditions of many nations, most of the great composers of the West have taken musical note of the season, some of them in a big way.

title: On Stage, and Off
description: Casting Crunch for a New Rabe Play

title: 'Teach Us How to Be Good Doctors'
description: Last week a group of families met in Minneapolis to talk about their struggles to help loved ones die, with little help from physicians.

title: U.N. Wants Somalia Disarmed Before U.S. Leaves
description: The United Nations Secretary General, Boutros Boutros-Ghali, has told the United States that its troops should stay in Somalia until they disarm the country's warlords, remove mines in the north, train a military police force and restore order, senior Administration officials said today.

title: Review/Dance; Ailey Season Begins
description: For the first time in years, the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater opened without its customary and highly festive gala. Not to worry: there will be two such benefits in a season that also features an unusually large number of premieres (four) and stretches through Jan. 3.

title: A Curious Approach to Cone
description: No free-agent negotiations went well for the Yankees here. One set of talks, however, was colored by a unique peculiarity. The Yankees, after making a respectable initial offer to David Cone, steadily shrank the financial dimensions of their proposal until it was too late.

title: INSIDE
description: Clue to Tumors' Power

title: Packwood Offers Apology Without Saying for What
description: Senator Bob Packwood said today that he took "full responsibility" for his "unwelcome and offensive" sexual advances toward female aides, but declined repeatedly to describe his behavior.

title: Metro Digest
description: BREATH TESTS AIMED AT TRANSIT WORKERS

title: Metropolitan Opera
description: The Metropolitan Opera is to present the first performance this season of Wagner's "Walkure" at 7 P.M. tomorrow. The cast includes Gwyneth Jones as Brunhilde, Jessye Norman as Sieglinde, Hanna Schwarz as Fricka, Gary Lakes as Siegmund, James Morris as Wotan and Aage Haugland as Hunding. James Levine conducts. Tickets are $21 to $117. Information: (212) 362-6000.

title: Czechs and Slovaks Divide Up Assets on Brink of Separation
description: Like all 136,000 men and women in Czechoslovakia's armed forces, Lieut. Col. Peter Fuzak must choose between serving in the future Czech or Slovak Army after the country splits up on January 1.

title: Next Goal for the Military: Dealing With Realities
description: It is said around the Pentagon that no military plan survives contact with the enemy. Already that piece of accepted wisdom is starting to come true in Somalia.

title: Chambers Street: Bargains and Bagels
description: SHAKESPEARE said the human drive to consume is incurable. Herbert Marcuse went a step further, suggesting that modern man finds his soul in possessions. Well, of course! Go downtown and the thesis will be forever proven.

title: The Art Market
description: Warhol Money Troubles

title: Coach to Be Exonerated
description: Drug possession charges against ARNOLD JETER, an assistant football coach at Rutgers, are expected to be dropped, the Middlesex County, N.J., prosecutor's office said yesterday.

title: Wounded Plainclothes Officer Plans to Sue
description: Lawyers for the plainclothes transit police officer who was shot and critically wounded by fellow officers in Brooklyn last month said yesterday that he planned to file a $50 million lawsuit against New York City and the transit police.

title: Imcera Group President Resigns in a Shake-Up
description: The Imcera Group announced a shake-up today of its top management and warned that its earnings growth might not meet expectations.

title: Rhetoric Aimed at Dinkins on Race Relations Offends Decency
description: To the Editor:

title: How Censorship Efforts by Religious Right Disrupt Education
description: To the Editor:

title: New Cable Venture
description: The former head of Fox television plans a cable venture featuring shop-at-home and pay-per-view services. Page D1.

title: THE TRANSITION: A Cabinet Begins to Take Shape; CLINTON TEAM TAKES SHAPE WITH BENTSEN AND 4 OTHERS NAMED TO ECONOMIC POSTS
description: President-elect Bill Clinton began to give shape to his Cabinet today with the appointment of an economic team of old hands from Washington and Wall Street to help him fulfill his campaign promise of fundamental economic change.

title: HOSPITALITY FRANCHISE STOCK RISES 17% ON ITS FIRST DAY
description: In its first day of trading, the stock of Hospitality Franchise Systems Inc. closed yesterday at 18 3/4, up 2 3/4, or 17 percent, from the price of its initial public offering on Wednesday. Volume was 2.8 million shares. Of the six million common shares in the offering, the largest block was sold by Buckhead America Inc., a bankrupt concern from which Hospitality bought the Days Inn chain early this year. Other sellers of Hospitality stock were Buckhead creditors, a lawyer representing Hospitality, James E. Buckman, said. Only 503,000 were sold directly by Hospitality Franchise, and no shares were sold by the company's chairman, Henry Silverman, or by other insiders, he said.

title: The Hatreds of India; Hindu Memory Scarred by Centuries Of Sometimes Despotic Islamic Rule
description: When Hindus destroyed a 16th-century mosque in a remote northern town on Sunday, they touched off four days of rioting in which hundreds were killed as Muslims protested against what they saw as persecution.

title: John A. Corbett, 69, Buffalo Broadcaster
description: John A. Corbett, a longtime radio and television broadcaster in Buffalo, died on Monday at Sarasota Memorial Hospital in Sarasota, Fla., where he lived. He was 69.

title: N.H.L. Is Going to Disneyland, and South Florida, Too
description: The National Hockey League voted unanimously today to expand to Miami and Anaheim, Calif., a bold move for a sport that only months ago was in such disarray that its players went on strike for the first time and its longtime president was forced to resign.

title: Mears Says He Will Retire
description: The four-time Indianapolis 500 winner RICK MEARS surprised the racing world last night by announcing his retirement as a competitive driver at the age of 41. Mears, who had surgery on Aug. 19 to repair a broken wrist suffered in crashes before and during the Indianapolis 500 in May, drove his last race Aug. 2, finishing 16th in the Marlboro 500 at Michigan International Speedway. (AP)

title: Piermont Prospers From Makeover on the Hudson; Location, Location, Woody and Mia Aid Transformation From Factories to Galleries
description: Howard Brawner vividly remembers the day in 1983 when he pointed his camera out his living-room window and captured Mia Farrow daubing on some makeup outside his family's home on Piermont Avenue.

title: For Crown Hts. Figure, a Life on Streets
description: Ralph Nimmons is missing. But for the 25-year-old man at the center of the Crown Heights beating case, that is nothing new.

title: Jolly Old Elves Toiling in December's Dream Factory
description: "DID I wake you up last year?"

title: Money Fund Assets Fall
description: The total assets of the nation's 615 retail money market mutual funds decreased $351.3 million, to $387.52 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.

title: A New Microwave System Poses Threat to Cable TV
description: The Federal Communications Commission approved a new microwave technology today to transmit simultaneously dozens of channels of television, telephone calls and large amounts of data.

title: Review/Art; Wolfing Down Modernism Whole
description: Countless catalogues are available on contemporary artists who have barely reached mid-career, but books on American modernists of the inter-war years are few and far between. The names of John Sennhauser, Werner Drewes, Albert Swinden, Gertrude Greene and Charles Shaw, all leading members of an American avant-garde 60 years ago, have scant recognition value today.

title: Review/Photography; Paris in Its Prime, Posing for Classic Images
description: Paris in all its romantic glory is the subject of a fascinating show at the Houk Friedman Gallery. Under the cumbersome title "De l'Ancien Regime aux Temps Modernes: Paris et ses Environs," the gallery has assembled a diverse and often beautiful selection of photographs of the city in its heyday. Most of the pictures in the show, which includes classics by Man Ray, Brassai, Henri Cartier-Bresson, Robert Doisneau and many others, are from the period between the two world wars, when artists and writers flocked to Paris, drawn by its atmosphere of creativity and freedom.

title: Business Digest
description: The Economy

title: Tumors May Suppress Immune Cells That Fight Cancer, Study Finds
description: Cancer cells may release a potent molecule into the bloodstream that cripples the immune system, scientists report. If confirmed, the surprising and potentially far-reaching discovery could cast light on the longstanding mystery of why so many tumors defy rejection by the body's immune defenses.

title: San Antonio Journal; Ancient Ritual for a Modern Casualty
description: Other businesses just go bankrupt or close down, but journalists like to say that newspapers die when they cease publication. At The San Antonio Light, which executives have said will either be closed or sold this month, all the anger and sadness of mourning have found expression in a custom as old as the Aztecs.

title: No Headline
description: "I have heard all those stories about my being an insider. Let me tell you I felt like an outsider for 12 years, and I'm tired of the gridlock." -- LLOYD BENTSEN, chosen as Treasury Secretary by President-elect Clinton. [ A36:5. ]

title: Macy Reports a Narrower Loss in Quarter
description: Losses at R. H. Macy & Company narrowed in the first quarter of its 1993 fiscal year, the bankrupt retailer reported yesterday. It added that holiday sales were running ahead of last year and slightly ahead of plan, but the company said it remained cautious.

title: CHRONICLE
description: PRESIDENT BUSH read what he called "a roll-call of American heroes" yesterday as he bestowed the Presidential Medal of Freedom on 10 people in the arts, diplomacy, the military and sports.

title: Review/Dance; An Ailey Tribute to Dizzy Gillespie
description: "The Winter in Lisbon" is the Alvin Ailey American Dance Company's heartfelt tribute to Dizzy Gillespie, a riot of color and rhythm that celebrates the jazz trumpeter and composer as what he has always been, a great entertainer.

title: Classical Music in Review
description: Two Youth Orchestras Symphony Orchestra Vivo, Alice Tully Hall, and New York Youth Symphony, Carnegie Hall

title:
CAVEAT EMPTOR;
Extended Warranties Are a Good Deal, for the Seller
description: Many buyers of appliances and electronic goods are finding themselves lured by low-ball prices offered by retailers and then pressured to take extended warranties that bring the prices back up to undiscounted levels.

title: THE STORM'S HAVOC: Long Island; Degree of Ferocity Shocks a Place That Is Used to Storms
description: On Long Island, where wind and waves have often turned charming beach communities into disaster areas, the storm that hit today stunned officials with its ferocity.

title: A Daughter, Redemption And Smiles In 1 Package
description: "I LOVE you, you love me, we're a happy family," sang Kendra Vance, repeating words she learned from Barney the Dinosaur on television. The child, who will be 3 in March, laughed and danced and hugged her father in their East Harlem apartment.

title: LDI Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: Judge Bars Broadcasters From Farrow-Allen Case
description: The battle between Woody Allen and Mia Farrow for custody of their three children, part of an already ugly and highly publicized clash between the couple, will not be played out on television and radio when it goes to court, a judge ruled yesterday.

title: Review/Music; A 'Messiah' Looks Back to Premiere in Dublin
description: Handel's "Messiah," which had its premiere in Dublin 250 years ago, has throughout its history been a touchstone of the vicissitudes of Baroque music. One of few works from the era to circulate prominently through the ages, it held its own by evolving with progressive times, from Mozart's fluffy orchestration to the elephan tine inflations of the late 19th century. Some streamlining took place in the 20th century even before current notions of historical correctness began to take hold about four decades ago.

title: Can't an Ad Play Off New York's Problems?
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Music; 'Don Pasquale' in Juilliard's Youthful Embrace
description: If there is a moral to the Juilliard Opera Center's new production of "Don Pasquale," it is this: Beware of delivering music that is vitally young into youthful hands. By the final performance tomorrow afternoon, some of the tentativeness witnessed on Wednesday night at the Juilliard Theater will probably be resolved, but nothing will rescue the inappropriateness of this student cast and Moni Yakim's muddled conception to Donizetti's opera.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Home Section on Thursday about home security systems misstated the telephone number for the National Burglar and Fire Alarm Association, a trade group. The number is (301) 907-3202.

title: Who Manages a Fund? That Can Be Top Secret
description: ONE little sentence. That's all it would have taken to let investors know who was running their mutual funds.

title: Seems Like Old Times As Majors Rejoins Pitt
description: Nearly 20 years to the day after he was asked to rebuild a moribund program at Pittsburgh, JOHNNY MAJORSyesterday took on the same job under nearly the same circumstances.

title: Bolar Chief, A Founder, Steps Down
description: Bolar Pharmaceutical, the troubled Long Island-based maker of low-priced generic drugs, said yesterday that Lawrence S. Raisfeld, one of its founders, would step down as president and chief executive on Jan. 15.

title: FLEET BANK ACQUIRES EASTLAND FINANCIAL UNITS
description: Fleet Bank, lead unit of the Fleet Financial Corporation, yesterday acquired Eastland Bank and Eastland Savings Bank, both based in Woonsocket, R.I. The two banks, owned by the Eastland Financial Corporation, were closed yesterday afternoon by state regulators after the F.D.I.C. held Eastland Bank liable for losses at its parent, Eastland Savings. The F.D.I.C. was named receiver for the banks.

title: Marcus Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 12
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding were adjusted to reflect a 50 percent stock dividend distributed Nov. 6.

title: Home Shopping Network reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Giants Planning a Rotation of Rookies
description: Phil Simms will be here to lend encouragement, but his elbow is still too tender to play. Jeff Hostetler will not be here because he still becomes dizzy from post-concussion syndrome. So when the Giants play the Phoenix Cardinals on Saturday, the rookies -- Kent Graham, their present quarterback of the future, and Dave Brown, perhaps the future quarterback of the future -- will be on display.

title: Genesee Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The company said earnings for the year-earlier 6-month period benefitted from $ 672,000 of non-recurring income from the settlement of an insurance claim and the sale of real estate.The company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: Jimbo's Jumbos Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Aaron Kellner, 78, Who Created A Blood-Supply Network, Is Dead
description: Aaron Kellner, who helped to create a reliable blood-supply system for transfusions for much of the New York region, died yesterday at his Upper East Side home. He was 78.

title: Luis Rivera, a Dancer And Troupe Head, 54
description: Luis Rivera, a Spanish dancer and company director, died on Wednesday at St. Vincent's Hospital in Manhattan. He was 54 years old.

title: Exiting Cabinet Member Leading China Trip
description: As many as three dozen political appointees who will leave office next month will first visit Beijing when Commerce Secretary Barbara H. Franklin flies there next week on a $13,000-an-hour Air Force jet, Government and industry officials said.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ABLE TELECOM HOLDING CORP., Deerfield Beach, Fla., announced that Able Telcom's Venezuelan subsidiaries had received contracts to expand their service work for Cantv into Maracaibo and Valencia. BALL CORP., Muncie, Ind., announced that its Airlink satellite communication high-gain antenna subsystem had been selected by British Airways for its fleet of 30 Boeing 777 aircraft. The Ball Airlink antenna will be integrated with the Collins Avionics Satcom 906 system consisting of the satellite data unit and high-power amplifer unit. WISCONSIN PHARMACAL CO., announced that the obstetrics and gynecology devices panel of the Food and Drug Administration yesterday unanimously recommended that its Reality female condom be approved by the F.D.A. Reality will be the first of a new class of products approved by the F.D.A. to help prevent the spread of AIDS.

title: ASA Ltd.  reports earnings for Year As of Nov 30
description: Net income represented net investment income.Total net assets as of Nov. 30 for the latest year was $ 292,921,382, or $ 30.51 a share, compared to $ 429,168,241, or $ 44.71 a share, in the year-earlier period.

title: THE STORM'S HAVOC: New Jersey; Swamped and Powerless, Thousands Flee Shoreline
description: Thousands of people were evacuated today -- by police boats, by National Guard trucks, and, in one case, by surfboard -- as a wind-driven storm forced evacuations in an estimated 20 towns along the New Jersey coast.

title: Terreri Keeps Penguins on the Short End
description: The strong and swift Penguins kept jamming the net against Chris Terreri tonight, but the Devils' diminutive goaltender held his ground marvelously, flopping from side to side and denying the defending Stanley Cup champions time and again.

title: THE STORM'S HAVOC: The Overview; STORM LASHES NEW YORK REGION WITH RAIN, GALES AND FLOODING
description: Howling like Valkyries on a rampage, a huge prewinter storm packing gusts up to 90 miles an hour and enough rain to submerge a small state struck the New York metropolitan region yesterday. It crippled transportation, commerce and education, flooded wide areas, knocked out power to hundreds of thousands of homes, damaged thousands of buildings and disrupted the lives of millions of people.

title: Knicks' 2 Big Questions: Intensity and Smith
description: With or without Charles Smith, who has a sprained right ankle, the Knicks will try to recover from their first home loss of the season when they play host to the Detroit Pistons tonight.

title: Maldonado to Cubs
description: The Chicago Cubs signed outfielder CANDY MALDONADO to a two-year contract. Financial terms of the contract were not disclosed, but the Cubs have an option for a third year.

title: Charge in Weinberger Case That Caused Furor Before Election Is Thrown Out
description: A Federal district judge today threw out a one-count indictment that was brought against former Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger four days before the Presidential election and created an uproar when Republicans asserted that it had contributed to President Bush's defeat.

title: European Leaders Try to Salvage Treaty on Unity
description: European Community leaders struggled today to restore the lost momentum of the drive to closer unity, which was stalled when Denmark rejected a treaty on political and monetary union this summer, and hoped to find a way out of the impasse on Saturday.

title: At Fire-Scarred Church, Hopes, but No Decisions
description: No Masses were celebrated yesterday at the Church of St. Agnes in mid-Manhattan, but dozens of worshipers gathered outside anyway, peering out from under umbrellas at their fire-ravaged sanctuary, trying to glimpse the future.

title: Clinton Widens His Circle, Naming 4 Social Activists
description: President-elect Bill Clinton today broadened the political and ideological profile of his emerging Administration, choosing three academics and an environmentalist known for strong advocacy of social causes.

title: Challenger Steps Up Attack on Serbian Leader
description: Promising peace and prosperity, the Prime Minister of Yugoslavia brought his campaign to oust Serbia's hard-line nationalist President to this republic's industrial heartland today, trying to build support in a onetime stronghold of the President that has been laid waste by economic decline and international sanctions.

title: THE TRANSITION: Woman in the News; Emphasis On Action: Donna Edna Shalala
description: Dr. Donna E. Shalala, an energetic, exuberant administrator who has never been shy about trumpeting her considerable achievements, is now going to tackle two of the most intractable problems in American society: health care and welfare.

title: Survey Doubles Hurricane Cost Estimate
description: One of the nation's top insurance rating agencies said yesterday that it expected insured losses from Hurricane Andrew eventually to reach $15 billion to $16.5 billion, more than twice the industry's original estimates.

title: The School Board's Confusing Signals
description: New York City's Central Board of Education has sent a muddled signal to combatants in the battle over a multicultural curriculum.

title: In a First, Duke U. Names a Woman President
description: Breaking with tradition, Duke University yesterday named one of the most prominent women in American higher education, Nannerl Overholser Keohane, the president of Wellesley College, as its next president.

title: More on the Storm
description: Other reports on the storm in the New York region and its aftermath are on pages 25-28.

title: Doll Gives Identity to Down Syndrome Children
description: Diana Zernone's new doll is the first she's ever had that looks like her: The 14-year-old New City girl has Down syndrome, and so does Dolly Downs, a pigtailed blonde who went on the market last week, assembled by retarded and developmentally disabled workers at Camp Venture Inc.

title: Japan's Cabinet Is Shuffled Under Harsh New Spotlight
description: Struggling to quash a scandal that is threatening his tenure in office, Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa replaced a number of Cabinet members and top officials of the governing party today. But he found his effort overshadowed by damaging new disclosures and factional infighting.

title: A Homeowner Challenges an Inflated Tax Assessment, and Wins
description: In December 1990, John Castellano, 37, bought a two-bedroom townhouse condominium in Verona, N.J., for $160,000. He is a partner in the real estate development company that built the condominium complex.

title: INSIDE
description: 2 Somalis Reach a Truce Leaders of two powerful Somali factions agreed to halt hostilities and remove a dividing line in the capital. But their pact had no immediate effect on fighting elsewhere. Page 6. Iran-Contra Charge Dropped

title: Why Political Democracy Hurts Russia's Economic Freedom
description: To the Editor:

title: School Costs Exceed the State Average by 35%, Study Shows
description: Administrative costs for Long Island school districts are 35 percent higher than the state average and 65 percent higher than in New York City, according to a report by two State Senators. In addition, the report said, the number of Long Island school officials making $70,000 or more doubled in the last two years.

title: Observer; Weave Me No Spell
description: The papers and the television keep repeating "storybook marriage." Eleven years ago with the same witless monotony they kept repeating "fairy-tale wedding."

title: Greenwich Financial reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $ 725,000, or 30 cents a share, from cumulative effect on prior periods of an accounting change.

title: Insurance Futures Begin Trading
description: When officials at the Chicago Board of Trade hammered a bell to inaugurate trading in insurance futures contracts at 10 A.M. today, the 40 or so men in the new pit acted less like traders than bewildered baseball outfielders hoping someone else would grab the fly ball about to fall between them.

title: Wise Stores reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net lossResults are in Canadian dollars.

title: Comptronix Dismisses Chief In Bogus-Earnings Scandal
description: The Comptronix Corporation dismissed its chairman and chief executive yesterday and said it expected to sue him for routinely and illegally inflating the company's profits for more than three years.

title: 2 Somali Factional Leaders Pledge to End the Fighting
description: The leaders of the two most powerful Somali factions met here today under the auspices of the United States and pledged to cease hostilities immediately.

title: Decision Time For Tax Planners
description: Some simple steps taken before the yuear ends could bring big savings on 1992 and 1993 returns. Page 36. [ Drawing ]

title: Orioles Get Reynolds
description: Second baseman HAROLD REYNOLDS yesterday agreed to a one-year, $1.65 million contract with the Baltimore Orioles, who in turn placed BILL RIPKEN on unconditional-release waivers.

title: Economic Recovery Gaining Momentum
description: Retail sales rose for the fifth straight month in November and consumers spent at a much faster pace in October than previously estimated, the Government reported yesterday. Other figures showed a hefty rise in average weekly earnings last month and another jump in consumer confidence in early December.

title: Marlins Woo Santiago
description: Catcher BENITO SANTIAGO is close to signing a $3.8 million, one-year contract with the Florida Marlins, his family said yesteday.

title: William Sonenshine, Lawyer, 63
description: William Sonenshine, a New York criminal defense lawyer until his retirement in 1985, died yesterday at North Ridge Hospital in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. He was 63 and lived in Pompano Beach, Fla.

title: Tapping the Rich May Prove Tricky
description: As Bill Clinton's new economic team considers how best to turn his campaign promises on taxes into legislative proposals, it may feel the ground shifting.

title: Novell Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: THE STORM'S HAVOC: Westchester; Day of Falling Limbs, Power Failures and Phone Disruptions
description: A combination of high winds and falling limbs summed up the problems of today's storm for Westchester County residents.

title: Manuel Noriega, Prisoner of War
description: Puppet, dictator, informant, racketeer, convicted felon, and now the only prisoner of war in United States custody. That's the career path of Manuel Noriega, whose P.O.W. status was certified this week by the judge who sentenced him to 40 years in Federal prison.

title: National Semiconductor reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 29
description: b-Included a pre-tax gain of $ 31.7 million for patent licensing fees as a result of the company's ongoing intellectual property licensing activities; $ 4.5 million in legal expense accruals in connection with a tax dispute scheduled for trial in the U.S. Tax Court on Feb. 1, 1993; and an accrual of $ 9.1 million representing the costs of centralizing sales and logistics facilities within the company's international business regions.c-Net loss and included a $ 149.3 million charge for restructuring of operations taken in the first quarter.

title: Aid Officials in Somalia Take an Optimistic View
description: As the American-led military operation to help Somalis began three days ago, officials of Western aid agencies viewed it with skepticism. But now, their attitude has switched to optimism and, for some, downright relief.

title: 6 Children and 10 Abortions in 15 Years
description: Liana said, "I want to be the first," and she was. Three women -- Liana, a cousin and a friend -- had come from Batumi on the Black Sea to Kutaisi, Georgia's second largest city. They wanted an operation that would enable them to stop having children. We Americans were there to train surgeons to do the half-hour operation. We had been invited by the Zhordania Institute of Human Reproduction, a medical training institution in Tbilisi.

title: A Bad Bet for Sports
description: The gambling industry's constant craving for broader license -- this time for sports betting -- faces a crucial test next week in New Jersey. The State Senate votes on a bill to let Atlantic City casinos make book on sports. That would be bad for sports, for bettors and for the state.

title: N.H.L. Goes to the Hoop for First Commissioner
description: The National Hockey League continued its expansive theme today by electing Gary Bettman as its first commissioner.

title: Pacific Telesis Plans to Split in Two
description: The Pacific Telesis Group, whose markets for telephone services are the largest in the country, said yesterday that its board had unanimously voted to split the huge California-based carrier into a $9 billion traditional-telephone company and a nearly $1 billion wireless-phone company.

title: Environmental Truce Clears Smoke in Rice Fields
description: It is nearly winter in the wide, fertile valley of the Sacramento River in Northern California, a time when the poplars and willows turn golden and the rice farmers normally send up a ghastly pall of smoke over the valley as they burn the stubble of last season's crop.

title: Cabre Exploration reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Henry Baldwin, 96, A Research Forester And an Early Skier
description: Henry Ives Baldwin, a retired research forester and naturalist who schussed the New England mountains long before skiing became fashionable, died on Thursday at the Medical Center at Princeton, N.J. He was 96.

title: Carl Karcher Enterprises reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 2
description: The company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

description: Some of yesterday's transportation disruptions were expected to continue today. Here's the status as of late last night. Airports: La Guardia: Expected to open at noon. For information on specific flights, call the airline, or general airport information: 718-476-5000

title: Review/Performance Art; A Dream World Where Passion Rules
description: "I want to take you swimming in the dark," David Cale intones seductively, with a hint of menace. "It's something you would never do. It's something you would like to do."

title: Big Jumps Are Posted For Sales
description: Reinvigorated shoppers drove up retail sales in November for the fifth straight month and spent at a much faster pace in October than previously estimated, the Government said today.

title: THE STORM'S HAVOC: Scenes; A Day the Sea Was More Than Just a View
description: Armand DeRose spent his day in Huntington, L.I., soaked to the bone yesterday, struggling to lash down 300 boats at the West Shore Marina so that they would not bob off in the crazy, wavy seas like so much flotsam.

title: Another Storm For Torretta To Weather
description: After everything that Gino Torretta and his University of Miami teammates have endured in their perfect football season, it could not come as a shock that the storm that has battered the Northeast might force the Hurricane quarterback to accept a Heisman Trophy long distance.

title: Clinton Plans Early Meeting With Mexico's Leader
description: President-Elect Bill Clinton has told Democratic members of Congress that he plans to meet with President Carlos Salinas de Gortari of Mexico, quite possibly before Inauguration Day.

description: BOSTON (AP) -- Derrick McKey (23 points) and Gary Payton (22) helped Seattle survive Boston's fourth-quarter comeback and snap a six-game losing streak against the Celtics. Pistons 107, Cavaliers 103

description: TAKING STOCK OF THE STORM'S HAVOC: DAMAGE, FLOODING, DISRUPTIONS

title: THE STORM'S HAVOC: New York City; For One Stormy Day, New York Was Not for the Blase
description: Drenched and befuddled, New Yorkers yesterday sloshed through puddles bordering on small lakes, dodged shattered windows and exploded umbrellas, watched their homes and businesses rudely invaded by water and sullenly improvised on their day as the rains kept tumbling down. If you wanted to buy a Christmas tree, you needed a fishing rod.

title: Dart Group reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Included pretax gain from partial settlement of insurance claims for Trak Auto of $ 205,000 in the quarter and $ 1,598,000 in the 9 months, and the quarter also included an extraordinary loss of $ 388,000, which included a gain of $ 497,000, or 27 cents a share, net of minority interest, from the tax effect of a net operating loss carryforward for Trak Auto; and a loss of $ 885,000 from the early redemption of the company's remaining debentures.c-After an extraordinary loss from reacquisition of debentures of $ 323,000 in the quarter and 9 months.The company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: Review/Jazz; An Adventurous Farewell
description: The last piece of the American Jazz Orchestra's last concert, at Cooper Union on Thursday night, wasn't by David Murray, who was the guest composer, saxophonist and conductor. It was Jimmy Lunceford's "Lunceford Special," but its performance showed exactly how distinct Mr. Murray's work has become.

title: Violence Is Abating in India; Death Toll Continues to Rise
description: The violence that swept through towns across India all week appeared to be abating today, although the death toll in Hindu-Muslim clashes and in battles with security troops rose past 1,050.

title: Sports of The Times; Casting The First Stone
description: I FIRST met Arthur Triche about seven years ago at the National Sports Festival in Baton Rouge, La.

title: THE STORM'S HAVOC: Connecticut; A Vise of Coastal Flooding And a Blanketing Snowfall
description: A surging tide flooded coastal areas from Greenwich to East Haven today, sparing neither mansion nor beach cottage as Connecticut was hit by a storm that cut electricity to 63,000 homes.

title: Clinton's Choice of Reich Hints at a Stepped-Up Role for Labor Department
description: President-elect Bill Clinton's choice for Labor Secretary, Robert B. Reich, brings a detailed and perhaps controversial agenda to an agency that has long been an administrative backwater.

title: Next Stop for Nets Is Home of the True Test
description: As rain and wind whipped up a frenzy in New York, the Nets quietly packed their belongings and took off for Chicago, leaving a natural storm and heading into a man-made one.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about President-elect Bill Clinton's selection of his top economic officials rendered the name of his choice for deputy budget director incorrectly in some copies. She is Alice M. Rivlin. An accompanying article about the Office of Management and Budget misstated her alma mater. It is Bryn Mawr College, not Radcliffe; she received her Ph.D. from Radcliffe.

title: Fernandez and Board in Queens Exchange Invitations to Meet on Curriculum
description: New York City's Schools Chancellor, Joseph A. Fernandez, yesterday offered the members of a defiant school board in Queens more time to arrange a meeting with him to try to resolve their long, bitter dispute over a curriculum that teaches first graders to respect and appreciate gay people.

title: The Time for Tax Planning Is Right Now
description: Time is short, but there are still two weeks and a few days left in 1992 to take steps to reduce this year's taxes and, just as important, to lay the personal financial foundations for 1993.

title: G.M. DELAYS PRODUCTION OF ELECTRIC CAR
description: The General Motors Corporation has indefinitely delayed commercial production of its much publicized electric car, previously scheduled to begin in 1995.

title: Berlin Journal; A Look Into the Violent World of a Young Neo-Nazi
description: Neighbors describe Michael Peters as a school dropout who rarely worked, was often drunk and liked to give loud parties at his four-room apartment in the placid western German village of Gudow.

title: Ed Krause, 79, the 'True Legend' of Notre Dame
description: Ed (Moose) Krause, the Notre Dame official who played football under Knute Rockne and coached under Frank Leahy before succeeding him as athletic director in 1949, died Thursday night after delivering a round of his customary cheer at the athletic department's annual Christmas party.

title: British Press Will Keep Up Royal Chase
description: When he announced in the House of Commons on Wednesday that the Prince and Princess of Wales were separating, Prime Minister John Major said in earnest tones and to roars of approval from his colleagues in Parliament that he hoped the news media would now afford the royal family some privacy.

title: Man Beaten in Crown Hts. Resurfaces
description: Ralph Nimmons, the missing man at the center of the Crown Heights beating case, reappeared yesterday at the side of his lawyer and the Rev. Al Sharpton. But the two men said Mr. Nimmons would not testify to a Brooklyn grand jury, and they repeated their demand that Gov. Mario M. Cuomo appoint a special prosecutor to take over the case.

title: Police Cadet Shot In Traffic Dispute
description: A New York City police cadet was shot and critically wounded during a fight following a traffic accident in Brooklyn last night, the police said.

title: T.W.A. SEES STOCK AS WORTHLESS UNDER BANKRUPTCY
description: T.W.A. said yesterday that its preferred and common stock would become worthless under a proposed bankruptcy reorganization. The disclosure came in an announcement by the Trans World Airlines Corporation that it had asked a Federal bankruptcy court to approve this week's settlement among T.W.A., the Government's Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation, and Carl C. Icahn, the airline's owner.

title: Trak Auto Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Included pretax unusual gains of $ 205,000 in the quarter and $ 1,598,000 in the 9 months from the partial settlement of insurance claims related to losses incurred in the Los Angeles riots. The 9 months also included an extraordinary credit of $ 727,000, or 12 cents a share, from net operating loss carryforward.The company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: Yankees And Boggs Pursuing Each Other
description: Wade Boggs playing for the Yankees? Could one of the hated members of the Red Sox make the switch from Boston to the Bronx? According to Alan Nero, Boggs's agent, the possibility is strong, and an answer from the Yankees about signing the free-agent third baseman could come as early as today.

description: Transportation officials blamed an almost freakish convergence of events for leaving hundreds of thousands of commuters delayed or stranded yesterday. They described the disruptions as the worst they could recall from a single storm.

The 1992 and 1991 pro forma results of operations reflected the effects of the initial public offering and the related refinancing.Pro forma 1991 results also reflected the effects of the acquisition of Occidental Life Insurance Co., consummated on Oct. 24, 1991, as if the acquisition had occurred on Jan. 1, 1991.Revenue represented total revenues.

title: Parole Order Faces Review By the State
description: A man convicted of manslaughter in the explosive Howard Beach racial attack in Queens has been granted parole even though he has served less than three years of his five-year minimum prison sentence, and a state official said yesterday that the parole decision would be reviewed.

title: CHRONICLE
description: JOSIE NATORI, the founder and president of the lingerie and fashion company that bears her name, gets lots of invitations, especially at this time of year, so nothing seemed exceptional to her about one that arrived in her office the other day.

title: It Was Not a Hurricane, But a Heck of an Impostor
description: The storm that soaked and battered the New York area yesterday looked and acted much like a hurricane. But it was really a northeaster -- a winter storm with winds off the Atlantic.

description: Gov. Jim Florio received the recommendations of his Advisory Council on AIDS today, then left immediately to assess storm damage reports while panel members defended such recommendations as providing condoms to all high school students and prison inmates.

description: A woman shopping in a Korean grocery store in Flatbush, Brooklyn, was harassed and struck by two store workers after they accused her of trying to steal a bottle of juice, the police said yesterday.

title: Climbing His Way Back, With Help From Neediest
description: One day Larry K. was wearing expensive suits, hatching deals for a prominent brokerage firm and dating a woman he loved. The next day he woke up in a mental hospital and his life began a seven-year plunge that left him an angry and confused man cut off from family and friends.

title: Pentagon Says Killing of 2 Somalis May Have Been Accidental
description: One day after French and American troops shot and killed two Somalis in the belief that the Somalis were trying to run a roadblock in Mogadishu, the Pentagon said today that the episode might have been an accident.

title: Robb to Go Before Jury Again, Lawyers Say
description: Senator Charles S. Robb has asked for a second opportunity to testify before a Federal grand jury that is investigating whether he violated electronic eavesdropping laws, lawyers familiar with the case said today.

description: Today, after a labyrinthian process that involved a trade with the Edmonton Oilers, a pair of contract negotiations and some little-known and little-understood National Hockey regulations, Kevin Lowe became a Ranger.

description: Fierce competition for mutual fund investors is leading to lower sales charges.

description: University of Washington players are being investigated by the United States Secret Service in connection with the use of cellular phones altered to avoid billing, newspapers in Washington state reported yesterday.

description: President-elect Bill Clinton offered indirect criticism of President Bush's foreign policy today, nudging the Administration toward a new United Nations resolution enforcing the ban on Serbian flights over Bosnia and Herzegovina.

title: Islanders' Ferraro Breaks Leg
description: The Islanders, already limping along in last place in their division, absorbed a dual loss Thursday night in Chicago. The team not only squandered a 3-2 third-period lead in a 5-3 defeat, but in the second period, veteran center Ray Ferraro took a tumble into the boards that resulted in a fractured right leg.

description: Two months ago a Pennsylvania Supreme Court justice was publicly reprimanded by his colleagues for violating judicial ethics by privately advising a trial judge about a pending case.

title: Bridge
description: If one searched the world for a club game where the stakes and the quality of play were both very high indeed, one would probably end up at the Regency Whist Club in Manhattan. A game there, virtually a club within a club, continues a tradition established at the Cavendish Club, whose demise is still lamented by New York experts.

title: Corrections
description: Excerpts yesterday from President-elect Bill Clinton's news conference omitted parts of two sentences in some copies. Introducing Representative Leon E. Panetta, Mr. Clinton said, "As director of the Office of Management and Budget, Congressman Leon Panetta will bring integrity to this critical office and restore the confidence of the American people and their elected representatives that O.M.B. is shooting straight with the Congress and shooting straight with the American people, and doing its best to help us not only to have a responsible budget but to manage the massive American Government in a different and better way than ever before." Introducing Robert E. Rubin, Mr. Clinton said, "Finally, I have asked Robert Rubin to serve as assistant to the President for economic policy, and to help to coordinate and to direct our new Economic Council."

title: New Start for an Old Opera in Berlin
description: On Dec. 7, 1942, the Berlin State Opera celebrated its 200th anniversary. It cannot have been an altogether festive occasion. Germany was locked into a murderous war, which prescient observers knew it would lose. The historic opera house had been destroyed by Allied bombs the year before but rebuilt in record time (it was to be destroyed again in 1945).

title: Heather's Mommies vs. Heather's Parents
description: Pluralism means that groups of people who disagree on questions of profound importance agree not to use those differences as excuses for civil wars or uncivil behavior. It means we "agree to disagree," to "live and let live," even though we live differently. New Yorkers, who have long lived in one of the most culturally and ethnically diverse spots on earth, were for many years masters of pluralism.
