title: Selden D. Bacon, 84, Professor and Expert On Alcohol Abuse
description: Prof. Selden Daskam Bacon, former director of the Center of Alcohol Studies at Rutgers University, died Sunday in Martha's Vineyard, Mass., where he had retired. He was 84.

title: The City's Exuberant Ceramic Facades
description: THE traditional image of Paris, with its facades of dignified stone, begins to change with careful exploration of the city's architecture. Among the many limestone buildings are a remarkable variety and number of ceramic facades -- more than 100. Fired and glazed ceramic forms, ranging from half-dollar-sized pellets to two-ton sculptured figures, can be found on buildings in nearly every arrondissement. Although they provide the city with a tremendous richness of color, texture and imagery, these structures tend to escape visitors' notice.

title: In Love Again (This Time a Weird Fern)
description: "YOU don't want a staghorn fern," Byron Martin said. "They need a lot of light and you have to soak them in the bathtub twice a week."

title: Marlo C. Pfister, Jeffrey Cadeddu
description: Marilyn M. Thorpe of New Orleans and Gerrit A. Pfister of Gaillard, France, have announced March wedding plans for their daughter, Marlo Colette Pfister, and Jeffrey Anthony Cadeddu, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Cadeddu of Plandome, L.I.

title: Rights Report Faults Officials in Ethnic Strife
description: The upsurge in ethnic violence since the collapse of the Soviet Union stems as much from deliberate governmental policies as it does from age-old racial, religious and national antagonism, Human Rights Watch said this week in its annual report.

title: Childhood Malapropism
description: To the Editor:

title: Rape After Rape After Rape
description: What is happening in Bosnia and Herzegovina to Muslim and Croatian women seems unprecedented in the history of war crimes. Women are raped by Serbian soldiers in an organized and systematic way, as a planned crime to destroy a whole Muslim population, to destroy a society's cultural, traditional and religious integrity.

title: Agent of Influence
description: THE DARK SIDE OF POWER

title: JERSEYANA
description: ON a winter day in 1954, a workman dredging a pond in Sussex County came upon the enormous, grinning skull of some monstrous animal. The owner of the pond, Gus Ohberg, called the police, who called the New Jersey State Museum in Trenton. After weeks of digging, scientists and volunteers unearthed the skeleton of a mastodon from the muck at the bottom of the pond.

title: Data Bank/December 13, 1992
Apartheid's Endgame
description: THIS DAY AND AGE

title: The Grooves. The Box. Ribbon-Ready.
description: Boxed sets have become a holiday gift-giving staple. Here are some new choices for this season. Prices are suggested retail. 'Hitsville U.S.A.: The Motown Singles Collection' Motown 3746336312; four CD's ($49.98) or cassettes ($39.98).

title: Arguments for Islam
description: ISLAM AND DEMOCRACY

title: MOST LIKELY TO SUCCEED
description: No offense to Alessandra Stanley, or to Frank Aller, who sounds as if he must have been quite special, but if contacts weren't everything in America, he'd be just another suicide case, remembered by only those who loved him. As it turns out, though, Frank Aller has become a front-page "star."

title: Devils' Weekend Isn't Wild Enough
description: The Devils, seeking a second victory in two nights over the Penguins, got off to a three-goal lead tonight. But they were foiled by an unlikely source -- the veteran wing Troy Loney, who scored his first two goals of the season, including the game-winner on a disputed call.

title: String of Arsons Terrorizes a Small Community
description: In this quiet rural community, people are used to leaving their doors unlocked, exchanging gossip at the recycling station and gathering for barbecues on summer afternoons. They are also getting used to something else: living in fear of arson.

title: Corrections
description: A report in Styles of The Times last Sunday about the wedding of Carolyn L. Goodman and Michael J. Pianin was published prematurely. They were married last evening.

title: Rules for Drivers Entering Mexico
description: DRIVING into Mexico has become more complicated in recent years. There are the stringent border controls created to keep cars, including stolen ones, from being driven into Mexico for illegal sale. There are persistent concerns about safety and gasoline supply on some roads, and finally, there are the weekday driving restrictions that Mexico City, facing acute pollution, has applied.

title: Will I Be Famous? Will I Be Rich?
description: NANCY STARK

title: QE2 Accident
description: To the Editor: Like Kathleen Pavelec (Letters, Oct. 27), my father and I were passengers on the ill-fated QE2 voyage of Aug. 7. And, like Ms. Pavelec and her son, we were left on the ship all day.

title: Newly Selected Chief of Staff Is Widely Known for Loyalty
description: Almost everyone, it seems, who has ever known Thomas F. McLarty 3d says the same thing about him.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE TURNING POINTThe Abstract Expressionists andthe Transformation of American Art.By April Kingsley.Simon & Schuster, $30.

title: Roger Nettler and Michelle Duke
description: Michelle Helene Duke, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jack F. Duke of Forest Hills, Queens, was married last evening to Roger Lawrence Nettler, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul T. Nettler of Greenvale, L.I. Rabbi Aaron M. Petuchowski performed the ceremony at Temple Sinai in Roslyn Heights, L.I.

title: Wearing Fur, Walking Fur
description: Well-dressed and groomed dogs accompanied by stylishly dressed owners added panache to the Madison Avenue Christmas for Children Fund promenade last Sunday.

title: Music To Many Ears
description: To the Editor:

title: For NBC, Hard Times and Miscues
description: YOU thought the Queen of England had it bad this year? Look at what happened to NBC, the king of television just three years ago.

title: Where the Menu Crisscrosses the Map
description: WHEN the restaurant called Gates first opened its wrought-iron doors in New Canaan in 1979, you could count the restaurants in town on one hand with fingers to spare. Gates became an instant hit, based on a combination of appealing dishes, inviting atmosphere and friendly staff. Today one block of Forest Street and the parallel block on Main Street constitute practically a restaurant row.

title: Philipp C. Jung, Set Designer, 43
description: Philipp C. Jung, a set designer for dozens of theater, opera, dance and film productions, died on Thursday at a hospital in San Luis Obispo, Calif., where he lived. He was 43.

title: Packing
description: To the Editor: How much and what to pack depends, for me, on the method of travel. I was a tank commander in the U.S. Army in Germany for several years. When we were sent on a three-day alert, I packed for three weeks: almost 100 pounds of dry underwear, socks, uniforms, books, cigarettes and snack food. Sometimes it was an unused load to carry, sometimes I had the only clean, dry socks in our battalion.

title: Gehry's Disney Hall: A Matterhorn for Music
description: Walt Disney is a trademark. Walt Disney is an empire. But Walt Disney is also the name of a popular American artist whose subject was enchantment. A pumpkin grows into a coach. A kiss breaks the spell. Trick photography makes the bud blossom. Disney's enchantment was America's. His images of wonder were metaphors for a nation that, in his time, was as blessed as any magic kingdom. Then, like American moral authority, the Disney magic waned. The padded Mickeys, the bloated theme parks, the denatured wholesomeness came to seem like desperate overcompensations for curdled American innocence.

title: Carrie Goodman, Michael Pianin
description: Carolyn L. Goodman, a daughter of Dr. Richard Goodman of Stony Brook, L.I., and the late Florence L. Goodman, was married last evening to Michael J. Pianin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Pianin of West Hartford, Conn. Rabbi Robert Marcus officiated at the Muttontown Club in Brookville, L.I.

title:
OUT THERE: LONDON;
Outbreak of Dice Fever
description: THERE'S been a whole lot of shaking going on in London since a tournament recently focused attention on a centuries-old South American dice game that has been re-invented for the 1990's by a British entrepreneur.

title: FIGHTING IN INDIA APPEARS TO SLOW
description: After a week of savage sectarian rioting in dozens of cities and towns set off by the demolition of a 16th-century mosque by Hindu militants last Sunday, India struggled toward calm today, with far fewer reports of deaths and injuries trickling into the capital.

title: 'The Change'
description: To the Editor:

title: Protector of the Prominent
description: AS a prosecutor years ago, Charles A. Stillman gained a reputation as a tough, no-nonsense lawyer who put many white-collar criminals behind bars.

title: POSTURING
description: I am writing to make a modest proposal about irony and wit in contemporary writing. From my position as one of the bozos referred to in Paul Taylor's About Men column "Posturing" (Oct. 25), perhaps I can shed some light on what seems to be a misapprehension of the artist's process, and product. In art, as on 14th Street, caveat emptor. A writer's voice is a subtle subject for study, providing a subtext, through irony, that seems to have been missed by one of your readers (Letters, Nov. 5).

title: Public & Private; 21 Going on 6
description: None of it makes sense without subtraction.

title: The Cold Peace
description: THE PORCUPINE By Julian Barnes. 138 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $17.

title: Sailing Program for the Disabled
description: Americans with disabilities may learn to sail next year while exploring the Netherlands aboard a double-masted clipper ship. Four departures are scheduled for a 13-day vacation on the Lutgerdina, a 95-year-old sailboat refitted with hydraulic steering, an electronic speaking device to instruct blind helmsmen and navigational charts in Braille. It also has adapted showers and toilets for wheelchairs and an elevator.

title: Larry Frankini and Gita Khilnani
description: Dr. Gita Monica Khilnani, the daughter of Lia D. Khilnani of Scarsdale, N.Y., and the late Dr. Mansho T. Khilnani, was married yesterday to Dr. Larry Andrew Frankini, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Oronzo P. Frankini of Flushing, Queens. Msgr. Lawrence McAllister performed the ceremony at St. Andrew Avellino Roman Catholic Church in Flushing.

title: Fernandez and His Battles: Can an Innovator Be Happy in New York?
description: Three years ago, Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez charged into New York City with a virtual mandate to rouse a slumbering system in which corruption, incompetence and mediocrity flourished.

title:
MUSIC;
Roberta Peters in an AIDS Benefit
description: THE loss of two accompanists to AIDS within three years has prompted the soprano Roberta Peters to donate her services, she said, for a benefit concert in New Brunswick with the New York City Gay Men's Chorus.

title: Reaching Beyond Personal Slurs to Public Policy
description: Marge Schott's racial and ethnic slurs were reprehensible, and all of baseball's owners must act swiftly to condemn her remarks and, despite her lukewarm apology last week, impose a serious sanction. The owners should not expect to be praised for this. It is neither courageous nor controversial to condemn Schott's explicit racism. It is a minimum action we have a right to expect from the sport.

title: We Need a Slimmer but Still Capable Air Force; Dangerous Isolation
description: To the Editor:

title: SURFACING
description: PRIDE -- Black colleges' sweatshirts: It's an ethnic pride thing among young African-Americans, whether they went to the schools or not. Recent sighting: the rap impresario Russell Simmons, who attended City College, wearing a Grambling sweatshirt on the cover of Black Enterprise. CHARITY -- Donating frequent-flier miles: Seriously ill children hoping to realize a special wish, disabled athletes and multiple-sclerosis patients are among those who benefit from programs offered by American Airlines and Continental Airlines. TOYS -- Rollerblading dolls: California Roller Baby (Tyco) and Baby Rollerblade (Mattel) are among the season's hottest toys.

title: Lincoln Square
description: To the Editor:

title: Orlando's Success Raises Questions
description: THE Fall National Championships of the American Contract Bridge League, which ended two weeks ago in Orlando, Fla., proved to be the biggest in the 64-year history of the tournament. In 10 days, there were 14,980 tables in play, beating the record set in Anaheim, Calif., five years earlier by 1,032 tables.

title: Jaruzelski Faces Accusers, or Is It Vice Versa?
description: Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, the last Communist leader of Poland, sits impassively at the head of a long wooden table in Parliament. Arrayed behind him are the balding and gray-haired Communists who, on Dec. 13, 1981, crushed the Solidarity movement with a show of force they called martial law.

title: Barri L. Katz and Michael J. Stryer
description: Dr. Barri Lynn Katz, a child psychiatrist, was married last evening to Michael Jonathan Stryer, a business executive. Rabbi Marc Disick officiated at Tappan Hill in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: Wall Street; Bill Donoghue's Electronic Tarring
description: FINANCIAL experts get away with lots of bogus claims and useless predictions in both their own publications and the media in general. But in one relatively new forum the pros are being kept a bit more honest than usual.

title: Angela Gomez, Wayne Sinhart
description: THE REV. WILLIAM G. KALAIDJIAN, the pastor of the Bedford Park Congregational Church for the last 39 years, is one of the best-known clergymen in the Bronx. People call him "Mr. Bronx," "Reverend Bill" and "the good-vibes pastor."

title: APPLYING YOURSELF
description: If the purpose of the Hers column is to articulate the human condition and, perhaps, make a connection between people, then Nancy Ring's article succeeded, at least in my case, in a most unusual way.

title:
THEATER;
This Director Prefers to Be Upstaged
description: James Nicola, artistic director of the New York Theater Workshop, is uncomfortable talking about himself. He will speak passionately about the plays of Caryl Churchill, say, but asked why a pig mailbox, a pig mug and a dozen or so other porcine tchotchkes adorn his Times Square office, and his response is terse: "I like pigs." Colleagues describe his wicked sense of humor -- he evidently likes to make anagrams of people's names, turning them into naughty epithets -- but during a recent interview he remained private and serious. It is more important, he says, that his theater be known than himself.

title: Serial Killers Claim Movies As Their Prey
description: THEY EMERGED FROM the shadows to tap into our deepest fears and nightmares. Monsters of the New Age, they are immune to deterrents like garlic, wolfbane, crucifixes, silver bullets and sharpened stakes. Their relentless horror is real, and without apparent motive. Meet the serial killer -- popular culture's villain of the 1990's.

title: The Benefit Rediscovered
description: American Museum of Natural History explores the known, Dec. 8.

title: GARDENING
description: THERE is a word in the plant kingdom that gardeners will have to learn. It is "dioecious," a word rooted in Greek which means two households. For a gardener, the term means that two will have to be planted, that is, a male plant and a female plant since the male and female flowers are borne by different plants.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: HANG TIME Days and Dreams With Michael Jordan. By Bob Greene. Doubleday, $22.50.

title: Silicon Valley's Laugh Man
description: "I'M the Bill Gates of computer culture," says Jeff Armstrong, who's been satirizing the Microsoft chairman and lesser members of the industry for six years as one of the world's first high-tech comedians.

title:
HERS;
The Wedding Gift
description: ARM IN ARM, WE walked numbly down the street. It was a gray day . . . Tuesday, March 10, 1992. Christian turned to me. "Look," he said. "Here we are on Madison Avenue and 75th Street." He looked at his watch. "It's 4:25 in the afternoon." He took both my shoulders in his hands. "Will you marry me? I'm asking you now."

title: William Peterson, 98, A Legislator, Is Dead
description: William R. Peterson, a retired businessman, Connecticut legislator and civic leader, died on Friday in a nursing home in Portland, Conn. He was 98 and had lived on a farm in Portland.

title: Debating Whether 'Yes' Means 'No'; Glen Ridge Sex Assault Trial Tests the Defense of Consent
description: A 17-year-old girl follows a group of teen-age boys into the basement of a suburban home, removes her clothes and, without protest, participates in an afternoon of sexual stunts while the boys goad her on. When it is over, she dresses and lingers in the house, hoping someone will ask her out on a date.

title: The Chancellor's Answer
description: Excerpts from the proposed revisions of the New York City teachers' guide, "Children of the Rainbow."

title: Ms. Johnson, Andrew Tennant
description: Bruce A. Johnson of Dorset, Vt., has announced February wedding plans for his daughter, Sharon Kay Johnson, and Andrew Wellman Tennant, a son of Donald and Barbara Tennant of Carlsbad, Calif.

title: Barely Gone, 80's Are Back
description: AN odd thing happened last summer. Members of the so-called MTV generation who supported Gov. Bill Clinton and were in favor of abortion rights got sentimental when former President Ronald Reagan took the stage at the Republican National Convention.

title: Behind Appointments, Quiet Warring
description: As President-elect Bill Clinton begins to fill out his Cabinet appointments, a spate of political knife fights have broken out behind the scenes between interest groups trying to cut their people into the new Administration, and their opponents out.

title: Union Teaches Nuts and Bolts Of a Career
description: THE 100-year-old Bridgeport house, long abandoned, had been torched last year, but its foundation was still solid. On a recent weekday afternoon a dozen workers were busy hammering nails into floorboards, installing windows in reshaped frames and cutting long wooden boards in half with power saws.

title: School Plan Cuts Impact of Moving
description: FOR Diane Jones, a homeless mother of two young children, frequent moves around the county from one site to another were difficult enough. What concerned her most, however, was the impact on her 7-year-old son's education. "He used to go to school in Ossining, then in Elmsford," Ms. Jones said. "Then he spent first grade in Mamaroneck."

title: U.N. Chief Says Letter to Bush Outlines U.S. Commitment to Disarm Somali Gangs
description: In a new attempt to persuade the American-led force in Somalia to disarm the warring militias and pacify the country, Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali of the United Nations says he plans to release a letter that he sent to President Bush, setting out the understanding he thought he had reached with the Administration on the American role in the operation.

title:
Long Island Q&A;: Louis Kruh;
Fascinated by the Times and Places of 41 American Presidents
description: BY attending night school, Louis Kruh of Merrick earned a bachelor's degree at the age of 40, a master's at 50 and a law degree at 61.

title: Savage Intolerance; Fundamentalism In South Asia Isn't All Islam
description: THE cry on the lips of the fanatical Hindus who stormed and destroyed an obscure mosque in the northern Indian town of Ayodhya was deafening and terse: "Jai Sri Ram!" ("Hail Lord Ram!").

title: The Grooves. The Box. Ribbon-Ready.
description: Boxed sets have become a holiday gift-giving staple. Here are some new choices for this season. Prices are suggested retail. 'Jefferson Airplane Loves You' RCA 61110; three CD's ($43) or cassettes ($29).

title: Philadelphia Journal; Hospital Helps Itself by Helping Poor
description: Four years ago, when the national shortage of nurses was nearly at its low point, the Presbyterian Medical Center of Philadelphia closed its School of Nursing.

title: DEC. 6-12: Better Prison Digs?; Noriega: Public Enemy Becomes Prisoner of War
description: For the past three years, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega has argued that he is a prisoner of war, and last week a Federal judge in Miami agreed. But rather than place him beyond the reach of American courts, as the former Panamanian leader had hoped, the ruling could merely ease his lot in prison, where he is to spend the foreseeable future for drug trafficking, money laundering and racketeering.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Nov. 22 about facial disfigurement and reconstruction omitted the word "always." The sentence should have read, "Mrs. Leupold said that head and neck cancers did not always cause disfigurement."

title: 'Gypsy' Revisited
description: To the Editor:

title: F.B.I. Chief Took Government Plane to the Ballet
description: The Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, already under scrutiny for using Government aircraft for private travel, flew on an F.B.I. plane to a performance of the Bolshoi ballet at the Sands Hotel in Atlantic City last month as a guest of the Russian Ambassador, bureau officials say.

title: Update; U.S. Still Searching For Missing Boy
description: More than eight months have passed since Shai Fhima, a 13-year-old Jewish boy, disappeared in Brooklyn. But despite search efforts by Federal investigators, Shai is still missing.

title: MOST LIKELY TO SUCCEED
description: The article about Frank Aller was sad and disturbing. He seems to have been adept at hiding his pain; it is unfortunate that, among his highly educated and sophisticated friends, so few had any notion of his suffering until it was too late. The friend who wondered why Aller couldn't just "check out of the intensity of those times" as "most people" did might as well have been asking why he couldn't just make up his mind to swim the Pacific Ocean. A depressed person does not have the freedom to decide to give up his particular "intensity"; he has difficulty getting from one day to the next, let alone making decisions. It is a marvel of human resilience that Aller was able to accomplish as much as he did.

title: A Monument to Energies, Human and Inhuman
description: "Carbon" by Lothar Baumgarten is not like any other book that has come this critic's way. Nobly proportioned and built to evade and outlive the inroads of physical decay (it costs $325), the book has been published by the Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles.

title: Scots March to Instruct Europe on a Concept: Independence
description: If European Community leaders gathered in Holyrood House were having trouble today deciding what the abstruse concept of "subsidiarity" meant, 12,000 to 14,000 Scots who paraded down Princes Street today demanding independence, or at least home rule, were prepared to tell them.

title: Jennifer Berenson, David F. Penson
description: Richard and Susan Berenson of Armonk, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Jennifer Margot Berenson to Dr. David F. Penson, a son of James Penson of Los Angeles and Ruth Penson of Roslyn, L.I. An April 1993 wedding is planned.

title: More Than Militant Feminism?
description: To the Editor:

title: Data Update
GARDENING
description: THERE is a word in the plant kingdom that gardeners will have to learn. It is "dioecious," a word rooted in Greek which means two households. For a gardener, the term means that two will have to be planted, that is, a male plant and a female plant since the male and female flowers are borne by different plants.

title: Bosnia's Religious Leaders Transcend War in Humanity's Name
description: To the Editor:

title: Business Diary/December 6-11
description: THE ECONOMY Clinton's Team Looks a Lot Like Cuomo's

title: Susan R. Kessler, Seth Harris Ross
description: Susan Rachel Kessler, an engineer, was married yesterday evening to Seth Harris Ross, the editor of a real-estate newsletter, both in New York. Rabbi Stanley Kessler, an uncle of the bride, performed the ceremony at Temple Beth Hillel-Beth El in Wynnewood, Pa.

title: The Executive Computer; In the Weight vs. Power Equation, a New Compromise
description: Many attempts have been made over the years to create personal computers small enough to carry easily yet powerful enough to meet the minimum needs of a traveling executive. Most have failed because of the many compromises required.

title: In Mayor's Race, Gay Vote Is Appealing
description: The raucous debate over whether New York City's schools should teach first graders to respect homosexuals, and how they might do so, has probably obscured other and clearer signs of the growing political power of the city's gay voters.

title: Erika A. White and Gary B. Glass
description: Mr. and Mrs. Barry D. White of Newburgh, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Erika Alexandra White, to Gary B. Glass, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Weisglass of New York. A March wedding is planned.

title: Josef Hoffmann's Linear Motifs, All in a Row
description: Josef Hoffmann, Vienna's most versatile 20th-century architect, designed cafes, town houses, a sanitarium, a palace and the decorative furnishings that filled them. After co-founding the Wiener Werkstatte in 1903, he kept the Viennese workshop's artisans busy, producing scores of objects in a variety of materials until it closed in 1932.

title: MOST LIKELY TO SUCCEED
description: Alessandra Stanley's article "Most Likely to Succeed" (Nov. 22), about Frank Aller, Bill Clinton and, by extension, all of us in the Clinton generation, is a remarkable piece of writing -- not in the least because it recalls and feels like the life of the time it describes.

title: GARDENING
description: THERE is a word in the plant kingdom that gardeners will have to learn. It is "dioecious," a word rooted in Greek which means two households. For a gardener, the term means that two will have to be planted, that is, a male plant and a female plant since the male and female flowers are borne by different plants.

title: Miss Lambert, Gary T. Carter
description: Maryjayne Anita Lambert, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Cedric P. Lambert of Henrietta, N.Y., was married yesterday to Gary Thomas Carter, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. Carter of Penfield, N.Y. The Rev. Michael Upson performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at Immaculate Conception Church in Rochester.

title: China Tour On Last Emperor
description: "The Last Emperor's Route" is the title of a tour of northern China that lasts for 12 days and costs $1,688 or, with an extension, for 19 days at $1,988. Both prices, per person in double occupancy, include round-trip air fare from the West Coast to Beijing. Departure is Jan. 31 and the tour company is HoliAsia Tours, in San Francisco, (800) 553-3533.

title: Jennifer Hough, Francis Conley
description: Mr. and Mrs. John D. Hough of New Canaan, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jennifer Keyes Hough, to Francis Joseph Conley, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William P. Conley of Stonington, Conn. A July wedding is planned.

title: World Markets; The Britain-First Cure Is Working
description: It is only technically accurate to call what occurred in rural Vermont last weekend a retreat. True, some 50 A-list women, influential in policy, economics, the women's movement and plain old politics, gathered away from the ambitions and distractions of everyday life to develop an economic plan attendant to the needs of women.

title: POSTINGS: A Home of Their Own; Neo-Classic Synagogue For a Historic District
description: Accustomed to modern synagogues that are starkly abstract, New Yorkers may do a double take when they see the recently drafted plans for the new Congregation Beit Yaakov synagogue at 11-13 East 63d Street. Its lavishly neo-classical facade, built of a creamy gray French limestone, would have four Corinthian columns, about 20 feet high, supporting a full entablature and framed by rusticated walls.

title: Focus: Charleston, S.C.; A Village Proposed for a Pastoral Island
description: THE completion of the Mark Clark Expressway last June linking the pastoral Daniel Island with downtown Charleston just minutes away across the Cooper River has paved the way for a proposal to build a village over the next three decades to support as many as 17,000 residents.

title: 'The Change'
description: To the Editor:

title: An Uncandy Woman
description: With her lack of eyebrows, androidlike looks and angular poses, the model Kristen McMenamy would appear to have limited commercial prospects. But after several star turns on the runway at the recent spring shows in New York, she has landed two high-profile ad campaigns.

title: The Grooves. The Box. Ribbon-Ready.
description: Boxed sets have become a holiday gift-giving staple. Here are some new choices for this season. Prices are suggested retail. 'Barry Manilow: The Complete Collection and Then Some. . .' Arista 07822-18714-2; four CD's ($79.98) or cassettes ($69.98).

title: APPLYING YOURSELF
description: I am rooting for Nancy Ring! I hope she becomes such a great chef that she will be able to earn all the money she needs by baking only one cake a day. Then she could paint as she wishes, "lost in the flow of time." Also, she could write articles -- many of them -- like "Applying Yourself" (Hers, Nov. 15), in which she tells the absolute truth, notwithstanding her first sentence, "I lie." MARGOT S. NEUHAUS Washington ILS>Drawing

title: Frank C. Wright, 59, A Finance Executive
description: Frank C. Wright Jr., a finance executive, died on Friday in Newport News, Va., where he was on business. He was 59 and lived in Manhattan and Mantoloking, N.J.

title: Season Becomes Pointless for the Giants
description: How bad was the Giants' humiliating 19-0 loss to the Phoenix Cardinals today? Let us count the ways:

title: MOST LIKELY TO SUCCEED
description: When Bill Clinton and Frank Aller "agonized" over their respective decisions regarding the draft, one was toughing it out morally while the other was engaging in complicated career calculations.

title: GARDENING
description: THERE is a word in the plant kingdom that gardeners will have to learn. It is "dioecious," a word rooted in Greek which means two households. For a gardener, the term means that two will have to be planted, that is, a male plant and a female plant since the male and female flowers are borne by different plants.

title: POSTINGS: Land-Use Guidebook; Keeping the Hudson Valley Intact
description: In Washington Irving's 1819 story, Rip Van Winkle awakes after a 20-year sleep and finds his Hudson River Valley home completely different. These days, Rip could probably get by on 20 (or 40) winks and still be shocked at the changes. Or at least such is the concern of the Columbia Land Conservancy and the Dutchess Land Conservancy, which have issued the "Hudson River Valley Rural Design Guidebook" to urge the use of new zoning and other methods to make those rapid changes more pleasing to the eye and the environment.

title: Suffolk Opposing Buses for Disabled
description: SUFFOLK County legislators are challenging a new Federal directive that would cost the county as much as $3 million a year to provide bus service for the handicapped.

title: 'The Porcupine'
description: Everybody knows (to employ a Marxist locution) the opening sentences of Karl Marx's essay "The 18th Brumaire of Louis Bonaparte." "Hegel remarks somewhere," Marx wrote, "that all great world historical facts and personages occur, as it were, twice. He has forgotten to add: the first time as tragedy, the second as farce."

title: Filling the Stockings of The Athletically Active
description: Whether you're looking for a gift for a friend, or for an excuse to buy something for yourself, the holiday season is a plentiful time to shop. While sales are scarce, sports merchants tend to keep the shelves full of the newest products. Here are a few suggestions: GOLF Simplicity dictates the design of the Bag Boy Lite, a pull cart. With the use of aluminum for the frame, the Lite, which was first introduced last year, weighs only 6.78 pounds and folds up after use. It is available in six colors for about $80 at golf shops and sporting-goods stores. For information, telephone Bag Boy in Milwaukee, Ore., at (800) 955-2269. TENNIS Proceeding from the premise that consistency brings service power, Serv-O-Meter is the latest gadget for the tennis player who has everything and wants more. A 5-inch plastic meter for measuring swing speed and ball speed during practice, the Serv-O-Meter is being pitched by Nick Bollettieri, the coach who operates a tennis academy in Bradenton, Fla.

title: Mutual Funds; Risk-Reward in Latin Debt Funds
description: SEEKING to capitalize on investors' frustration with rock-bottom yields in the United States, a trio of closed-end bond funds that invest in Latin American debt and yield roughly 11 percent have come to market in the last five months.

title: No Pigeons Were Killed (Or Even Annoyed)
description: WHEN "HOME ALONE 2: LOST IN NEW YORK" WAS being filmed in Central Park a year ago, animal experts guarded the safety and well-being of the movie's hundreds of stunt pigeons. In the credits of "A River Runs Through It," the audience is assured that "no fish were killed or injured" during the making of this movie about the killing and injuring of fish.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE TWILIGHT OF SOVEREIGNTY How the Information Revolution Is Transforming Our World. By Walter B. Wriston. Scribners, $25.

title: THE STORM'S HAVOC: The Overview; On Heels of Rampaging Gales Come Snow and Floods
description: The region's worst storm in decades continued its assault on the New York metropolitan area yesterday with wide sweeps of wind-driven snow and renewed coastal flooding at high tides.

title:
In the Region: New Jersey;
Leasing Steady on I-78 Somerset Corridor
description: WITH new leases slowly whittling down the available space, the eastern stretch of Interstate 78 in Somerset County -- a focal point of new construction during the mid-80's building boom -- is holding its own amid the state's sour office market.

title: Save Us From the Wild Recruiter
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Sophisticated Ladies' At Downtown Cabaret
description: AUDIENCES at the Downtown Cabaret Theater can still arrive with fried chicken and chips in picnic hampers but on stage these nights the bill of fare is caviar. That's because the setting is Duke's Place and the show is a streamlined smorgasbord of Mr. Ellington's luxurious music.

title: Clinton and Abortion: Limited Expectations
description: President-elect Bill Clinton will turn aside many of the laws, regulations and proclamations that have halted abortions over the last 12 years, but he will not eliminate all of them, advocates on both sides of the issue say.

title: Many Calls on Storm Reported by Insurers
description: Insurance companies in the metropolitan region reported a surge in calls yesterday as customers tried to make claims for storm damage.

title:
DINING OUT;
A Hideaway With an Imaginative Menu
description: IT'S been sort of a sleeper since it opened at the north end of Hoboken almost 10 years ago, yet Lady Jane's is a thoroughly likable eating place that suits today's easygoing restaurant mood. Since its 1983 debut, flashier dining spots have come and some have gone in the Hudson County city, while this hideaway has held on to its bohemian air and casually dressed clientele of regulars.

title: Editorial Notebook; Dr. Video
description: Jack Wennberg of the Dartmouth Medical School says doctors often don't know what treatments work and almost surely don't know which treatment best serves their patients. Dr. Wennberg is onto something big -- big enough to change the way U.S. medicine is practiced.

title: 'Woyzeck' Ricochets Through a Mad World
description: "Woyzeck," as Joanne Akalaitis has directed it at the Joseph Papp Public Theater, is ravishingly grim.

title: How to Attract U.S. Investors: High Prices
description: Nothing draws American money like rising prices. A few years ago, when stock prices were low in what used to be called third world countries, few in this country were interested. Now those countries are called emerging markets, many of them have seen soaring prices, and the money is pouring in. (Latin debt funds, page 16.)

title: How a 'Rainbow Curriculum' Turned Into Fighting Words
description: THREE years ago, not long after the killing of a young black man in a white neighborhood in Bensonhurst, a group of teachers and administrators in New York City began writing a curriculum to teach first graders to respect the city's myriad racial and ethnic groups.

title: BENEIFTS
description: For Children in the Parks

title: Upstaging the Exhibit
description: Eye-catching outfits grace the Metropolitan Museum's Costume Institute benefit, Dec. 7.

title: Streetscapes: The Chatsworth; Riverside South's Threat to a 1904 Apartment Tower
description: "CONTEXT" is an urban design buzzword for the late 20th century and Riverside South is going to be one big hunk of context, six blocks of prewar-style apartment houses along the Hudson River that could be approved by the New York City Council next Thursday.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: DAIMONBy Abel Posse.Atheneum, $20.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: TARRYTOWN CHRISTMAS

title: Jets Passer Takes a Step Up, but Has Nowhere to Go
description: For much of this season, the Jets' quarterback situation has been a revolving door of the young and the old, the future and the past, depending upon the health of the players involved.

title: Miss Chapman, David Sandman
description: Dr. Sabrina C. Chapman of State College, Pa., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Kathryn Sabrina Chapman, to David Michael Sandmann, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael G. Sandmann of Glastonbury, Conn. A February wedding is planned.

title: U.S. DENIES APPEAL FOR 4 ILL HAITIANS
description: Despite pleas from military officials, the Immigration Service has refused to allow four ill Haitians infected with H.I.V. to leave the crude camp where they are held here and come to the United States for treatment.

title: Concern Over Meningitis at a College
description: KATHLEEN DUGAN was looking a bit harried on the Thursday afternoon that a public forum was to take place in the Student Center Lounge of Westchester Community College, to address the recent death of Norman Beckford, a student at the college and a Mount Vernon resident, from meningococcal meningitis.

title: Corrections
description: A chart on Nov. 29 headed "Preventive Measures," with an article about the condom market, defined the "sterilization" category incorrectly. The category included tubal ligation, preferred by 15 percent of American women, and vasectomy, 10 percent. Hysterectomy should have been included in the "other" category.

title: Frank X. Zambetti, 77, U.S. Housing Official
description: Frank X. Zambetti, a retired construction engineer for the Federal Housing Administration and a civic leader in Riverdale, Calif., died on Thursday at his son John's home in Santa Monica. He was 77.

title: 'Go Vegan or Die!'
description: MUSTANG SALLY

title: THE STORM'S HAVOC: Drenched and Stunned on New York's Shore; Brooklyn Neighborhood Loses a House to the Sea
description: In Sea Gate, battered by fierce tides, a house crumbled into the sea yesterday morning. A dozen other homes on the shore line appeared to ready to fall, too.

title: Opulent Brasseries of the Belle Epoque
description: LIKE many advances in civilization, brasseries are an invention of war. Although small restaurants or taverns existed in France since medieval times, large brasseries, originally linked with breweries, were created during the Paris Commune of 1870 when Alsatians and Lorrainers fled the Germans occupying their lands and set up shop in Paris. From there, they sold the Alsatian food and beer that is still the mainstay of brasserie cooking.

title: No Headline
description: You see those starving kids on TV and you think, 'How could we not do this?' -- LEE HOSKINS, a salesman from a Cincinnati suburb. [ 16:1. ]

title: Yeltsin Bargains With Congress, Reducing Pressure at the Meeting
description: President Boris N. Yeltsin and Russia's militant Congress today backed away from the most serious confrontation yet in their stormy coexistence, striking a bargain that reopened the issue of the selection of a Prime Minister and called a referendum on a new Constitution for April.

title: Chelsea's School: Public or Private?
description: This city, which hasn't seen a First Child since the freckled-faced Amy Carter, is about to get a new kid on the 1600 block of Pennsylvania Avenue.

title: Oil Slick Spreads Havoc Along Spanish Coast
description: Next to a pile of oil-drenched rubber slickers, Juan Bonome gazed out across the small harbor of Mugardos, 35 miles northeast of La Coruna on the northwest coast of Spain. Workers had just finished loading another 14-ton tanker truck with oil skimmed up by cleanup boats. For a week, six to eight trucks a day had hauled away the black goo.

title: That Old Gang of Theirs
description: RUSSIA'S SECRET RULERS By Lev Timofeyev. Translated by Catherine A. Fitzpatrick. 177 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $21.

title: Hong Kong for Kids
description: BEFORE I could grab the rail to keep from hurtling over the brink, an attendant stepped forward and shoved me. I screamed, but my speeding body passed my voice going down. I descended so quickly and steeply that my heart seemed about to fly out the top of my head. I kept on screaming to the end. When I hit the pool with a splash, I realized two important things: I was still alive, and my swimsuit was hiked up so high between my legs that I was decidedly indecent. Quickly regaining my senses and my decorum, I greeted my two children, who also had just come down a giant water slide at Hong Kong's Water World.

title: Life at Hard Labor
description: TRIALS OF THE EARTH The Autobiography of Mary Hamilton. Edited by Helen Dick Davis. Illustrated. 259 pp. Jackson: University Press of Mississippi. $25.

title: THE STORM'S HAVOC: Connecticut; Snowfall Adds to Woes As Flooding Subsides
description: In Harwinton, in west-central Connecticut, a 50-year-old man was killed today when his carport collapsed on him while he was plowing snow on his driveway. Joseph Kirschner was pronounced dead at a hospital at 2 P.M. The state police said his small tractor-plow might have struck one of the carport's supports.

title: Sports of The Times; Baseball's Antitrust Exemption
description: Take me out to the ball game Take me out to the crowd Buy me some peanuts and Crackerjack Just put them in my antitrust sack.

title:
ART REVIEWS;
In a Group Show, 5 Artists Seeking Meanings
description: THE current exhibition at the Discovery Gallery in Glen Cove groups the works of five artists under the title "In Pursuit of Meaning."

title:
WESTCHESTER Q&A;: HARRY C. BARRETT;
Preparing Doctors for the 21st Century
description: AS science and medicine change, so must medical school. Students of today must be prepared for a 21st century that can only be imagined. If the last decade is any indication, there will be new diseases and new technologies -- and with them related social and ethical issues.

title: An Outbreak of Anti-Semitic Incidents
description: THE flier was mailed last month. It carried Adolf Hitler's image and included such phrases as "death to the Jews" and "my work will be easier now we have microwave ovens." Among those who reported receiving the flier were Temple Emmanuel in Oakland Park, the Fort Lee Jewish Center, Temple Israel in Cliffside Park and 10 residents in Teaneck and Tenafly.

title: Proposed Auto-Ferry Route in Limbo
description: TWO companies on the East End, Cross Sound Ferry of Orient Point and Viking Starship of Montauk, hope to operate automobile ferry service between the South Fork and New London, Conn. But before they could begin, they would have to persuade the Town of East Hampton to lift its ban on automobile ferries in town waters.

title: DEC. 6-12: American Financier; For Russian Science, A $100 Million Man
description: While Western governments continue to debate how best to help the former Soviet Union, the American financier George Soros last week just went ahead and did it. His gift of $100 million, earmarked for fundamental scientific research, equals roughly a tenth of the United States Government's 1992 aid package for the region.

title: A Campaign to Make 'Main Street' Main Street
description: RETALIATING against the discount stores, warehouses, strip shopping centers and megamalls, several towns are vowing to take back their Main Streets.

title: B.C. Player Suspended
description: Boston College guard GERROD ABRAM, the team's top 3-point shooter, was suspended indefinitely after he was charged with larceny involving receiving stolen goods and an illegal application for a credit card, the school has announced.

title: Is a Cinematic New Wave Cresting?
description: While the Hollywood studios spent much of 1992 churning out the most forgettable home video fodder in recent memory, a funny thing was happening out on the fringes. American independent film makers enjoyed an exhilaratingly good year, marked by receptive audiences, critical encouragement and the promise of even better things to come.

title: U.S. Helicopters Destroy Vehicles In Somali Clash
description: In the first clash of its kind since troops landed in Somalia, two Marine Corps helicopter gunships destroyed three armed Somali vehicles today after the American aircraft were fired on, the military said.

title: A Giant Tune With the Wrong Notes
description: People blow on their hands in Arizona, too. During the second quarter of today's Giants-Cardinals game, the temperature was barely 50 degrees, the 20 mile-an-hour wind made a hissing sound in the players' helmet earholes, and the Sun Devil Stadium sod was mush.

title: More Shopping, More Donations Are Making Spirits Bright
description: FRAN PELLETIER is a retired teacher, but there's a jauntiness to his step, a snap to his morning, even a twinkle in his eye, when he thinks of his seasonal job.

title: The Wright Stuff
description: FRANK LLOYD WRIGHT: COLLECTED WRITINGS Volume One: 1894-1930. Edited by Bruce Brooks Pfeiffer. Illustrated. 352 pp. New York: Rizzoli. Cloth, $60; paper, $40. Volume Two: 1930-1932. Edited by Bruce Brooks Pfeiffer. Illustrated. 384 pp. New York: Rizzoli. Cloth, $60; paper, $40. THE WRIGHT STYLE By Carla Lind. Illustrated. 224 pp. New York: An Archetype Press Book/ Simon & Schuster. $50. FRANK LLOYD WRIGHT By Meryle Secrest. Illustrated. 634 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $30.

title: Abby R. Klieman, Lawrence La Sala
description: Larry and Lenore Klieman of Fair Lawn, N.J., have announced February wedding plans for their daughter, Abby Rose Klieman, and Lawrence Joseph La Sala, a son of Jeanne M. La Sala of Ridgewood, Queens.

title: 'Messiah' at Carnegie Hall
description: The Masterwork Chorus and Orchestra, under the direction of David Randolph, will perform Handel's "Messiah" at Carnegie Hall today at 2:30 P.M. The performance is to feature the soloists Louise Wohlafka, soprano; Grayson Hirst, tenor, and Kevin Deas, bass. This is to be the last season in which Mr. Randolph conducts the chorus's performance of "Messiah." Over the last 37 years, he has conducted it 159 times, a fact appearing in the Guinness Book of Records. His final performance will be on Dec. 27 at Carnegie Hall. Tickets are $13.50 to $60. Information: (212) 247-7800.

title: GARDENING
description: THERE is a word in the plant kingdom that gardeners will have to learn. It is "dioecious," a word rooted in Greek which means two households. For a gardener, the term means that two will have to be planted, that is, a male plant and a female plant since the male and female flowers are borne by different plants.

title: NOTES
description: At the premiere party for Al Pacino's film "Scent of a Woman" on Tuesday, Chris O'Donnell, his 22-year-old co-star, said that his first scenes were simple to shoot. In the movie, Mr. Pacino plays a blind man. "My character is really nervous around him when they meet," said Mr. O'Donnell, who has also appeared in "School Ties" and "Fried Green Tomatoes." "That was natural. He's Al Pacino."

title: Bruce Hausman and Amy Kadin
description: Amy Judith Kadin and Bruce Hausman were married in New York last evening. Rabbi David Seligson performed the ceremony at the Carlyle.

title: A Village Proposed for a Pastoral Island
description: The completion of the Mark Clark Expressway last June linking the pastoral Daniel Island with downtown Charleston just minutes away across the Cooper River has paved the way for a proposal to build a village over the next three decades to support as many as 17,000 residents.

title: Knicks Offering Student Discount
description: The Knicks are again offering half-price tickets to New York City students through the G.O. Card High School Student Discount Program.

title: Is Neilson's Alarm Bell Too Rude an Awakening?
description: Last weekend, the Rangers arrived on Saturday at their practice facility in Rye, N.Y., and were greeted by an angry Roger Neilson. Practice was canceled. The Sunday morning skate was canceled. Sunday afternoon hotel rooms, a courtesy on game days, were canceled.

title: Case Sets a Record For Victories in Season
description: WALTER CASE Jr. broke HERVE FILION's North American harness racing record for most victories in a single season when he got his 815th triumph of 1992 last night, guiding Radar Hanover to a 1-length victory over Lord Bertram at Yonkers Raceway.

title: THE GUIDE
description: CRECHES FROM FRANCE

title: How Does One Live?
description: NEW AND SELECTED POEMS

title: Hotels Offer Un-Plane Meal
description: The French-owned Sofitel group of seven hotels is sending its guests on their way with an $8.95 box lunch called the Un-Plane Meal. Although suitable for air travelers looking for an alternative to airplane food, an official said, the meals are available to all guests who call room service an hour before departure.

title: 'The Change'
description: To the Editor:

title: Stony Brook Gristmill Is Grinding Again
description: DOWN by the old millstream in Stony Brook the gristmill's wheel is grinding grain into flour just as it did over 200 years ago. But today, the flour is used not for bread, but to help teach a lesson in regional cultural heritage.

title: NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Rutland, Vt.; A Downtown For the Future
description: THE owners of a downtown shopping center here have agreed to undertake a $12 million renovation in the spring by replacing a 20,000-square-foot Price Chopper supermarket with a new 58,000-square-foot version.

title:
DINING OUT;
An Ambitious Repertory in Chappaqua
description: CONSIDERING the vastness of the main dining room, which on weekends is particularly packed to the proverbial rafters and considering that other areas for private parties are frequently in use, what is amazing is that this restaurant delivers hospitality with an even hand. No caveat to avoid popular Friday or Saturday evenings is necessary. At all times the welcome remains warm and the service gracious, attentive and seemingly unharried. Most miraculous, however, is the work of the backstage crew, the kitchen staff, which manages to turn out a repertory of dazzling dishes with equal skill whether diners number 20 or 200.

title: Louise V. Weir, George Creel 3d
description: Louise Vernice Weir, a daughter of Mrs. Mahlon S. Weir of Delray Beach, Fla., and the late Mr. Weir, was married yesterday to George Robert Creel 3d, the son of Colonel Creel Jr. of the United States Army and Mrs. Creel, who reside in Tequesta, Fla. The Rev. Winston B. Charles performed the Episcopal ceremony at St. James Church in New York.

title: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: Christmas 1993: Store Sales Up, Stocks Down
description: FOR the first time in three years, it looks as though Christmas will be a merry one for the nation's retailers. But on Wall Street, that already is being treated as old news. Share prices in the big store chains peaked within a day or two of Thanksgiving, the traditional kickoff of the shopping season.

title: A Stockingful of Holiday Favorites
description: A GLANCE at the concert schedule makes it clear the holidays are coming. For starters, the Stamford Center for the Arts is presenting the Stamford City Ballet production of Tchaikovsky's "Nutcracker" in the Palace Theater with guest artists from the New York City Ballet at noon and 4 P.M. Handel's "Messiah" is offered this evening at 7 with James David Christie conducting the Ensemble Abendmusik of Boston at St. John's Roman Catholic Church (325-4466).

title: Commercial Property: Concierges; The Concierge Comes to Office Buildings
description: ONE recent morning, Bernadette Hakin, the office manager for Trebol International Corporation, walked into her office in the Seagram Building to a rather daunting sight: a pair of six-foot skis, with a note asking her to send them to her boss's son in Colorado. Sounds easy -- except how do you wrap skis, is the post office the cheapest way to get them there, do they need insurance, do they . . . ?

title: Zooming In on the Island's Natural Worlds Month by Month
description: SINCE his retirement from the Brookhaven National Laboratory in 1970, Dennis Puleston has traveled the world over.

title: Settlement Ends Federal Control of Texas Prisons
description: A Federal judge on Friday ended more than 20 years of legal battles over living conditions in Texas prisons, approving a settlement between the state and inmates in an epic lawsuit that brought sweeping changes to one of the nation's largest penal systems.

title: The Executive Life; Hollywood's Tree Gets the Spartan Look
description: "THOSE were the days," laments Russell Schwartz, an independent film distributor with fond memories of Hollywood Christmases past. During the 1980's boom, he recalls, "we used to get 10-cup coffee makers, big thick argyle sweaters and big boxes of frozen steaks."

title: It Was Sad When That Great Ship Went Down
description: TITANIC

title: Croat Asks Western Action in Bosnia
description: President Franjo Tudjman of Croatia has welcomed growing pressure for Western military action to halt Serbian offensives in Bosnia and Herzegovina, saying that the threat of such action might be enough to cause "a sobering up" of the Serbian Government of President Slobodan Milosevic.

title: Corrections
description: An article and a picture caption on Nov. 29 about the Marin Headlands, in Marin County, Calif., referred incorrectly to a local artist. She is Robin Lasser.

title:
THING;
The Cat Dancer
description: WHAT IT IS (LITERALLY) A three-foot piece of 20-gauge oil-tempered spring steel, tipped at each end by twisted strips of cardboard. Waved at a cat, the Cat Dancer undulates enticingly.WHAT IT IS (ENTREPRENEURIALLY) A basement inventor's dream come true: a gimmick born of scrap metal and ingenuity that has become the Nordic Track of cats, selling at the rate of 300,000 units a year, for $2 to $5 each (except in California, where some people pay $8 "because they're nuts," said the inventor, Jim Boelke of Neenah, Wis.).

title: Amy M. Ludwig, Tedd Weisman
description: Amy Michelle Ludwig, a daughter of Doreen and William Ludwig of West Orange, N.J., was married last evening to Dr. Tedd Lowell Weisman, the son of Diane and Herbert L. Weisman of Great Neck, L.I. Rabbi Barry Friedman performed the ceremony at the Fair Lawn (N.J.) Jewish Center.

title:
New Jersey Q & A: Victor Paulius;
Creating Jobs in 2 Lands, Simultaneously
description: VICTOR PAULIUS has a plan to create badly needed jobs for the two lands to which he owes allegiance. Born in Lithuania, Mr. Paulius, a Bergen County developer, has built an international construction and engineering company in Allendale since locating in New Jersey, where he gained his American citizenship.

title: MOST LIKELY TO SUCCEED
description: Your article reports that Bill Clinton attributed Frank Aller's draft resistance to "the old Martin Luther King thing . . . 'I'm doing this because I can't do anything else.' "

title: Better Protection Asked In Rabies Epidemic
description: The Nov. 8 article regarding the rabies epidemic (New Jersey Q & A, "Leading the State's Fight Against Rabies") highlighted the problems facing veterinarians, physicians and the public at large. Unfortunately, in New Jersey the public is not adequately protected from the threat of this disease.

title: Eagles' Joyner Hits as Hard As His Candor
description: In today's brand of professional football, in which specialization and situational substitutions have become the norm, Seth Joyner is a novelty. Playing on all defensive downs for the Philadelphia Eagles at outside linebacker, he is strong enough to clash with a fullback in the backfield, nimble enough to cover a receiver over the middle and intelligent enough to master his variety of responsibilities in the Eagles' thick defensive playbook. In this, Joyner's seventh pro season, no one is playing his position better.

title: Seminar Focus: Students With Cancer
description: CHILDREN with cancer pose a special challenge for teachers. They must deal with the students' medical and emotional needs and answer questions that classmates are bound to ask. To help teachers cope effectively with these situations, Yale-New Haven Hospital has established an annual seminar for teachers, "The Student with Leukemia and Other Cancers."

title: Update; Construction to Begin At Closed Raceway
description: After nearly five years of controversy, construction on two new retail outlets is about to begin at the long-closed 172-acre Roosevelt Raceway, the largest tract of undeveloped commercial property in Nassau County.

title: Lending One's Good Name to Something With a Bad One
description: THERE are many lines on Vernon E. Jordan's voluminous resume, but none as controversial as the one identifying him as a director of the R.J.R. Nabisco Holdings Corporation, which owns R.J. Reynolds, the nation's second-largest cigarette manufacturer.

title: THE STORM'S HAVOC: New Jersey; Jersey Shore's Rich and Poor Respect Impartiality of Weather
description: The foghorn at Manasquan Inlet today sounded its mournful bleat every 20 seconds over a community where the rich and poor took stock of what the sea stole from them in the worst winter storm in memory.

title: Drive Is On To Collect Back Taxes
description: FOR hundreds of residents who live in Greenburgh, Bedford, Somers and New Rochelle who have not been paying their property taxes, the wolf is at the door, and he wants the house.

title: Grace Hanrahan and Robert Gibbons
description: Grace Catherine Hanrahan, a daughter of Grace C. Hanrahan of Yonkers and the late James Hanrahan, was married yesterday to Robert Graham Gibbons, the son of Robert A. Gibbons of Marion, Mass., and Elaine B. Gibbons of New York. The Rev. John Dwyer performed the ceremony at Sacred Heart Roman Catholic Church in Highland Falls, N.Y.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article about Time Warner on Nov. 29 misstated the format for the recording of Ice-T's "Cop Killer." The song was never issued as a single.

title: Corrections
description: A listing of Caribbean resorts on Nov. 1 and a correction in this section on Nov. 15 misstated the daily winter rates for a double room at Caneel Bay on the island of St. John. They range from $320 to $570, without meals.

title: We Need a Slimmer but Still Capable Air Force; Dangerous Isolation
description: To the Editor:

title:
FILM;
Barry Levinson Makes His Dream Movie
description: Imagine mile after mile of undulating emerald fields an "abstract Ireland," in the words of the director Barry Levinson -- dominated by a shimmering, Cubist construction before which stands a snow-blowing, rainbow-hued statue of an elephant. This is the home of Zevo Toys -- the fictional locus of "Toys," Mr. Levinson's new film -- and if the exterior is magical, the interior is even more so.

title: In the Fight to Save Lives, Copters Save Precious Time
description: LAURIE ROCHE, a flight nurse, opened the left rear door of the helicopter for her first time at 200 feet above the Westchester County Fire Training Center. She slowly slid her right foot out on the skid and began to check the pilot's blind spot as he descended for his landing.

title: 250th-Anniversary 'Messiahs' Show Intimacy, Too
description: WHEN it comes to Handel's "Messiah," small is better. At least that fact of musical life holds true on the Island this holiday season, as community and church choirs and professional ensembles mount their 250th-anniversary productions of the most famous, and most performed, oratorio in the classical repertory.

title: Fruit Juice
description: It's a new age -- the age of the hybrid. The two hottest beauty trends -- back-to-nature simplicity and pharmaceutical sophistication -- have finally melded in a product extracted from a piece of fruit.

title: But Who'll Disarm the Thugs?
description: Americans take quiet pride in the army they have sent to help relieve Somalia's agony. But as Operation Restore Hope rolls on, a nagging doubt arises. After years of chaotic civil strife, Somalia is awash in guns and gunslingers. What's the sense of temporarily keeping the peace, so starving Somalis can be fed, if the thugs who prey on them keep their arms?

title: The Grooves. The Box. Ribbon-Ready.
description: Boxed sets have become a holiday gift-giving staple. Here are some new choices for this season. Prices are suggested retail. 'The Stiff Records Box Set' Demon/Rhino 71062; four CD's ($50).

title: Little Rock Expects Surge Of Visitors
description: Tourism officials in Little Rock hope President-elect Bill Clinton's trip to the White House will inspire streams of visitors to his home state.

title: New Accusations Erupt Over the Dead Sea Scrolls
description: More name-calling controversy has erupted among scholars of the Dead Sea Scrolls, deepening distrust and threatening to disrupt an international conference scheduled to begin tomorrow at the New York Academy of Sciences.

title:
VIEWPOINTS;
Don't Forget Women at the Summit
description: THE policy makers and business leaders who gather in Little Rock, Ark., tomorrow for the economic summit meeting must consider women as economic players. Women today are 45 percent of the work force. Policies intended to restore competitiveness and get America moving again that do not take into account women's vital economic roles will not succeed.

title: Heather Miller, N. A. Picchione
description: Heather Elise Miller, a daughter of Philip B. Miller of Katonah, N.Y., and Rita C. Downey of Roxbury, N.Y., was married yesterday to Nicholas Antonio Picchione, a son of Frank L. Picchione of Wilton, Conn., and Irene J. Picchione of Miami Beach. The Rev. John Kauta, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Patrick's Church in Bedford, N.Y.

title: The Priest and the Runaways
description: BROKEN COVENANT By Charles M. Sennott. Illustrated. 373 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster.

title: Couple's Long Career Culminates in Festival
description: ELLIE and Red Conason have been in business together so long that one expects them to finish each other's sentences. And they do, except it seems often not to be what the other one would say. For more than four decades, the couple has been arguing about design matters and setting standards for crafts in the county -- first in their highly esteemed White Plains gift shop, called Ellie Conason, then in the Red Grooms Gift Shop of the Hudson River Museum here, which the Conasons ran for 10 years.

title: Ms. Krueger, Nathanael Larson
description: Elizabeth Anne Krueger, the development officer at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum in New York, was married yesterday to Nathanael Carl Larson, an associate at the New York law firm of Shearman & Sterling. The Rev. Richard L. Jeske performed the ceremony at the Holy Trinity Lutheran Church in New York.

title: Face of Beauty, Faces Bright
description: THE human face is a book, a mirror of the mind and a blank slate. For the supermodel Christy Turlington, it is also a blank check.

title: Corrections
description: A listing on Nov. 22 with an article about Antigua, Guatemala, misstated the telephone number of a language school at Proyecto Linguistico Francisco Marroquin. Dialed from the United States, the number is (011-502-9) 320 406.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Football National Football League DETROIT LIONS -- Activated Reggie Barrett, wide receiver, from injured reserve.

title: The Grooves. The Box. Ribbon-Ready.
description: Boxed sets have become a holiday gift-giving staple. Here are some new choices for this season. Prices are suggested retail. 'Earth, Wind and Fire -- The Eternal Dance' Columbia/Legacy 52439; three CD's ($46) or cassettes ($35).

title: The Grooves. The Box. Ribbon-Ready.
description: Boxed sets have become a holiday gift-giving staple. Here are some new choices for this season. Prices are suggested retail. 'Roots 'n' Blues -- The Retrospective 1925-1950' Columbia/Legacy 47911; four CD's ($52) or cassettes ($37).

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: GRANDMA'S LATKES By Malka Drucker. Illustrated by Eve Chwast. Unpaged. San Diego: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $13.95. Ages 4 to 8. ELIJAH'S ANGEL A Story for Chanukah and Christmas. By Michael J. Rosen. Illustrated by Aminah Brenda Lynn Robinson. Unpaged. San Diego: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $13.95. All ages. IN THE MONTH OF KISLEV A Story for Hanukkah. By Nina Jaffe. Illustrated by Louise August. 32 pp. New York: Viking. $15. Ages 3 to 8. THE GLASS MENORAH And Other Stories for Jewish Holidays. By Maida Silverman. Illustrated by Marge Levine. 64 pp. New York: Four Winds Press. $14.95. Ages 6 to 9.

title: Broadway Is Just the Beginning
description: As image problems go, the one Walter J. Turnbull describes is not the worst, however inconvenient it may be.

title: Foreign-Born Adopted Kids' Identity Struggle
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Magic World of the Illustrated Book'
description: WILLIAM DANE has done it again. The keeper of special collections at the Newark Public Library has mounted yet another show that comes on unassuming -- prints on the walls of the building's inner court, books in glass cases -- the better to entrap its viewers. This one, "The Magic World of the Illustrated Book," can eat up an entire afternoon.

title: Nets Put a Scare Into Bulls, But Jordan Counts for More
description: When Chicago Bulls forward Scottie Pippen dribbled the ball off his leg and out of bounds in the third quarter against the Nets tonight, it was a sign that the Bulls' heads weren't quite in the game. Actually, it seemed as though their heads were in a fog bank. They should thank Michael Jordan for proving to be too much for the Nets.

title: Foreign Affairs; Never Again
description: The day will soon come when two groups of leaders are charged with crimes against humanity in Bosnia: the Serbs who are killing Muslims and driving them from their homes, and the Western leaders who are doing little to stop this unspeakable brutality.

title: Window-Shopping For Beauty
description: IT was a cleansing moment. Brian D'Amato stood at his kitchen sink, scrubbing a pear with liposome-free Aquanil lotion. "I'm hyperaware of toxins in New York," said the 30-year-old author of "Beauty," a novel about plastic surgery published in October by Delacorte Press. "I'm not maniacal about skin care, but I'm interested in aging and death. I think it's important to start freezing your loved ones. It would be a shame not to have Walt Disney walking around in 70 years. Or your mom."

title: 'Drugs,' A Bitter, Satirical Expose
description: THE answer to the question, "What were the major influences on the latter half of the 20th century?" might very well be sex, drugs and rock-and-roll.

title: THE STORM'S HAVOC: The Warnings; Accuracy of Storm Forecast Debated
description: New York City officials yesterday questioned whether forecasters adequately advised them about the extreme nature of Friday's storm.

title: Spies & Thrillers
description: Charlie Muffin, that seedy fellow, is back. He may be a slob, but there is nobody smarter, more experienced or more resourceful in the British Secret Service, as he powerfully demonstrates once again in Brian Freemantle's COMRADE CHARLIE (Thomas Dunne/St. Martin's, $22.95).

title: Is It Art or Is It a Gift? (How About Both?)
description: Some nonprofit arts centers are unapologetic about going commercial for the holidays.

title: Outdated U.S. Charts Trouble Navigators
description: IT was already hot and well into the night of Aug. 7 when the Queen Elizabeth 2, sailing south from Nova Scotia to New York harbor, was jarred by an unexpected underwater reef three miles off the Massachusetts coast just west of Martha's Vineyard. The accident left a 74-foot-long gash in the QE2's hull; no one was injured but the accident spelled an early end to the voyage.

title: Mary Lindblom, Peter S. Zegras
description: Mary Lewis Lindblom, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Norwood W. Lindblom of Short Hills, N.J., was married there yesterday to Peter Stephan Zegras, a son of Maria Zegras of Rye, N.Y., and the late Stephan J. Zegras. Chief Judge Herman D. Michels of the Appellate Division of New Jersey Superior Court officiated at the bride's parents' home.

title: Packing
description: To the Editor: I was amused by Robert Eisner's "Packing by the Book" (Oct. 18). I myself have never learned to pack light, although I never stop dreaming of baggage-free traveling. Frankly, each time I travel I want to bring my home along with me -- and I very nearly do -- but I necessarily pay the price for dragging such niceties of comfort and of preparations for the unexpected.

title: Baseball Star Thanks His Hometown
description: ON the morning after Thanksgiving about 250 people, from wide-eyed children to white-haired adults, surrendered an extra hour or two of sleep to gather in a small gymnasium at Fairfield High School. Many were armed with baseball cards bearing the picture of Charles Nagy, the All-Star pitcher for the Cleveland Indians who was born and raised in Fairfield.

title: MORE ON THE STORM
description: A Blow to the Wallet

title: Sports of The Times; An Athlete Named Nnenna Becomes a Rhodes Scholar
description: CECIL Rhodes would have been comfortable with the famous American male athletes named Byron White and Bill Bradley and Tom McMillen who earned the scholarships he founded. But what would he have thought of a black woman with a first name from the Ibo tribe in Nigeria?

title: McNally's 'Lips Together' in Chappaqua
description: THE Coyote Theater's production of "Lips Together, Teeth Apart" offers a welcome chance to hear the play. Terrence McNally's "comedy that hurts," about the prejudices and terrors of two upscale heterosexual couples, has been favored with praise and even prizes.

title: Battle Lines Drawn For Major Struggle Over Rent Control
description: "RENT control is like a drug," said Jim Whelan, Atlantic City's Mayor. "Once you're on it, it's very difficult to get off it."

title: Peers Ask: Why Quit?
description: Two veteran Indy-car drivers who don't want to quit said they were surprised to learn that RICK MEARS had done just that late Thursday.

title: The Grooves. The Box. Ribbon-Ready.
description: Boxed sets have become a holiday gift-giving staple. Here are some new choices for this season. Prices are suggested retail. 'Fleetwood Mac -- 25 Years -- The Chain' Warner Brothers 45129; four CD's ($72.98) or cassettes ($62.98).

title: Still Trapped in a Vast Wasteland
description: The recent yanking of CBS's "Brooklyn Bridge" and the uncertainties surrounding NBC's "I'll Fly Away" are combining to produce a public epiphany in this country. Commercial television, buffeted by new technologies that offer viewers attractive alternatives, is caught up in a frantic, and probably fruitless, drive to keep audiences and increase profits. Now the network system, released from regulatory handcuffs during the Reagan-Bush era, is shackled by its own programming handcuffs instead: play safe, focus on undemanding formulas, minimize risks and dump series that fail to show immediate ratings potential.

title: For Winning N.J. Schoolboy, Old Hill Was a Welcome Sight
description: Brendan Heffernan of New Jersey and Amanda White of Maryland, the Northeast regional title-holders, raced to convincing victories here today in the Kinney High School Cross-Country Championships.

title: No Headline
description: Legalizing a Lease Question: Over 10 years ago my married daughter signed a lease for a Manhattan Mitchell-Lama apartment. Her unmarried daughter, who has the same name as her mother, then moved in and has been paying the rent. The rent is based on the income of the mother, which is higher than her daughter's. Is there any way to legitimize the daughter's position and get her name on the lease? . . . Aaron Galuten, Manhattan Answer: Probably not. As you have described the situation, your daughter and granddaughter have violated Mitchell-Lama rules, as they apply to both state- and city-supervised housing.

title: Action Is Put Off on a House 'C-Span' Rule
description: Backing down after protests from the Republican leadership, House Democrats have agreed to postpone a proposed rule change curbing the ability of members to express their views after business hours, customarily to an empty chamber but before a national C-Span audience.

title: DEMOCRATIC LEADER AND CLINTON FRIEND GAIN MAJOR POSTS
description: President-elect Bill Clinton reached back to Hope, Ark., and into the corporate lobbying culture of Washington today to fill two more top jobs, naming his oldest childhood friend, Thomas F.McLarty 3d, as chief of staff, and the Democratic Party chairman, Ronald H. Brown, as Secretary of Commerce.

title: CURRENCY
THE STORM'S HAVOC: Television; New TV Outlet Wearily Takes A Starring Role
description: The storm that has pummeled the New York metropolitan region has given New York 1 News, the nascent 24-hour cable station, its first chance to play a role similar to that of CNN during the Persian Gulf War -- albeit on a local scale.

title: Man in Beating to Sue Hasidim, Sharpton Says
description: After making repeated calls for a special prosecutor in the case of a black man beaten by Hasidim in Crown Heights, the Rev. Al Sharpton yesterday announced what he described as a "new legal strategy," a civil suit against the Hasidim.

title: Anthropologists Go Home
description: EQUATORIA

title: A New Notch in Humongous Shopping
description: LE CORBUSIER called the pared-down house of the future a machine for living. The 7-week-old Price Club, a megawarehouse of general merchandise at wholesale prices on Old Country Road in Westbury, L.I., is a machine for shopping.

title:
WHAT'S DOING IN;
Philadelphia
description: William Penn gave it a name that means "brotherly love" in Greek, considered it his "greene countrie towne," laid it out on a grid and divided it into quadrants. Philadelphia has seen many changes since it was founded in 1682, but it has remained above all a city of neighborhoods. There are a lot more than four of them today.

title: Old Mill Town Revived By Foreign Investment
description: AT one time Connecticut's textile industry was world renowned, employing tens of thousands of people and accounting for much of the state's manufacturing base.

title: What Counts Is Productivity and Productivity
description: TOPIC A at Bill Clinton's economic extravaganza next week in Little Rock will no doubt be the recession. But as the President-elect told everyone from newspaper executives to Congressional leaders last week, it is productivity that will mark the success or failure of his economic policies. And most economists, it is safe to say, would agree with him.

title: Residential Resales
