Mr. Cogan was named to the new post of vice chairman and also became chairman of the newly formed executive committee, which also includes Mr. Hay and William H. Bundy, 51, formerly the senior vice president for manufacturing, Mr. Bundy succeeded Mr. Hay as president and chief operating officer. The manufacturing post was not filled.

title: Question Box
description: Golf Leaders Who Win

title: Harry Connick Arrested
description: Harry Connick Jr., the singer and musician, was arrested at Kennedy International Airport last night when he tried to board an airliner while carrying an unloaded semi-automatic pistol, according to the Port Authority police. Mr. Connick, 24 years old, was charged with a misdemeanor -- fourth degree possession of a weapon -- taken to Queens Central Booking and released on his own recognizance, according to Sgt. Stephen Prospero, a spokesman for the Port Authority police.

title: Europe, Unifying, Has Fears For Its Art
description: For many of the region's guardians of national art treasures, the dream of European unity suddenly looked like an awful nightmare when European Community countries decided to remove all border controls inside a giant single market that goes into effect on Jan. 1.

title: Northwest Extends Its European Fare Cuts
description: Northwest Airlines has extended by three months, until March 31, its fare cuts to Europe of up to 43 percent, hoping to bolster travel during the historically slow winter months. The discounts had been scheduled to end this week.

title: Domino's Pizza Gives Grey A Second Chance to Deliver
description: THESE days, second chances are as uncommon along Madison Avenue as year-end bonuses, particularly those bestowed by unhappy clients struggling to regain momentum in competitive categories. So Grey Advertising Inc., in overhauling a disappointing initial effort for Domino's Pizza Inc., intends to get it right this time.

title: Pro Bono Accounts
description: * Chicago Historical Society, Chicago, to DDB Needham Chicago, to handle the museum's account, previously at Hal Riney & Partners, Chicago.

title: U.S. SHOOTS DOWN AN IRAQI WARPLANE IN NO-FLIGHT ZONE
description: A United States F-16 shot down an Iraqi warplane today after Iraqi jets breached a zone in southern Iraq, the Defense Department said.

title: Pity the Animal Prisoners of Conscience; That Goes for Fish Too
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an obituary on Saturday about former Representative Richard H. Ichord misidentified his hometown in some copies. He lived in both Waynesville, Mo., and Washington, not in Nevada, Mo.

title: Yes, Schools Can Teach Respect for Others; A Struggle for Control
description: To the Editor:

title: Market Place; Generic Drugs: An Upbeat Time
description: THESE are heady days for the generic drug companies that make low-priced copies of prescription drugs no longer protected by patents. Important drugs that had about $3.5 billion of combined annual sales lost their patent protection in 1992, and products with least $10 billion more of sales will be up for grabs over the next three years.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about Bill and Hillary Clinton's Christmas described one of their gifts incorrectly in some editions. Mrs. Clinton gave golf clubs to Mr. Clinton; he did not give them to her.

title: INSIDE
description: Serbian Forces Warned

title: Yes, Schools Can Teach Respect for Others; Part of Pluralism
description: To the Editor:

title: Bill Auction By Treasury
description: The Treasury financings this holiday-shortened week are confined to the regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills today.

title: Results Plus
description: HOCKEY Lemieux Rolls Along Mario Lemieux recorded his 98th and 99th points of the season with two assists as the Pittsburgh Penguins beat the Sabres, 4-2, in Buffalo. The victory was the sixth in the last seven games for the Penguins, who have a league-leading 55 points. The Penguins took a 1-0 lead at 6:22 of the first period on a power-play goal by Jaromir Jagr, who flipped a backhander from the slot past a sprawled Dominik Hasek, with Lemieux picking up an assist. Pittsburgh built a 3-0 lead in the second period on goals by Rick Tocchet, a short-handed tally at 11:18, and Bob Errey, whose shot at the 15:08 mark went in under the glove of Hasek.(AP)

title: Books of The Times; A Narcotics Detective Finds That No One's Family Is Immune
description: Once Through the Heart By Ralph Blumenthal 352 pages. Simon & Schuster. $22.

title: Crown Heights Exposes Fissures Among Jewish Groups
description: The bitter standoff between blacks and Jews in Crown Heights has not only stirred long-simmering racial tensions in New York City and distilled deep anger among both groups. It has also exposed longstanding divisions within the city's diverse Jewish population, and given fresh and wider voice to a strain of outspoken figures who have been active on the fringes of debate for years.

title: Jackson Still Says No
description: The Dallas Mavericks' owner, DONALD CARTER, has relented and offered top pick JIM JACKSON of Ohio State a six-year contract.

title: Bishop Assails School Leaders Over Lessons on Homosexuals
description: Describing homosexuality as "a basic human disorder," the Roman Catholic Bishop of Brooklyn and Queens said in a taped television interview yesterday that public school educators who promoted the teaching of gay and lesbian conduct as legitimate alternative life styles were failing to provide "moral leadership."

title: CHRONICLE
description: When BILL BIXBY, the actor and director, underwent an experimental procedure for prostate cancer recently, he was surprised to find his doctors so grim and worried. So he tried to shake their anxiety in a way that an actor might: he played dead on the operating table.

title: Linda Zappi, Edward Magro
description: Linda Elizabeth Zappi and Edward Anthony Magro, both lawyers in New York, were married yesterday at St. Patrick's Cathedral by the Rev. Joseph Kelly.

title: Breathing New Life Into a Hospital
description: WHEN the Koch administration announced the closing of Sydenham Hospital in 1979, Harlem rallied behind the venerable institution as a symbol of community pride, but not necessarily of quality health care. Finally, Harlem has both.

title: A New Agency for the Homeless Gives No Cause for Optimism
description: To the Editor:

title: Winning Ways in South Korea
description: Kim Young Sam, a veteran democrat, won South Korea's presidential election by a convincing margin. Kim Dae Jung, his main rival, lost the election but won new respect with a gracious and healing concession speech. The defeated candidate then announced his retirement from politics, opening the way to a new generation of democratic leadership.

title: States, Failing to Cooperate, Face a Nuclear-Waste Crisis
description: Thousands of hospitals, pharmaceutical makers and electric utilities across the country face grave new troubles in the new year, when it will become much more difficult and costly to dispose of their low-level radioactive wastes.

title: DISARMING SOMALIS GAINS IN PRIORITY
description: As the two most powerful Somali clan leaders reiterated an agreement to end factional fighting here in the capital, United States officials said today that American troops would step up their efforts to disarm Somali gunmen.

title: Prisoner Advocacy Group Battles Financial Woes
description: A group that provides legal services to perhaps the least-loved clientele in New York State is battling, both in court and in the political arena, to avert crippling financial blows. At the heart of its struggle lies the question of whether the government must help prison inmates take legal action against their jailers.

title: Accounts
description: * Pitney Bowes, Stamford, Conn., to Keiler & Co., Farmington, Conn., to handle the company's mailing systems account, previously at Deutsch/ Dworin Inc., New York. Billings were not disclosed. * Genentech Inc., San Francisco, to Vicom/FCB, San Francisco, to handle advertising for Pulmozyme, a drug that is pending approval to treat cystic fibrosis. Billings were not disclosed.

title: CHRONICLE
description: LOU RAWLS, the husky-voiced pop-jazz baritone, helped raise more than $10 million in cash and pledges for the United Negro College Fund on Saturday night during his 13th annual Christmas telethon.

title: Questions Outweigh Answers In Shooting Spree at College
description: When his music changed, Wayne Lo changed, and in time two people lay dead, four others were wounded and a sheltering place had become a killing field.

title: Gartner! Kovalev! Gartner! Kovalev!
description: Faced with the sort of terrible odds that make for terrific comebacks, the Rangers clambered all the way back last night to defeat the Boston Bruins, 6-5, and discovered a real hero in the process.

title: A-Pact Chances Are Called Good as Bush Bends
description: In a last-ditch push to conclude a nuclear arms treaty before he leaves office next month, President Bush has agreed to compromise on two of the remaining three hurdles to an agreement, Secretary of State Lawrence S. Eagleburger said today.

title: Pity the Animal Prisoners of Conscience
description: To the Editor:

title: McMillan Claims Official Aimed Racial Slur at Him
description: The National Football League is investigating an allegation by the Jets' Erik McMillan that an official working the New York-New Orleans game on Saturday used a racial epithet in referring to the cornerback.

title: Shortage of Trained Caseworkers Imperils Young Victims of Abuse
description: Over the last three years, the Dinkins administration has sharply reduced the staff of caseworkers who investigate child abuse, leaving many of New York City's most vulnerable children in the hands of overburdened, inexperienced workers.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 3-11 U.S. SHOOTS DOWN IRAQI PLANE

title: News Groups Caught in Dispute Between Hispanic and Gay Journalists
description: An angry dispute between two groups of journalists about the boycott of Colorado is threatening to present the nation's major news organizations a choice between insulting Hispanic people or homosexuals.

title: No Headline
description: I don't think we broke apart. We just took the year off. -- PEPPER JOHNSON on the New York Giants' 6-10 season. [ C3:1. ]

title: M-G-M Media To Foote, Cone
description: Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Inc. said last week that it had selected Foote, Cone & Belding in Los Angeles to handle media planning and buying on its estimated $30 million to $40 million account, which had been handled by Wells Rich Greene BDDP in Los Angeles since 1983. The change takes effect on Feb. 1.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the scheduled release dates for major economic indicators this week. Monday

title: N.F.L. Talks Will Continue
description: National Football League owners and player representatives will meet today in New York in hopes of completing a preliminary settlement of their labor differences.

title: Afghanistan, Armed and Abandoned, Could Be the Next Bosnia
description: To the Editor:

title: Abroad at Home; George Milhous Bush
description: Government officials may violate the law whenever they believe their actions are good for the country. That was President Bush's principal rationale for pardoning six men involved in the Iran-contra affair.

title: Laura R. Shaw, Aaron M. Frank
description: Laura Rachel Shaw, a daughter of Dr. Henry and Evelyn Shaw of Scotch Plains, N.J., was married yesterday to Aaron Michael Frank, a son of Dr. Gerald and Judith Frank of Potomac, Md. Rabbi Joel Tessler performed the ceremony at the Lincoln Square Synagogue in New York.

title: Review/Music; Latest From the Late: Schickele Offers More P.D.Q. Bach
description: Among the highly gifted, versatility is a mixed blessing. For however much they may overachieve in a lifetime, they are almost sure to fall short of their full potential in one area or another, to the disappointment of at least some of their admirers.

title: After Highway Shooting, Reports of Other Incidents
description: Detectives investigating the shooting of a woman on a Queens highway Friday night fielded calls over the weekend from motorists who also reported frightening encounters on city highways, but none of the callers had specific information about the shooting, the police said.

title: No Headline
description: The Rev. J. Robert Williams, whose ordination in 1989 by the Bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of Newark caused consternation in the Episcopal Church because he was an avowed homosexual, died on Thursday in Boston. He was 37.

title: Spotlight Turns to Mashburn
description: Kentucky's Jamal Mashburn has the most impressive statistics and advance reputation among the college basketball performers scheduled to play in the Chemical Bank ECAC Holiday Festival, which begins tonight in Madison Square Garden.

title: Soweto Journal; From Die-Hard Camps, the Roll of the War Drums
description: On a patch of green and perfect lawn that mimicked the greater estates of the rich over the hill, Terence Serero and Mpifa Tshepe took stock of their land the other day and decided that everyone else had gotten it all wrong.

title: Polish Limits on Abortion Create a New Clandestine Movement
description: As Lucja, a devout Roman Catholic, tells the story, she became pregnant in September when her husband clamped his hand over her mouth and raped her in an alcoholic rage.

title: Katherine Savits, Jeremy Rabinovitz
description: Katherine Rose Savits, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joel M. Savits of Rockville, Md., was married yesterday in Washington to Jeremy Rabinovitz, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin H. Rabinovitz of Brookline, Mass. Rabbi Joseph Weinberg performed the ceremony at the Washington Hebrew Congregation.

title: Moira Curtain, Karun Singh
description: Moira Gerardine Curtain, a daughter of Ursula and John Curtain of Melbourne, Australia, was married there yesterday to Karun Krishna Singh, a son of Sarah and Amar Singh of Bryn Mawr, Pa. The Rev. John McEntee performed the ceremony at St. Thomas Aquinas Roman Catholic Church.

title: Yes, Schools Can Teach Respect for Others
description: To the Editor:

title: Old St. Wapniacl
description: Now that President-elect Bill Clinton has done the hardest thing, appoint his Cabinet, schoolchildren around the country will be pressed to do the next hardest: remember it -- at least to the extent of remembering the names of all the Cabinet departments. It's an assignment that invites sympathy and assistance.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Basketball National Basketball Association PHOENIX SUNS -- Activated Kevin Johnson, guard. Waived Alex Stivrins, forward. Football National Football League CLEVELAND BROWNS -- Placed Tommy Vardell, fullback, on injured reserve. Activated Keenan McCardell, wide receiver, and Ken Swilling, linebacker, from the practice squad. Waived Latin Berry, cornerback.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK CITY HIGH TURNOVER AMONG CASEWORKERS FOR CHILDREN

title: Sports of The Times; The Giants' Motto: Just Let George Do It
description: WHEN the 20-10 loss to the Eagles ended along with the 6-10 season, Ray Handley sprinted from the sideline to the tunnel and up the ramp, the first of the Giants coaches and players to enter the locker room. After a short speech to the players that linebacker Pepper Johnson later described as "basic stuff," the Giants coach now was in an anteroom, waiting for the news media to gather.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Television; Is It Jay? David? No Matter; Ted Koppel Is Likely Winner
description: While the television industry watches to see whether Jay Leno or David Letterman is left standing after their shootout at the late-night corral, the real winner may be the innocent bystander.

title: How to Survive in Music? Play Anything, Anywhere
description: One recent Saturday, at an hour well before many clock radios switch themselves on, Wayne du Maine stood in a corner of a practice room at the Juilliard School, took off his St. Louis Cardinals cap and put it on again, backward. He picked up his trumpet, silently fingered its valves, and gently challenged a young student to play a scale.

title: An Unfinished Act of Faith
description: The Cathedral of St. John the Divine -- the world's second-largest church -- celebrated its 100th birthday yesterday with the eccentric pomp for which it has become famous. The high-wire artist Philippe Petit, balancing a globe in the air, led a procession through the aisles that included an angel on stilts, two circus clowns, bagpipers and West African drummers.

title: Susan Butler, William Lacy
description: Susan Cavert Butler, a producer in New York for "A Current Affair," the Fox Television show, was married yesterday to William Neal Lacy, the owner of Bill Lacy Design, an architectural consulting concern in New York. The Rev. Theodore Hoskins performed the ceremony at the Saugatuck Congregational Church in Westport, Conn.

title: Knicks Need a Spark At Point-Guard Spot
description: How much more was revealed about the Knicks this weekend than that they are still not a good road team and they don't like playing on Christmas Day?

title: Finance Subsidiaries: 'For Sale' Sign is Up
description: Some of the best-known names in American industry are coming to the same conclusion: They are better off concentrating on their core businesses and pulling out of their finance company subsidiaries.

title: Clinton Set for a Vacation Of Sports and Lots of Talk
description: President-elect Bill Clinton will leave Monday for his version of a busman's holiday: several days of seclusion with a thousand or so friends, talking.

title: On Health Care Reform; Managed Competition Is Good Diagnosis
description: To the Editor:

title: Exit Losing
description: The Giants' season ended today the way it began and the way it evolved. The Giants were inconsistent and overly generous. They were lethargic, then sharp, then almost asleep, and they lost, 20-10, to an Eagles team that played with more intensity.

title: Maria Herrera-Uslar; Society Figure Was 78
description: Maria Teresa Herrera-Uslar, the Dowager Marquesa de Torre Casa, who was a society figure, philanthropist and author, died on Saturday at the Caracas Medical Center in Venezuela. She was 78 and lived in Caracas.

title: Fear in Caribbean Over Trade Pact
description: Just out of earshot of the shop-floor bustle of industrial parks here, plant managers fear they will soon be able to detect another sound here: the whoosh of capital drawn toward Mexico by its sweeping new trade agreement with the United States.

title: Barbara Sopher, Daniel Harelick
description: Barbara Abigail Sopher, a daughter of Marilyn and Morris Sopher of Riverdale, the Bronx, was married yesterday to Daniel Barak Harelick, a son of Marlene and Stanley Harelick of Fair Lawn, N.J. Rabbi Charles H. Sheer performed the ceremony at the Sephardic Temple in Cedarhurst, L.I.

title: Miami Seeks Perfection Off Field, Too
description: For millions of television viewers, and the record books that reflect the history of college football, the defining moment of this season for the University of Miami will come here in the Louisiana Superdome Friday night when the Hurricanes meet Alabama in the Sugar Bowl to decide a national championship.

title: People
description: * Becky Broers, senior vice president and account executive at Lintas New York, was promoted to executive vice president.

title: Bridge
description: A neat defensive play on the diagramed deal was recently reported by the French journalist Guy Dupont. It was played in an interclub match in Val-de-Marne, and the hero was Claude Vigneron, who held the West cards.

title: U.S. Chief Bids Adieu to an Expanding Hermes
description: After eight years of expanding the United States presence of Hermes -- the Paris-based luxury-goods purveyor best known for its ties, scarves and handbags -- Chrys Fisher resigned yesterday as chief executive of the company's American subsidiary.

title: Barbara F. Meister, Jean-Marc Juhel
description: Barbara Fay Meister, who teaches French at the Collegiate School in New York, was married yesterday to Jean-Marc Juhel, who teaches French at the Fountain Valley School in Colorado Springs. Rabbi Edward M. Maline performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's sister, Dr. Lynn Meister, in Coral Springs, Fla.

title: High, if Not Dry: Storm Proves Value of Strict Building Codes
description: If any good news came out of the storm that bruised the region's coastline two weekends ago, it was the general success of houses constructed under strict building codes to withstand high winds and surging tides, Federal and local government officials say.

title: A Disgruntled Team That Got No Kick From Campaign
description: Suddenly, the words that Giants players diplomatically tried to avoid all season -- bickering, chaos, finger-pointing -- came blurting out today as their campaign ended with a crash: another defeat filled with lost opportunities to an opponent that seemed to have more will.

title: Finding Profits in Risks of Weather
description: Harold Mollin will often call a number at random in a faraway area code and ask whoever answers if it is raining. He has never been turned down, and most offer to give him a call if they detect the slightest sprinkle.

title: The Ludlum Defect
description: To the Editor:

title: Japan's Health Care: Cradle, Grave and No Frills
description: Seventy-year-old Genji Ito had to travel 20 minutes by bicycle on a drizzly morning recently to get to the Toho University Hospital by 7:30, an hour before it officially opened.

title: Robbers Fatally Shoot Worker
description: Four masked gunmen killed a restaurant employee on Saturday night after they robbed 20 customers, the police said. No one else at the Sizzler Steak House was injured.

title: Arnold Miller, 60; Founder of Matrix, A Shampoo Maker
description: Arnold M. Miller, who began his career as a hair stylist and later founded Matrix Essentials Inc., one of the nation's leading makers of hair-care products, died on Saturday at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston, where he had been receiving treatment for cancer. Mr. Miller was 60 years old and lived in Beechwood, Ohio, a suburb of Cleveland.

title: Barriers Fade for European Shoppers
description: Standing in the aisle of a supermarket here, loading their shopping cart with discounted beer and wine for the return trip across the English Channel, Steve and Claire Field spoke eagerly of the potential benefits of the single European market that comes into being Jan. 1.

title: Law Ill-Equipped for Politics
description: In pardoning Caspar W. Weinberger and five other Iran-contra figures last week, President Bush pronounced his own caustic verdict on the process that had convicted four of the men and indicted the two others. "The criminalization of policy differences," the President called it.

title: Review/Television; ABC on the Trail of Cocaine Traffickers in Bolivia
description: If Bill Clinton tunes into ABC tonight, he will hear himself being instructed by Peter Jennings to admit that "the cocaine war in Bolivia is already lost" and to stop wasting money on it. Such a directive to an incoming President may seem a touch presumptuous, even from a network anchor, but it is forcefully backed up by pointed interviews and vivid scenes from the field.

title: West Feliciana Parish Journal; The Men Are Here, And Here To Stay
description: It is not as though the country roads of West Feliciana Parish are crawling with anxious men in pickup trucks looking for scarce women. There is no more than the usual complement here of that most typical of rural meeting spots, the honky-tonk bar.

title: Marion Strachan; Nurse-Midwife, 84
description: Marion Strachan, a nurse-midwife and educator, died on Dec. 20 in Hartford. She was 84 and lived in Bloomfield, Conn.

title: Truly a Contest For the 1990's
description: If the 1970's were known as the "Me Decade" and the 1980's were the "Greed Decade," what should the 1990's be called?

title: BUSH WARNS SERBS NOT TO WIDEN WAR
description: President Bush has warned Serbian leaders that the United States is ready to use military force if they widen the Balkan war to a Serbian province inhabited mainly by ethnic Albanians, diplomats said today.

title: Some Target Practice On a Stand-In Goalie
description: The Devils took advantage of a Hartford goaltender switch because of an injury to Sean Burke and skated away with a 6-2 triumph over the Whalers this evening at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: Battle Lines Drawn, as Deer and People Collide
description: THE pastoral sight of deer feeding around the Durand-Eastman County Park has not necessarily been a welcome one to residents here.

title: Rain + Cold = Treacherous Trips for Commuters
description: Thousands of commuters collected new horror stories yesterday as freezing rain left a treacherous layer of ice on roads throughout the New York metropolitan region just in time for the morning rush hour. Traffic officials said there were few serious accidents -- just hundreds of fender benders that left trucks and cars strewn along roads like jackstraws, tying up those traveling behind them.

title: Millfeld Trading Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Included losses from discontinued operations of $ 371,998 in the quarter and $ 744,556 in the 9 months.c-Included losses from discontinued operations of $ 315,624 in the quarter and $ 767,205 in the 9 months.

title: 166 'Messiahs' Later, A Maestro Takes His Final Bow
description: David Randolph's final presentation of Handel's "Messiah" in Carnegie Hall on Sunday, his 166th performance of the oratorio, ended much as the first one did in 1961. There was a dramatic one-second silence, followed by a stupendous double "amen" that seemed almost to levitate the hall.

title: Chronic Pain Fells Many Yet Lacks Clear Cause
description: CHRONIC pain, in the absence of any discernible physical cause, is the most common reason for lost workdays in this country, yet doctors remain unsure about what causes the complaint, how to treat it, or even if exists.

title: Dudley Is All Legs, All Heart, All Right
description: On any night, a quick look down the Nets' bench for a game-saver and the eyes just might skip backup center Chris Dudley. He's gawky, all legs, and he looks as if he would be more comfortable playing volleyball in southern California than mixing it up on a basketball court in New Jersey.

title: Q&A
description: The Smell of Snow

title: Have the House Democrats No Shame?
description: House Democrats have just awarded themselves five more votes. Unfazed by the crying need for Congressional reform, the Democratic caucus proposes to let non-voting delegates vote on the House floor. All five are, of course, Democrats.

title: Donald G. Sullivan To Leave Thompson
description: The J. Walter Thompson Company and Donald G. Sullivan, executive vice president of planning and development, said yesterday that by mutual agreement, Mr. Sullivan would leave the agency after seven years. The departure takes effect Jan. 31.

title: New Jobs Depend on Fast Economic Growth, Experts Say
description: The recession is officially over, but the American economy will have to grow more than 3 percent a year -- perhaps much more -- to stop the kind of mass layoffs that have taken place in recent months and to create enough new jobs to employ most of the people who want to work.

title: Gotham Names New President
description: The Gotham Apparel Corporation said yesterday that it promoted Patricia Kipperman to president and chief operating officer.

title: Rebecca Ann Donovan, Professor, 46
description: Rebecca Ann Donovan, a sociologist and an associate professor at Hunter College, died on Sunday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. She was 46 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Claude E. Forkner, 92, Internist and Professor
description: Dr. Claude E. Forkner Sr., a former professor at Cornell University Medical School and an internist, died on Dec. 20 at his home in DeLand, Fla. He was 92.

title: Ex-Chief of Airport Council Is Charged in Fraud Case
description: The former head of a little-known security agency for the region's three major airports was charged yesterday with illegally putting more than $50,000 of the agency's money to personal use.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: John Peters, 85, Dies; Founded an Aid Group
description: Dr. John L. Peters, a Methodist minister and founder of World Neighbors, an international self-help organization, died Saturday at the Cherry Creek Nursing Home in Aurora, Colo., a suburb of Denver. He was 85 and lived in Aurora.

title: Another Round of Bargaining But No N.F.L. Agreement Yet
description: Talks aimed at reaching a labor agreement between owners and players in the National Football League got off to a late start in New York yesterday and lasted six hours without reaching a final deal.

title: And the Giants Don't Even Deserve an A for Effort
description: The Giants' frustrating and disappointing 6-10 season is over. Ray Handley's two-year tenure as a head coach who never quite fit the job may be over in a day or two, and almost certainly by next week.

title: Power of Natural Pest-Killer Wanes From Overuse
description: WITH surprising speed, insect pests are becoming resistant to natural toxins that scientists hoped would usher in a new era of biological controls and ring down the curtain on synthetic insecticides.

title: Ring In New With New
description: New Year's celebrations are different things to different people. Some prefer quiet dinners by candlelight at home; others choose nightclubs with funny hats and sparklers, and thousands go out to watch the ball drop in Times Square.

title: U.S. Sends Jets to Iraq Zone From a Carrier Off Africa
description: The United States rushed today to build up its fighter force near Iraq, taking the unusual step of sending two squadrons of Navy warplanes to Saudi Arabia from an aircraft carrier off the coast of Africa.

title: MAGAININ AND SANDOZ TO DEVELOP CANCER PRODUCTS
description: The Magainin Pharmaceuticals Corporation and the Sandoz Pharmaceuticals Corporation have agreed to co-develop cancer-fighting products. Magainin, based in Plymouth Meeting, Pa., said yesterday that the venture would last 30 months and would be largely financed by Sandoz. Any compounds will be jointly owned. The venture will focus on magainins, a family of peptide protein fragments that can kill infected or diseased cells and are found in the host-defense systems of animals. Magainin Pharmaceuticals' shares were down 37.5 cents, to $8.625, in over-the-counter trading yesterday. Sandoz Pharmaceuticals, based in East Hanover, N.J., is part of the Swiss company Sandoz Ltd.

title: Let Teen-Agers Know Medical Risks of Birth Control Implants; A Need for Love
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Television; Helping Endangered Species Propagate
description: "Sex and the Single Rhino" does not signal a turn toward the risque by the straight-arrow producers of "Nova." Tonight's offering has to do with ways of assisting endangered species to reproduce. It is absorbing, not only for the look it provides into the work of biologists concerned over the disappearance of many kinds of animals, but also for the clear and fair way it lays out issues that divide animal lovers.

title: Israel to Let 10 Wrongly Deported Arabs Return
description: The Israeli Army announced today that among the 415 Palestinians expelled to Lebanon more than a week ago, 10 were wrongly deported and would be allowed to return.

title: Conviction in '80 Slaying Reversed by Federal Court
description: A Federal appeals court yesterday reversed the murder conviction of Angel Claudio, who is serving a prison sentence of 25 years to life for the 1980 slaying of a Queens high school student, in the latest round of a case that has plodded through the courts for years.

title: Denny's Chief to Retire
description: TW Services Inc., a unit of TW Holding Inc., said that E. Bernard Scott, 59, senior vice president of TW Services and chief operating officer of its Denny's division, would retire Thursday after 19 years of service. H. Stephen McManus will be interim operating chief until a successor is named. Mr. McManus, 50, will also continue as executive vice president for restaurant operations for TW Services, with overall responsibility for its Hardee's, Quincy's Family Steakhouse and El Pollo Loco divisions.

title: Governor of Alabama Is Indicted On Charges of Financial Misdeeds
description: Gov. Guy Hunt of Alabama, whose financial dealings have been under investigation for more than a year, was indicted today on 13 felony counts, including charges that he took $200,000 from his inaugural fund for his own use.

title: Beech Air Force Order
description: The Raytheon Company said today that the Air Force has decided to buy 36 more T-1A Jayhawk airplanes from its Beech Aircraft unit in a contract valued at $134 million. With the latest order, the Air Force has contracted for 113 aircraft valued at $482 million. Raytheon said it expected to sell 180 Jayhawks, used to train tanker and transport pilots, by the time the program ends.

title: Business Scene; Shrinking Goals For Aid to Russia
description: WITH Yegor T. Gaidar ousted as Russia's economics czar, American experts on Russia are going through a sometimes angry post-mortem: if the Western industrial nations had underwritten Mr. Gaidar's efforts with $24 billion in loans, would he still be in power today, hastening Russia toward a market economy? Maybe, but not for many more weeks. With or without Western money, his days seemed numbered.

title: Gunter Grass Considers the Inescapable: Politics
description: Conversations with writers usually drift from current events to literature to personal lives, back to literature again, then to a bit of the news and on to long discussions of the writer's current work. But a talk with Gunter Grass, one of Germany's most prominent novelists and essayists, is nearly all about politics, very specifically German politics. He cannot escape, he said, this shadow that insinuates its way into his writing, his etchings and his conversations.

title: Rufus Bullock, Investment Executive, 56
description: Rufus Bullock, chairman of Edgewood Management Company, an investment advisory firm in New York City, died on Friday at Greenwich Hospital in Greenwich, Conn. He was 56 and lived in Greenwich.

title: POTLATCH EXPECTS LOWER FOURTH-QUARTER EARNINGS
description: The Potlatch Corporation said yesterday that it expected fourth-quarter earnings to be below those for the similar 1991 period because of weak markets for paper products and problems at the company's plant in Lewiston, Idaho. Potlatch said earnings for the quarter would be reported in the third week of January. In the 1991 period, the company had earnings of 55 cents a share. Potlatch's shares dropped $1.875, to $45.125, on the Big Board.

title: Sports of The Times; When Sal The Barber Pitched
description: WHEN the Giants-Dodgers rivalry was stirring New York to its National League roots four decades ago, Sal Maglie would stare down from the mound as Jackie Robinson took his time settling into the batter's box. As soon as the Dodgers' cleanup hitter was ready, the Giants' ace right-hander would step off the rubber and pick up the resin bag.

title: Mets Sign Outfielder
description: The Mets yesterday reached agreement on a minor league contract for free-agent outfielder ERIC BULLOCK and invited him to spring training. Bullock, 32, batted .305 in 90 games with Indianapolis of the American Association last season and was 0 for 5 in eight games with Montreal. He has played for Houston, Minnesota, Philadelphia and the Expos and has a career batting average of .205 in 131 major league games. (AP)

title: 5 Suspects in Bank Theft Are Linked to an Earlier Robbery
description: A former lieutenant in the Orange County Sheriff's Department and four other men charged with robbing a bank here on Wednesday also took part in a bank robbery in Westchester County in July, a Federal prosecutor said today.

title: Bills' Kelly to Miss Game Against Oilers
description: On crutches, and angry and frustrated over a sprained ligament on the side of his right knee, Jim Kelly, Buffalo's All-Pro quarterback, said yesterday he would miss Sunday's first-round playoff game against the Houston Oilers. Kelly said he also would be unavailable for at least a week after that if the Bills advanced.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Companies

title: In With the New, and Out With the Coach
description: This was the day after the Giants' season ended, the start of a death watch on Ray Handley's career as their head coach.

title: Rise of Militants Seen in Algeria As Junta Falters
description: Almost a year after it took power in a coup, the military-backed Government of Algeria is facing a declining economy, deepening public resentment and mounting armed attacks by Islamic militants, and many Western diplomats here expect it to fall within a year in favor of an Islamic government.

title: 'Let's Do Lunch,' Clinton Says, Calculatingly
description: Clearly convinced that his forays into McDonald's are not enough, and mindful that Washington is perceived as short on ordinary Americans, President-elect Bill Clinton plans to go all out to show that his will be an Administration of and for the common people. He is shipping them to Washington for lunch.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-9 CLAN TERROR IN SOMALI TOWN

title: Books of The Times; Is It Love, or Just the Imperatives of Reproduction?
description: Anatomy of Love The Natural History of Monogamy, Adultery and Divorce By Helen E. Fisher 431 pages. W. W. Norton & Company.

title: New York City's Foggy Bottom of Foreign Policy; City Council Extends Its Reach Past Potholes to Apartheid and 'Freedom Fighters'
description: One of the longest, most emotional debates in the New York City Council this year had nothing to do with the city budget, incinerators or any of the other mundane business of running the city. It involved Puerto Rican revolutionary heroes, United States foreign policy and the sometimes subtle distinction between freedom fighters and terrorists.

title: Alien Species Threaten Hawaii's Environment
description: FOR 70 million years the Hawaiian islands enjoyed blissful isolation, disturbed only once every few thousand years by a species crossing the Pacific to find a new home. But researchers say alien species are now entering this tropical paradise at many thousands of times their natural rate, causing critical problems.

title: The Los Angeles Art World's New Image
description: Sue Spaid, a tall young woman who opened a gallery in a tiny storefront on Beverly Boulevard two years ago, is something of a legend in the freshman ranks of the Los Angeles art scene. Mention her name and people will remark that she has been known to work in a bakery at the minimum wage to keep her gallery going, or that she doesn't have a car.

title: A Mental Institution Copes With Bosnia's Horror
description: The afternoon light was fading when a group of her fellow patients at the Pazaric mental institution carried Adila Pasic's coffin up the barren hillside here on Sunday afternoon.

title: Gloom Lifts in U.S. and Falls on Japan
description: The Japanese are losing confidence that their nation will be the dominant economic power in the next century, while Americans see their own economy as gaining strength and view Japan as less of a long-term economic threat than before.

title: Home for the Holidays: Kentucky and St. John's
description: Kentucky and St. John's rose last night at Madison Square Garden and tossed aside their opponents like discarding a T-shirt. The occasion was opening night for the Chemical Bank ECAC Holiday Festival, a college basketball feast that dates to 1952 and one that drew 14,110 fans for the doubleheader that had so many New York trappings.

title: STATES FACE DROP IN FEDERAL BACKING OF AIDS PREVENTION
description: The Federal Government has notified states that it is cutting money for AIDS prevention programs, and as a result many states are reducing services even as they face a rising demand.

title: Assix International Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a gain of $ 3,174,075 as part of Phase I and Phase II of the company's overall debt restructuring plan.Assix International said that the first and second portions of its restructured debt agreement included a reduction in debt principle and a further reduction in accrued interest through a conversion into warrants to purchase stock.Under the first two phases, the company's senior lender, Citizens Fidelity Bank, a unit of PNC Financial Corp., entered an agreement to convert $ 3.1 million of principle and $ 334,075 of accrued interest in exchange for purchase stock at a price ranging from $ 3 to $ 5 a share.

title: Bridge
description: Try an arithmetic problem that is slightly harder than it appears. What is the highest score possible on a single deal?

title: Giving Shelter from a Storm Or Other Trading Disasters
description: Ken Israel does not exactly revel in disasters. But fires, bombs, hurricanes, earthquakes, floods, power failures and severed telephone lines are sure good for his business.

title: Review/Theater; Tommy Tune's Dream of Yesterday's Broadway
description: If Tommy Tune could wave a magic scepter, Broadway would be transformed from its currently bedraggled state into an immaculate thoroughfare of diamond-studded glamour and endless high spirits. The years would melt away, and names like George Gershwin, Cole Porter, Fred Astaire and Ray Bolger would blaze on every marquee. To step into a theater would be to enter a Busby Berkeley dream world of top hats, tap shoes and gushing Broadway melodies.

title: Not So, Dykstra Says
description: LENNY DYKSTRA has acknowledged that he gambles legally in Atlantic City, but has disputed a magazine account that he lost $50,000 at baccarat and had to be restrained from attacking another casino customer.

title: Having Backed Right In, Washington Limps Ahead
description: The Washington Redskins have been awarded the gift of a playoff game, but they are going to need substantial first aid just to field a team.

title: Kay Boyle, 90, Writer of Novels and Stories, Dies
description: Kay Boyle, a short-story writer and novelist renowned for her deft and powerful style and her keen insights into human nature, died on Sunday night at the Redwoods, a retirement community in Mill Valley, Calif. She was 90 years old and lived at the Redwoods, where she had moved from San Francisco several years ago.

title: Surgery for Kosar
description: BERNIE KOSAR will undergo surgery tomorrow to repair his right ankle, which he broke again in the Cleveland Browns' season-ending game at Pittsburgh on Sunday.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Rare Feat for Heat Harold Miner scored 12 of his 18 points in the fourth quarter last night, and the Heat overcame an 18-point deficit to earn their first victory ever over the Los Angeles Lakers, a 107-96 triumph in Miami. Miami is now 1-10 against the Lakers in franchise history. For Miner, who was born and raised in Inglewood, Calif., near where the Lakers play their home games, the game was something special. "I grew up bleeding purple and gold," said Miner, who played for Inglewood High School and Southern Cal. "It was a big thrill to beat them, especially with the game being televised back home." The Heat scored their last 10 points from the free-throw line to seal the outcome. Miami was 24 of 27 from the foul line for the game. The loss was the fifth in six games for the Lakers. The game marked the return of Lakers guard Byron Scott, who missed his team's previous 18 games with a sprained right foot. (AP)

title: Executive Changes
description: HOFFMANN-LA ROCHE INC., Nutley, N.J., a unit of Roche Holding Ltd., named Alan L. Rubino corporate associate vice president for human resources.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Thursday with an article headed "Meyersville Journal," about a New Jersey family that raises deer as pets, misstated the number of deer the family now has. It is eight, not nine.

title: The Contrabury Tales
description: Heere bigynneth the Pardoner's Tale Whan that November gave Bush the boote, He pierced Walsh's case to the roote: Ere goon to Houston on a pilgrymage, Bush cutte loose Wynberger's entourage. "For patriots, no Damoclesian sword," Seyde he (not cyting Nixon's Ford). "Caspar, a parfit Pentagonne knyght, Merits honour, not a kourtroom fyght. Abrams, Fiers, Clarridge, George, McFarlane -- none styck in my gorge." Heere bigynneth the Man of Law his Tale Walsh, Koppeled in his Oklahoma lair, Quod, "Another Saturday nyght massacre! There's no tyme at Willard Inn to sup 'Til I probe this iniquitous cover-up. The vileyne of conceeling notes May've stopp'd Reagan impeechment votes. Outsyde the loop? A contra-dykshun Of diary entrys -- an Iran-gayt fykshun. And Bush's fayte for this disgrayce? 'Tween Lytl Rock and the hardd playce." Heere taketh the maker of this book his leve And then 'twixt George and the Dragon Came Gephardt, Mitchell, fyngers waggin', Smellynge a Whyte Howse partee lyne; Angree, Dole seyde, "Prosecutor, resyne!" Surpryze! Who fayvord the clemencee? Aspin and Foley, seyde the G.O.P. What did Bush know? Whan did he know it? Gentyl Reeder, I'm but a Chaucerian poet (Merrilee meterynge the Pardoner's way Of treeting scandall in his C.I.A.).

title: China Plans Big Layoffs Of Coal Mine Workers
description: China has laid off 100,000 coal workers and will lay off hundreds of thousands more in the coming years, as part of a broad effort to modernize its energy industry, an official report said today.

title: Little Chance For 3 to Flee From Blaze
description: The fire at a power plant here Friday erupted so suddenly that three workers, who were suffocated by billowing black smoke, apparently had little chance to escape, a fire official said today.

title: On My Mind; Female Genital Torture
description: "They are by far the most emancipated of Muslim women. They wear no veils, often don sleeveless dresses and behave directly toward men, rather than submissively.

title: An Unusual (Free) TV Spot Tied to 'Northern Exposure'
description: ALASKA has always been known for attracting pioneers. Now, a venture involving two entertainment giants is using make-believe Alaskans in pioneering an unusual approach to advertising and marketing.

title: U.S.-Russian Arms Talks Seem Snagged on Details
description: The United States and Russia continued to talk today about concluding a far-reaching nuclear-arms-reduction agreement and agreed to meet again on Tuesday. Foreign Minister Andrei V. Kozyrev of Russia offered to bet a bottle of whisky on a positive outcome.

title: We Have to Protect No-Longer-Pristine Arctic
description: To the Editor:

title: Loss Narrows For Fedders
description: The Fedders Corporation reported today that its fiscal first-quarter loss narrowed to $2.6 million because of lower operating costs for its room air-conditioner factories. The loss for the quarter that ended on Nov. 30 dropped to $2.6 million, from $6.3 million for the comparable period a year earlier.

title: Jets Give Statements
description: The National Football League gathered written statements yesterday from Jets cornerback ERIK McMILLAN, his teammate MARIO JOHNSON and referee LARRY NEMMERS in an investigation of McMillan's allegation that Nemmers used a racial epithet in reference to the cornerback during the game against the New Orleans Saints Saturday at Giants Stadium.

title: Will Bush Pardon Himself?
description: If President Bush wants to avoid being investigated and bring a final end to the Iran-contra prosecution, there is one more person he will have to pardon -- himself.

title: Market Place; A Bright Outlook For Natural Gas
description: AS the year draws to a close the natural gas industry is crowing about how good 1992 was and even more about how much better the years ahead will be, with a new Administration coming to power in Washington. Investors who agree have several stocks to choose from.

title: INSIDE
description: Gore's Senate Seat Filled

title: Kenyans Sip Democracy But Find It Bitter, So Far
description: The campaign for Kenya's first multiparty elections in 26 years ended tonight with charges that brutality and fraud were being used to win votes.

title: Lawrence Bruce Jr., 47, Lawyer and Leader of Unicef Committee
description: Lawrence E. Bruce Jr., a lawyer and president of the United States Committee for Unicef, died on Friday at his home in Manhattan. He was 47.

title: Brooklyn Theft Brings Robbers $8 Million Cash
description: Robbers entered an armored car company's warehouse in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, late Sunday night and made off with more than $8 million in one of the largest cash thefts in the United States, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said yesterday.

title: BETHLEHEM STEEL COMPLETES SALE OF WIRE MILL
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation said yesterday that it had completed the sale of its Johnstown, Pa., wire mill to TMB Industries of Chicago. The terms of the deal, first announced in August, were not disclosed.

title: Illusions Are Also Left Dead As Child-Killer Awaits Noose
description: After trying for 17 years to reform the life of Westley Allan Dodd, the State of Washington is scheduled to kill him next week, in what would be the nation's first execution by hanging in nearly three decades.

title: Guns at Airports: a Common Problem
description: Security officers at Kennedy International Airport were surprised Sunday night when a New Orleans-bound passenger told them he had an unloaded handgun in his carry-on bag. When they verified that he was telling the truth, the airport police arrested the passenger, Harry Connick Jr., the singer and pianist.

title: One Key or 2 for the Car? Innovation Is Unwanted
description: Standing in the dark next to a locked Buick, arms filled with packages, a shopper inserts the key in the door; it won't turn. A package falls. The door opens on a second try, but the key fails to turn in the ignition because it has been inserted upside down.

title: A Cabbie Who Cared
description: To the Editor:

title: Honoring Streisand For Civil Liberties
description: To the Editor:

title: Carlos Querejeta, Advertising Executive, 68
description: Carlos Querejeta, vice president and controller of Serino Coyne, an advertising agency specializing in theatrical accounts, died on Friday at Calvary Hospital in the Bronx. He was 68 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Woman Awaits Posting As a Rabbi in the Army
description: When she was 38, Chana Timoner achieved one of her career goals: She was ordained as a Conservative rabbi. Now, at 41, she has achieved another: She is becoming a soldier.

title: Rival Somali Leaders Meet in Capital and Pledge to Halt Fighting
description: Surrounded by thousands of chanting, singing Somalis, the leaders of this city's two rival clan-based factions met today and renewed promises to end hostilities that have torn this city for two years.

title: New Honeywell Settlements
description: Honeywell Inc. will collect $11.4 million under settlements with three more camera makers relating to patent suits involving the company's automatic-focus technology.

title: Drivefone Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago results are restated.Revenue represented total revenues.The company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: The Neediest Is Lending Hand to Family
description: Victoria and Alan H. go to sleep many nights ashamed of how they are raising their three young daughters. They wish they could nurture the girls by helping them with homework, taking them to museums or pushing them on the swings at the playground. Instead, the girls are often forgotten.

title: Telecommunications Stocks Skid on a Light Trading Day
description: Accidents can happen even in light traffic, as owners of telephone stocks and some other well-known companies learned yesterday in an otherwise quiet trading session.

title: Topics of The Times; Fainthearted Republicans
description: Where do House Republicans stand on ethics? Actually "stand" is the wrong word; it suggests backbone. In the case of Representative Joseph McDade, at least, House Republicans have decided to sit on their hands.

title: Wage Case At Shearson
description: Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc., the nation's second-largest securities firm, is being investigated by the New York State Department of Labor for supposed violations of labor laws at a branch office, Mark Molinari, a department spokesman, said yesterday.

title: CHRONICLE
description: MORTON GOULD may not write music for rock audiences, but let no one say he's not keeping up with the times: his newest composition will be narrated in rap.

title: For a Fee, an Old Friend for a Day
description: HAROLD ADER was not one to trust in doctors. Sure, he had stomach troubles. But he could still drive a concrete truck. Even after his retirement, when inactivity made the illness seem worse, he refused to see a doctor -- until the day before he died of colon cancer last April.

title: American Is Accused of Passing Secrets to Philippine Government
description: A martial arts instructor was arrested on Sunday and accused of obtaining classified documents from a C.I.A. employee in Manila and passing them to the Philippine Government, law-enforcement officials announced today.

title: Shareholder Sues Home Shopping
description: A shareholder of Home Shopping Network Inc. has sued the company and its chairman, Roy Speer, contending that the company has paid Mr. Speer's son Richard at least $7.8 million in fees under a contract that is no longer valid.

title: METROPOLITAN COLLEGE REPORT
description: Of the several college basketball tournaments in the area this week, two offer some intriguing possibilities.

title: Germans Threaten Suit
description: The German Swimming Federation has threatened to sue the sport's world governing body unless it lifts an 18-month ban imposed on a German swimmer accused of doping.

title: DR. PEPPER BOTTLER MAY EXPAND THROUGH ACQUISITION
description: Dr. Pepper Bottling of Texas might acquire smaller, independent bottlers to expand its marketing region, according to regulatory documents. The company, based in Irving, Tex., said it was considering acquiring independent bottlers because "a growing awareness of health-related issues has caused many consumers to shift their preferences away from hot drinks such as tea and coffee and alcoholic beverages towards products such as bottled water, diet and caffeine-free soft drinks," according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Dr. Pepper Bottling of Texas is the largest independent franchised bottler of the soft-drink products.

title: Rohm Is Taking Charges Of $218 Million This Year
description: The Rohm & Haas Company said today that it would take charges of $218 million this year for changes in accounting rules and for costs of scaling back operations at its Philadelphia plant that produces water treatment chemicals.

title: Fonar Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Resolved: To Do Better Next Year
description: WHEREAS the new year is imminent, and;

title: Barton Stacey Journal; The Trout Are THIS BIG and Hard to Swallow
description: On the surface, it is a classic scene from English country life: men in floppy hats and green rubber boots standing silently along the misty shore as they watch their lines drift on the mirror-flat water.

title: Let Teen-Agers Know Medical Risks of Birth Control Implants
description: To the Editor:

title: URS Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Volunteer Fire Brigades Struggle to Survive
description: When floodwaters swept over Broad Channel, Queens, this month, inundating streets and homes and cutting the island community off from the rest of the city, the rescue effort fell to a ragged group of volunteer firefighters. The only problem was that their rickety firehouse was nearly waist-deep in water and one of their two aging firetrucks would not start.

title: Max Gruenewald, 93, A Rabbinical Scholar
description: Dr. Max Gruenewald, international president of the Leo Baeck Institutes and Rabbi Emeritus of Congregation B'nai Israel of Millburn, N.J., died yesterday at his home in Millburn. He was 93.

title: No Headline
description: It is the first time that I have hope for peace. I am very happy. But I don't want either to be President. These two have killed thousands and crushed our country. Today is today. Let them make peace and then we will see. -- NUR AHMED, a 19-year-old Somali, after rival clan leaders met and embraced. [ A6:3 ]

title: KRAFT GENERAL FOODS ACQUIRES FROZEN PIZZA MAKER
description: Kraft General Foods Inc., the food unit of the Philip Morris Companies, has acquired the Jack's Frozen Pizza Company. The terms of the deal were not disclosed.

title: Promises, Promises: Jets Will Be Better in 1993, Says Coslet
description: Bruce Coslet, the Jets' coach, said he opened his post-season speech to the team Sunday by telling them what a lousy season it had been. That was just re-stating the obvious for fullback Brad Baxter, who said that knowing the season was finally over was like waking up from a bad dream.

title: GEO International reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $ 11,007,000 in the quarter and $ 3,630,000 in the year, and both periods included charge of $ 10.6 million to reduce carrying value of discontinued operations, and to accrue estimated costs during the shut-down period.c-Included a loss of $ 805,000 and income of $ 2,644,000, or 15 cents a share, for the quarter and year, respectively, both from discontinued operations.

title: Progress Software reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: The company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: Topics of The Times; Eats Like America
description: The President-elect of the United States is, as The Times's Marian Burros wrote last week, no Jack Sprat. He eats fat. He eats lean. He eats tacos and chili con queso made with three kinds of cheese and three kinds of peppers. He eats ribs, baked beans, slaw, sweet potato pie, bagels, doughnuts and potato salad. Most of all he eats chicken enchiladas.

title: Have Drug Stocks Become a Bargain Yet?
description: Until this year, drug shares had long soared high above the earnings multiples that investors accorded more common stocks. The growth of health spending, drug prices and earnings seemed to defy all laws known to modern finance and medicine.

title: Alexander's Inc. reports earnings for 12wks to Oct 17
description: b-Included loss from discontinued operations of $ 4,754,000.

title: Frances Lehrich, 92, Lawyer and Magistrate
description: Judge Frances Williamson Lehrich, a lawyer and former New York City magistrate, died on Sunday at her home in Manhattan. She was 92.

title: By Design; New Year, New Spirit
description: There's a new year coming, and with it a fresh attitude toward dressing. It's all about lightening up. So discard your hair shirt. Instead, try a chiffon blouse with a deep, ruffled decolletage. If you wear it with nothing underneath, you will certainly be in the avant-garde for '93. But if you do as Ralph Lauren did in his spring collection and toss the chiffon wisp over a natty striped T-shirt, you'll really be in step with the new mixy mood of fashion.

title: Caspian Oil Date Is Set By Chevron
description: The Chevron Corporation said today that it expected to begin full-scale operations on April 1 in its joint venture with the Republic of Kazakhstan to develop the immense Tengiz and Korolev oilfields on the northeastern Caspian Sea coast.

title: Talks With China Mean Jobs for U.S.
description: To the Editor:

title: Big Science Squeezes Small-Scale Researchers
description: THE nation's top Federal agency for the support of basic scientific research is battling to reconcile the growing financial appetite of its biggest project with an overall budget crunch. The conflict is threatening to pull the plug on more than a hundred small-scale science projects across the country.

title: U.N. and The Bosnian Foes Make New Political Attempt in Geneva
description: A plan for ending the war in Bosnia inched forward here today after an extended series of meetings by leaders of the three major ethnic groups under United Nations auspices, participants said.

title: Governor Picks Aide for Senate Seat
description: Gov. Ned McWherter of Tennessee appointed his 65-year-old chief aide today to fill the Senate seat being vacated by Vice President-elect Al Gore.

title: Comet Alert Canceled, Thanks to New Data
description: DOOMSDAY has been postponed a thousand years or so, at least as far as Comet Swift-Tuttle is concerned.

title: Sports of the Times; Sugar Bowl Rocks Early With Strains of Marley
description: THE father was a mystical genius who felt the pain of the world. His name was Bob Marley, and he has been gone since May 9, 1981, but yet he is never gone.

title: Accounts
description: * Thermador, Los Angeles, to deYoung, Ginsberg, Weisman, Bailey, Irvine, Calif., to handle the kitchen appliance maker's account, previously at Ketchum Advertising, Los Angeles. Billings were estimated at $1.5 million.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball National League

title: Miller (Herman) reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 28
description: b-Net loss and included $ 7,976,000 charge for effect of adoption of Statement of Fiscal Accountability 106, Accounting for Income Taxes.The company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: WITNESSES REPORT A SOMALI MASSACRE BEFORE U.S. ARRIVAL
description: More than 100 religious leaders and business executives, a doctor and other prominent residents of this port city were hunted door to door and killed in three nights of terror that began on the eve of the American landing in Mogadishu, Somali witnesses and United States diplomats say.

title: For Anthony, 2 Games Don't Make a Season
description: Greg Anthony still hopes to be the Knicks' starting point guard of the future. He says he still believes he will develop into a consistent floor leader.

title: Northeast Bancorp Gets Buyer
description: After nearly a decade of searching for an out-of-state partner, Connecticut's third-largest banking company, Northeast Bancorp, agreed yesterday to be purchased by First Fidelity Bancorp of New Jersey for $29 million in stock.

title: Review/Music; Traversing A Cycle By Bach
description: For those who do not automatically find the output of Johann Sebastian Bach to be an endless universe of delight, the prospect of hearing all six "Brandenburg" Concertos in one sitting might seem daunting. The New York Chamber Symphony, under the leadership of Jaime Laredo, makes the experience quite painless. The group has made a sturdy holiday tradition out of the cycle; it was, in fact, first formed in 1976 for this purpose. The performances on Sunday afternoon at the 92d Street Y were not perfect, but neither was creation.

title: Clinton Delays Trip To Work, Pack Up And Fill More Jobs
description: Pressed by the lofty concerns of assembling a Government and the more mundane business of packing up a house, President-elect Bill Clinton delayed a planned weeklong vacation to the South Carolina coast today to stay home and work.

title: Kronberger Surprise: She's Finished
description: PETRA KRONBERGER, the world's best woman skier for the past three years, unexpectedly announced yesterday that she was quitting.

title: Tree Fire Kills Girl
description: An 11-year-old girl was burned to death last night when a Christmas tree caught fire at her aunt's apartment at 1315 Amsterdam Avenue, near 123d Street, in Harlem, Fire Department officials said. The dead girl was identified as Elaine Pino. Deputy Fire Commissioner Harry Ryttenberg said the girl was carrying a lighted candle shortly before the blaze and that "moments later the place was totally engulfed in flames." Three adults in the apartment, on the 14th floor of a 21-story apartment building, were unharmed, fire officials said.

title: The Best Case for the Pardons
description: Surely, reasonable people have said to themselves in the days since President Bush shocked the country with his Iran-contra pardons -- surely the President must have had good reasons. Surely he would not wish to live forever in history as the President who in effect pardoned himself. Surely he must have some plausible arguments for exonerating Caspar Weinberger even before his trial, and other officials after theirs.

title: The Pugnacious Domi Is Sent To the Ice Box: Winnipeg
description: Tie Domi had been invited by the Rangers' coaching staff to dress for only 12 hockey games this season, but the right wing represented something that went well beyond his two goals and no assists.

title: Land-Based Missiles Are Obsolete
description: If Bill Clinton is searching for ways to cut defense spending without reducing important military capabilities and without creating inordinate short-term unemployment, an unclassified General Accounting Office report provides a wonderful guide for reductions in a key area: nuclear weapons.

title: Review/Dance; Life's Eternal Mysteries Shaped by Movement
description: By offering two varied programs on Sunday at the City Center, the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater served as a choreographic showcase for fine dancers.

title: A 2-Way Street for Sharing Data Between Macs and I.B.M.'s
description: EXCHANGING files between two computers in a home office or small business is sometimes easiest via the "sneaker net," making a copy of a file on a floppy disk in one machine and walking over to put the floppy into the other one. You would not want to run a multinational corporation that way, but when the other computer is in the same room, or just down the hall, it is a quick and dirty solution.

title: Beyond the No-Flight Zone in Iraq
description: Baghdad, not Washington, provoked Sunday's aerial clash over southern Iraq by sending warplanes into a no-flight zone. U.S. planes responded admirably, showing resolve but also prudence. The first pair of Iraqi MIG's was turned back peacefully. One of a second pair was downed after turning to confront American planes.

title: Getty Petroleum Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: Revenue represented total revenues.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: QUANTUM FUND N.V., has acquired a 5.4 percent stake in Universal Health Services Inc., King of Prussia, Pa., a hospital management company, by buying 67,000 class B common shares at $13.875 to $14 a share on Dec. 16-17.

title: Bigger Bailout Is Proposed For Insurer
description: With state officials three days away from deciding whether to grant a heavy rate increase to the state's largest health insurer, Senate Republican leaders proposed today to reduce the size of the increase by raising the amount of a state bailout for Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield.

title: Joule's Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Fare Cuts Considered
description: The nation's other major carriers are studying Northwest Airlines' decision to extend its deadline for cut-rate European fares, but not all have matched the offer.

title: Super Food Services reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 21
Chess
description: Patrick Wolff struggled successfully all the way to triumph in the United States championship. Although he had almost no easy games, the 24-year-old grandmaster from Somerville, Mass., and former Yale star, scored 10 1/2-4 1/2 to take the $10,000 first prize of a total $30,000 purse put up by the chief sponsor, Software Toolworks. Wolff was also awarded the $1,500 Albaugh prize for being the solo winner in the tournament, played Dec. 1-20 in Durango, Colo.

title: 'Murderers Must Be Punished for Their Horrendous Acts'
description: To the Editor:

title: 10,000 Residents of Dresden Join Candlelit Protest Against Racism
description: More than 10,000 residents of this historic eastern German city took to the streets today for a silent candlelit vigil against racism and rightist violence.

title: U.S. Bonds Fall in Light Trading
description: Treasury bond and note prices declined yesterday in very light trading.

title: Graduate Study for Factory Hands
description: Shawn Wilson held part of a fuel tank firmly against a heavy metal table and began pounding an uneven flange to flatten it for welding. With each stroke, she added to the din at the sprawling factory here in this industrial city's still-vigorous West Side. And with each stroke, she came a little closer to a secure, good-paying job in a high-tech factory of the future.

title: AirSensors Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Stephen J. Albert, 51, Composer; Won a Pulitzer for His 'Riverrun'
description: Stephen J. Albert, a composer of lushly scored, dramatic symphonic music who won the 1985 Pulitzer Prize for his "Symphony Riverrun" was killed on Sunday afternoon in an automobile accident in Truro, Mass. He was 51 years old and had homes in Newton Center, Mass., and in Truro, on Cape Cod.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The music aficionados who bought tickets to see SOUTHSIDE JOHNNY perform at the Stone Pony in Asbury Park, N.J., on Sunday night had not a clue to the surprise that awaited shortly after midnight: an appearance by BRUCE SPRINGSTEEN.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a punctuation error in transmission, a sports article yesterday about the Knicks included a sentence erroneously in a quotation from Coach Pat Riley about Greg Anthony, a Knick guard. The sentence -- "His biggest problems are upstairs" -- was the article writer's, and should have preceded the coach's comment.

title: With Broncos Ousted, It's Farewell to Reeves
description: A week after quarterback John Elway contended that Coach Dan Reeves should turn more responsibility for the Broncos' offense over to his assistants, Reeves wound up yesterday yielding the entire coaching job in Denver.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: FAILURES OF AN OVERLOADED SYSTEM

title: Potomac Electric Power Co reports earnings for 12mos to Nov 30
description: Year-ago period's revenue was restated to include revenues from interchange deliveries previously classified as a credit to expense.

title: Sal Maglie, Star Pitcher of the 1950's, Dies at 75
description: Sal Maglie, who pitched for all three New York teams during the tumultuous baseball wars of the 1950's and who intimidated batters with hard looks and high, hard fastballs, died yesterday in a nursing home in Niagara Falls, N.Y. He was 75.

title: Litany of Signals Overlooked in Child's Death
description: Even in New York City's troubled child protection system, this oversight was remarkable: None of the caseworkers who investigated allegations that Doris Harden had mistreated her children discovered that she had previously served three years in prison for holding down a 7-year-old girl while another young woman sexually assaulted the child with a toilet plunger.

title: Plea Bargains Make No Sense in Rapes
description: To the Editor:

title: Girl, 9, Is Called Missing From L.I. Video Arcade
description: A 9-year-old girl was apparently kidnapped from a video arcade in Nesconset, L.I., minutes after she wandered away from a family friend who was taking care of her, the Suffolk County police said today.

title: Fear of the Rainbow
description: Two books published by my company, "Daddy's Roommate" and "Heather Has Two Mommies," are in the middle of the controversy surrounding the "Children of the Rainbow" first-grade curriculum.

title: Ted Shearer, 73, Dies; Cartoonist for 'Quincy'
description: Ted Shearer, an illustrator, cartoonist and painter, died on Saturday at Northern Westchester Hospital Center in Mount Kisco, N.Y. He was 73 and lived in Pound Ridge, N.Y.

title: Kenya Votes, a Mirror Perhaps of Democracy in Africa
description: With the country's political stability hanging in the balance, millions of Kenyans voted today, their first broadly contested election in nearly a quarter-century.

title: Bosnian Muslims Want Arms to Fight
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY: A Year of Transitions; Planning a Future of Telephones Without Tethers
description: In 1992, the telecommunications industry was not so much on hold as on continuous call-waiting, with the forces of new technology, industry consolidation and government regulation piling up like so many urgent telephone messages.

title: A Schoolteacher Pushes Use of Home Schooling
description: Behind a cedar grove in a house near the beach, the Guterson clan gathers for school at dawn. Cleared of breakfast bowls, the dining room table is set for class -- English, a bit of geography, some math.

title: Wheatley TXT reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: The year-ago 9 months' share earnings was after payment of $ 307,000 for dividends on and accretion of preferred stock.The company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: Estelle Bauer, Lawyer, 91
description: Estelle Bauer, who practiced law for more than 50 years, died yesterday at her home in Manhattan. She was 91.

title: CHRONICLE
description: BARBARA GALANTE and BRIAN DOYLE expect 6,000 or so people in attendance and fireworks in the skies when they are married in Central Park tomorrow before taking off on the five-mile New Year's Eve Midnight Run.

title: Concord Fabrics Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 29
description: b-Net loss

title: Lee Pharmaceuticals reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
The Quilted Giraffe Joins the Dinosaurs
description: TOMORROW evening, the champagne toasts at the Quilted Giraffe will welcome 1993 on a poignant note. In the first dawn of the new year, the granite tables in this sleek, trend-setting luxury restaurant in Manhattan, one of America's best, will be cleared for good.

title: Vivienne Segal, 95, a Stage Star In Roles Sweet to Cynical, Is Dead
description: Vivienne Segal, a musical-comedy star who appeared on Broadway in "The Desert Song," "No, No, Nanette," and "Pal Joey," died yesterday in Los Angeles. She was 95 years old and lived in Beverly Hills.

title: Corrections
description: In yesterday's column the result was misstated. The declarer lost 13 tricks and was down 11.

title: Defense Tactic in Sex Abuse Case Defeats Itself
description: To the Editor:

title: Shootings in Somalia Reflect Rising Tension for U.S. Troops
description: Shootings and car thefts in Mogadishu, often aimed at military and relief workers, have increased markedly in recent days, underscoring what American military officials say is a heightened tension in the capital.

title: Kentucky Fried Brings Back Slogan
description: The Kentucky Fried Chicken Corporation is bringing back a popular slogan as it continues efforts to bolster its business.

title: Yugoslav Premier Ousted by Foes 6 Months After Return From U.S.
description: Communists and nationalists combined forces in the federal Parliament today to oust Prime Minister Milan Panic. The move apparently ended the short but highly unusual political career of Mr. Panic, an American citizen who many in the West had hoped would somehow take power and end the war in Bosnia and Herzegovina.

title: The Movers and Shakers Moved and Shook
description: FOR the advertising industry, 1992 was not quite the annus horribilis that Queen Elizabeth II bemoaned, but it certainly was an annus tumultuous.

title: New Yorker Makes Sparkling Riesling In British Columbia
description: MOST New Yorkers, it is safe to say, have never drunk holiday toasts with a sparkling wine from British Columbia. And many, it is safer to say, will usher in 1993 with Champagne and other bubblies inferior to Cipes brut from Canada.

title: McDonnell in Deal With I.B.M. Unit
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation, the military contractor and commercial airplane manufacturer, said yesterday that it would turn over most of its information processing operations to an I.B.M. unit.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on Dec. 22 about a gene, bcl-2, that can make a cell live forever misidentified the scientist who studied the gene in 1987 and noted its connection to follicular lymphoma. He is Dr. David Vaux, not Dr. Irving Weissman.

title: Yvonne Brown, Commissioner's Wife, 55
description: Yvonne Brown, the wife of Lee P. Brown, the former New York City Police Commissioner, died yesterday in Houston. She was 55.

title: Seton Hall Prevails But Cal Is Upset
description: As matchups go, this would have been intriguing: Seton Hall vs. California, Terry Dehere vs. Jason Kidd.

title: Eighties, Nineties and Oh's
description: There'll be no doubt tomorrow night, when the world rings in the new year, about what to call it. The name "1993" is neither ambiguous nor controversial. If only that were true about what to call the next decade.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Night column in Styles of The Times on Dec. 20 about a premiere party for the film "Toys" misidentified a star of the film. The star is Joan Cusack, not John Cusack. (A correction in this space on Sunday rendered both performers' names incorrectly.)

title: College Hockey Report
description: Tournaments

title: No Headline
description: People who boycott Aspen must realize it's like attacking the Jews in the Warsaw ghetto because of the Nazis. -- HARLEY BALDWIN, the owner of a nightclub in Aspen, Colo. [ B16:5. ] This boycott is going to hurt us badly, and it should. What has happened in this state is a disgrace. -- RUDOLPH, an owner of another nightclub there. [ B16:6. ]

title:
Market Place;
2 New Drugs Win F.D.A. Approval
description: Indicating Taxol's potential importance for cancer patients, it was rushed to approval in only six months after Bristol-Myers Squibb submitted test results on July 22. The F.D.A. often takes two years to review a new drug, although it has pledged to shorten the wait with the help of industry user fees, which will pay for adding reviewers.

title: Ex-New Yorkers Keep Links To City Via Neediest Cases
description: They abandoned New York City because they had grown weary of so many facets of urban life: the sidewalks packed with get-out-of-my-way pedestrians, the inescapable noise and pollution, the poverty that greeted them when they stepped onto the street or the subway.

title: Review/Film; Parents Fighting to Keep Their Child Alive
description: "Lorenzo's Oil" is the tough-minded, completely gripping story of Augusto and Michaela Odone, parents who responded magnificently after receiving the worst conceivable news about their child. At 5, Lorenzo Odone began exhibiting symptoms of what would soon be diagnosed as adrenoleukodystrophy, a rare and invariably fatal disease. The Odones were essentially told that the best they could do would be to make Lorenzo's last days comfortable. They were told that he would die within two years.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Business Technology

title: C.D. Yields Unchanged For Week
